    "https://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/2024-03-14/national/socialAffairs/3-dead-1-missing-as-fishing-boat-sinks-by-South-Gyeongsang/2002085": "3 dead, 1 missing as fishing boat sinks by South Gyeongsang\n\">\nquickmenu\nsearch\nGO\nkcampus\nceleb\nNewsletter\nSubscribe\nFree Sample\nkorea joongAng daily\nNational\nKorea JoongAng Daily\nGO\nHome\n>\nNational\n>\nSocial Affairs\ndictionary\n+ A\n- A\n3 dead, 1 missing as fishing boat sinks by South Gyeongsang\nPublished: 14 Mar. 2024, 10:32\nUpdated: 14 Mar. 2024, 17:44\nLEE SOO-JUNG\n[email protected]\nSearch and rescue teams from the Korea Coast Guard on Thursday look for survivors from a fishing boat that sunk 8.5 kilometers (5.28 miles) off the coast of Yokji-do, an island in Tongyeong, South Gyeongsang. [YONHAP]         A fishing boat sank off the southern coast of Korea on Thursday dawn, leaving 10 rescued and one missing.           The inundated boat sank in waters not far from an island near Yokji-do, Tongyeong in South Gyeongsang at 4:15 a.m.            Of the rescued, three Koreans were pronounced dead after being transported to a hospital in unconscious state. A captain is one of the victims.           The other rescued crew members — one Vietnamese and six Indonesians — were confirmed to have no health issues.            The rescue team is currently searching for the last missing Korean crew member.           The Korea Coast Guard (KCG) Tongyeong Station received a report of the sinking ship at 4:15 a.m.           The KCG mobilized 16 coast patrol ships, two naval warships, two vessels from affiliated authorities and a privately-owned vessel for its rescue mission. Three aircraft are additionally aiding rescue efforts.           The 169-ton pair trawler departed from Dongho Port, Tongyeong at 5:10 p.m. on Wednesday and was scheduled to return on Thursday. It completely sank underwater as of Thursday 9 a.m.           The KCG launched an underwater rescue and search on Thursday at noon based on the identified location of the ship.           “The authorities are open to all possibilities regarding cause of the accident,” an official from the KCG said.             On the same day, the Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries announced that a total of 3,092 marine accidents happened last year. Some 94 people died or went missing due to such accidents last year.     BY LEE SOO-JUNG, HYEON YE-SEUL [[email protected]]\nKorea\nFishing boat\nTongyeong\nKorea Coast Guard\nSearch and Rescue\nSinking\nSouth Gyeongsang\nMore in Social Affairs\nMajor highways remain congested on Lunar New Year; traffic expected to ease in evening\nNo. of injured victims from Busan airplane fire rises to 7, all with minor injuries\nAir Busan plane on fire at Gimhae International Airport: fire authorities\nSick during the Lunar New Year? [NEWS1]                Five fishermen were rescued and one remains missing after a fishing vessel capsized in waters off Korea’s southeastern coast on Sunday.           A 9.77-ton fishing boat with six crew members on board overturned approximately 120 kilometers (74 miles) east of Guryongpo in Pohang, North Gyeongsang, at around 2:40 a.m. on Sunday, the Korea Coast Guard said.           The rescuers found two of the crew holding the screw at the rear of the boat and two stranded inside the air pocket.            The other was saved by a nearby fishing vessel.            The Coast Guard mobilized eight patrol ships and three aircraft to find the missing mariner, identified as an Indonesian in his 20s.            The authorities said that four survivors were in stable condition. The other, the first rescued, was sent to a hospital because of his critical condition.     "https://m.koreaherald.com/amp/view.php?ud=20240301050207": "Fishing boat capsizes off Jeju; 1 dead, 2 missing - The Korea Herald\nSearch\nFor our subscribers\nMy Page\nNational\nAll\nPolitics\nSeoul\nEducation\nSocial Affairs\nCourts and Law\nForeign Affairs\nMilitary\nNorth Korea\nDiplomatic Circuit\nHealth\nBusiness\nAll\nIndustry\nTechnology\nMobility\nConsumer\nEconomy\nMarket\nLife&Culture\nAll\nCulture\nTravel\nFood\nBooks\nPeople\nFilm\nTelevision\nPerformance\nSports\nAll\nSoccer\nBaseball\nGolf\nMore Sports\nWorld\nAll\nWorld News\nWorld Business\nOpinion\nAll\nEditorial\nViewpoints\nK-pop\nRecipe\n한국어판\nLiving In Seoul Map\nMore +\n#Hashtag Korea\nWeekender\nEnglish Eye\nPodcast\nPR newswire\nPrint edition\nPC Version\nRSS\n인스타그램\n페이스북\n트위터\n링크드인\nNational\nSocial Affairs\nFishing boat capsizes off Jeju; 1 dead, 2 missing\nMarch 1, 2024 - 20:13:02\nBy Yonhap\n0\n0\nCopy Completed!\nThis image provided by the Coast Guard shows a fishing boat that capsized in waters off the southern island of Jeju on Friday. (Yonhap) SEOGWIPO -- A fishing boat with 10 crew members on board capsized off the southern island of Jeju on Friday, leaving one of them dead and two others missing, the Coast Guard said.Five South Korean and five Vietnamese were aboard the 33-ton vessel when it overturned in waters about 12 nautical miles off the city of Seogwipo at 7:24 a.m., Coast Guard officials said.Eight crew members -- three South Koreans and five Vietnamese -- were rescued by a nearby fishing boat, but one of them, a South Korean, was pronounced dead at 10:07 a.m. after being transferred to a hospital under cardiac arrest. The seven others were being treated for hypothermia.The Coast Guard is searching for the two missing South Koreans, including the captain.Officials said six Coast Guard patrol vessels and three helicopters were conducting a search operation within a 3.6-kilometer radius of the accident site, but strong winds and high waves are hampering the operation.One Coast Guard official also sustained a serious injury and was taken to a hospital after being swept by waves while searching the capsized boat, officials said.Meanwhile, the Jeju Special Self-Governing Province Office said it has set up an emergency headquarters to spearhead the rescue operations. The incident happened around Boadzulu Island in the district which is in Southern Region of the country.\nKayenda has identified the two as Lakson Mapulanga from Mwanyama Village and Edward Manyozo from Makawa Village, both in the area of Traditional Authority Mponda.\nThe incident comes days after two fishermen also went missing when their fishing boat capsized on Lake Malawi at Chizumulu Island in the Northern Region.\nThe two went missing on Sunday, May 2 at night and their bodies were found in a decomposed state yesterday.\nPolice Officer In-Charge for Likoma district Superintendent Active Mkandawire said the fishermen drowned after their boat capsized due to strong wind.     "https://malawi24.com/2023/07/17/fisherman-drowns-in-lake-malawi-in-nkhata-bay/": "Fisherman drowns in Lake Malawi in Nkhata Bay | Malawi 24 | Latest News from Malawi\nMiracles\nWeird News\nHot Gossip\nContact Us\nDonate\nSports\nEntertainment\nHome\nNational\nPolitics\nHot Gossip\nSports\nEntertainment\nWorld News\nAdvertise With Us\nPrivacy Policy\nMiracles\nWeird News\nHot Gossip\nContact Us\nDonate\nSports\nEntertainment\nRecent News\nMANEB seeks $1.5 million to offset exam costs\nNational\nMLS suspends Nankhuni, partners for improper conduct\nNational\nAce Jizzy’s ‘Dodidodi’ raises eyebrows with Gattah mention\nNational\nWill South Africa qualify for the 2026 World Cup?\nNational\nAnthu 56 akubwela kuno kumudzi atapitikitsidwa ndi Trump ku Amereka\nNational\nLow turnout mars supplementary registration in Dowa\nNational\n$5 million investment set to boost Malawi’s agricultural sector\nNational\nSearch for:\nHome\nTop News\nFisherman drowns in Lake Malawi in Nkhata Bay\nFisherman drowns in Lake Malawi in Nkhata Bay\nJul 17, 2023\nMike Lyson Zgambo\nTop News\n0\nAdvertisement\nA 24-year-old man who has been identified as Timothy Banda has drowned in Lake Malawi in Nkhata Bay District after the canoe he was sailing in while fishing capsized.\nAccording to a report filed at Chintheche Police Post, the fisherman on July 16, 2023 afternoon, went into the lake for fishing.\nWhilst in the lake, heavy Mwera winds started blowing causing strong waves that forced the canoe to capsize. The fisherman eventually got drowned.\nFamily members got the information and embarked on a search and found their relative in unconscious state.\nThe matter was eventually reported to Chintheche Police Post where Police Officers rushed to the scene and took the body to Kachere health center where death was confirmed.\nAn autopsy conducted at the health center revealed that Banda died of suffocation.\nMeanwhile, police in the district are advising fishermen to avoid plying their trade in harsh weather as advised by the Department of Metrological Services.\nTimothy Banda hailed from Chivuta Village, Traditional Authority Fukamapiri in Nkhata Bay District.\nShare this:\ndeathDrowningLake Malawi\nAdvertisement\nPreviousMedia practitioners asked to report positive news to attract     "https://malawimuslims.com/news/two-fishermen-found-dead-in-lake-malawi/": "Two fishermen found dead in lake Malawi – Malawi Muslims Official Website\nNo Result  View All Result\nLogin\nHome Religion Business Health Education Entertainment Politics Sports World\nContact Us\nHome Religion Business Health Education Entertainment Politics Sports World\nNo Result  View All Result\nMalawi Muslims Official Website\nNo Result  View All Result\nHome Religion Business Health Education Entertainment Politics Sports World\nHome  Featured\nTwo fishermen found dead in lake Malawi\nby mmw 2 years ago in Featured, General   Reading Time: 1 min read\nA A\nA\nA\nReset 0\n0SHARES\n0VIEWS\nShare on FacebookShare on TwitterShare on Whatsapp\nThe dead bodies of fishermen who went missing after their canoe capsized due to a heavy Mwera storm have been found floating near Mtondo fishing dock.\nRELATED POSTS\nPastor Builds Grass-thatched Mosque\nLack of Mosque Worries Former Pastor\nGovt says SAPP will increase number of IPPs to invest in the country\nThe deceased have been identified as Ishmael Israel and Shiluba full particulars not advised, went missing on August 29, 2021 at Chiphole fishing dock along Lake Malawi in Mangohi district.\nAccording to Mangochi police station spokesperson Amina Tepani Daudi, on the said date, four fishermen including the deceased went fishing on the waters of Lake Malawi in one canoe despite strong winds.\nDaudi says in the process, their canoe got capsized and all of them fell into the water. Luckily, the two among them survived while others went missing.\nADVERTISEMENT“Members of the community organized a search party that later found the two body bodies floating on August 31, 2021. The Police and medical personnel from Maganga Health Centre visited the scene and suffocation has been indicated as the cause of the death,” Daudi says.\nPolice in the district is appealing to fishermen to pay attention to weather conditions and forecasts, allowing time to plan for threatening weather and react properly to avoid similar incidents.\nShareTweetSend\nRelated Posts\nFeatured\nPastor Builds Grass-thatched Mosque\nby Davie Katuli January 15, 2024 0  0  A former pastor, Pastor Gama, who has recently made headlines with his recent venture into Islam, has taken a bold...     "https://maritime-executive.com/article/alaskan-fishing-vessel-capsizes-in-icy-strait-five-missing": "Alaskan Fishing Vessel Capsizes in Icy Strait, Five Missing\nGo\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nMedia Kit\nnews\nFeatures\nPodcasts\nMagazine\nNewsletter\nJobs\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nnews\nfeatures\nPodcasts\nmagazine\nnewsletter\nJobs\nadvertise\nsubscribe\nTOP STORIES\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSenate Committee Calls on FMC as it Explores Situation at the Panama Canal\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nProduct Tanker Towed to Marseille After Engine Room Fire\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nGlosten Joins Core Power's Nuclear Power Barge Project\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\n18513\nViews\nAlaskan Fishing Vessel Capsizes in Icy Strait, Five Missing\nUSCG file image\nPublished\nDec 1, 2024 4:00 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nA search is under way for the crew of a commercial fishing vessel that capsized in frigid waters and severe weather off the coast of Couverden Island, Alaska.\nAt about 0010 hours on Sunday morning, Coast Guard Sector Southeast Alaska received a VHF mayday call from the crew of the fishing vessel Wind Walker. The crew reported that they were capsizing off Couverden Point, about 60 nautical miles south of Haines. The crew dropped out of contact, and no further responses were heard over VHF. Shortly after, the Coast Guard received an alert from the Wind Walker's EPIRB at a position in Icy Strait.\nThe Coast Guard did not get a definite count on the number of crewmembers aboard, but people who knew the vessel reported that there should have been five fisherman working on Wind Walker at the time. The count has not been confirmed.\nSector Southeast Alaska issued an urgent broadcast and dispatched a helicopter aircrew from Coast Guard Air Station Sitka, along with a response boat from Station Juneau to search the area.\nThe Alaska Marine Highway ferry Hubbard overheard the broadcast and diverted to assist, and she was the first on scene. In heavy snow and winds of up to 50 knots, the ferry and the Coast Guard responders began a search. Seven cold-water immersion suits and two strobe lights were located in the water in the search area, but no crewmembers.\nHubbard departed the search area midmorning and continued on her commercial voyage, according to AIS data provided by Pole Star. Coast Guard Cutter Healy arrived in the search area at about the same time, replacing Hubbard.\nMORE TOP STORIES\nItalian Coast Guard Responds to Two Groundings in Two Days\nBulker Operator Claims Proof That Subsea Cable Damage Was Accidental\nSean Duffy Confirmed as U.S. Secretary of Transportation\nContainership Schedule Reliability Stabilized Absorbing Red Sea Diversions\nEDITORIALS TOP STORIES\nIs Russia Helping China Build a Hybrid-Nuclear Submarine?\nWhy Shared Governance Could Save Our Oceans\nBeijing Struggles to Control Provinces as They Expand Distant-Water Fleet\nOp-Ed: Tide is Turning on Maritime Corruption, But We Must Finish the Job\nAn IMO Commitment to Polar Fuels Could Cut Black Carbon Emissions\nSUBSCRIPTIONS\nSUBSCRIBE\nPrint\nDigital\nNewsletter\nRenew\nSubscribe Now\nRELATED STORIES\nShipping\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nJan 29, 2025 4:11 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpain’s Policía Nacional working in coordination with the Tax Authority reports it has conducted a series of arrests breaking up a gang smuggling cocaine hidden in industrial machinery from South America aboard ships arriving at Spanish ports. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore released the details after it received information from the China Maritime Safety Administration.\nAccording to the reports, the accident took place a week ago on December 26 when the new bunker tanker was making its way from Chenghan Jiao in Northern China to Zhoushan. The vessel was built for Consort Bunkers which has operations in both Singapore and Zhoushan. It is unclear from the reports if the tanker may have been on her delivery run from the shipyard to her home base in China or if the plans called for her to proceed to Singapore.\nThe 7,999 dwt tanker Pearl Kenzo was built for Consort as part of the bunker company’s expansion effort. The new vessel is 377 feet (115 meters) in length with a reported top speed of 12 knots. She was underway on December 26 when shortly after midnight she collided with a Chinese-flagged fishing vessel Suiyupu 0183.\nThe China Maritime Safety Administration organized a search and rescue mission. They informed the MPA that the fishing boat had sunk and eight crewmembers were missing. The crew of the bunker vessel was reported uninjured.\nThe vessel had just completed construction earlier in the month at Jinglu Shipbuilding. The naming and handover ceremony took place on December 18. The shipyard highlighted the ship has unique capabilities with a special coating for its tanks that gives it extra versatility in its cargo operations. It can load up to 9,000 cubic meters and also adopts a double-hull structure for its tanks for increased safety and environmental security. It was apparently traveling without cargo at the time of the collision and there are no reports of environmental spills from the accident.\nThe Chinese officials are reporting that after the accident the bunker vessel has remained anchored at Shidao in northern China while the investigation is underway.\nMORE TOP STORIES\nItalian Coast Guard Responds to Two Groundings in Two Days\nBulker Operator Claims Proof That Subsea Cable Damage Was Accidental\nSean Duffy Confirmed as U.S. Secretary of Transportation\nContainership Schedule Reliability Stabilized Absorbing Red Sea Diversions\nEDITORIALS TOP STORIES\nIs Russia Helping China Build a Hybrid-Nuclear Submarine?\nWhy Shared Governance Could Save Our Oceans\nBeijing Struggles to Control Provinces as They Expand Distant-Water Fleet\nOp-Ed: Tide is Turning on Maritime Corruption, But We Must Finish the Job\nAn IMO Commitment to Polar Fuels Could Cut Black Carbon Emissions\nSUBSCRIPTIONS\nSUBSCRIBE\nPrint\nDigital\nNewsletter\nRenew\nSubscribe Now\nRELATED STORIES\nShipping\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nJan 29, 2025 4:11 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpain’s Policía Nacional working in coordination with the Tax Authority reports it has conducted a series of arrests breaking up a gang smuggling cocaine hidden in industrial machinery from South America aboard ships arriving at Spanish ports.     "https://maritime-executive.com/article/experienced-fisherman-dies-of-hypothermia-in-english-channel-rescue": "Experienced Fisherman Dies of Hypothermia in English Channel Rescue\nGo\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nMedia Kit\nnews\nFeatures\nPodcasts\nMagazine\nNewsletter\nJobs\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nnews\nfeatures\nPodcasts\nmagazine\nnewsletter\nJobs\nadvertise\nsubscribe\nTOP STORIES\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSenate Committee Calls on FMC as it Explores Situation at the Panama Canal\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nProduct Tanker Towed to Marseille After Engine Room Fire\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nGlosten Joins Core Power's Nuclear Power Barge Project\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\n2546\nViews\nExperienced Fisherman Dies of Hypothermia in English Channel Rescue\nEastbourne RNLI lifeboat responds to the distress call from the Jerki (Eastbourne RNLI)\nPublished\nJan 6, 2025 6:29 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nLast weekend, an experienced fisherman went over the side of a commercial trawler in the English Channel and died of hypothermia, according to local media.\nGlenn Vandewalle, 50, was a lifelong fisherman and a crewmember aboard the beam trawler Jerki Z-45. On Saturday, the vessel was operating about 12 nautical miles off Eastbourne, England in rough weather when Vandewalle fell over the side.\nHis crewmates initiated a rescue and called the UK Coastguard for help. The Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) station in Eastborne received the call just before midnight and quickly dispatched their volunteer-crewed response boat, the Esme Anderson, to join the search.\nThe Jerki's crew conducted their own search pattern for Vandewalle, though they were hampered by onboard mechanical troubles. In darkness, driving rain and waves of up to 12 feet, the small trawler's crew managed to find the helmsman in the water. They recovered him aboard the vessel, but he succumbed to hypothermia.\nThe RNLI lifeboat stood down and returned to its station once the Jerki had Vandewalle aboard; the trawler returned to port at Oostende, Belgium to deliver the victim's body to shore.\nThe public prosecutor's office in West Flanders, Belgium has started an investigation into how Vandewalle went over the side, but at this point officials are treating the casualty as an accident, according to The Fishing Daily.\nJerki's operating company, Aude Audenda, issued a brief statement commemorating Vandewalle's life and expressing sympathy for his loved ones. \"Out of respect for the family and our crew, we want to let them process this tragic accident in peace,\" the firm said. \"We can only stress that Glenn was a well-liked and experienced fisherman, a fisherman through and through.\"\nMORE TOP STORIES\nItalian Coast Guard Responds to Two Groundings in Two Days\nBulker Operator Claims Proof That Subsea Cable Damage Was Accidental\nSean Duffy Confirmed as U.S. Secretary of Transportation\nContainership Schedule Reliability Stabilized Absorbing Red Sea Diversions\nEDITORIALS TOP STORIES\nIs Russia Helping China Build a Hybrid-Nuclear Submarine?\nWhy Shared Governance Could Save Our Oceans\nBeijing Struggles to Control Provinces as They Expand Distant-Water Fleet\nOp-Ed: Tide is Turning on Maritime Corruption, But We Must Finish the Job\nAn IMO Commitment to Polar Fuels Could Cut Black Carbon Emissions\nSUBSCRIPTIONS\nSUBSCRIBE\nPrint\nDigital\nNewsletter\nRenew\nSubscribe Now\nRELATED STORIES\nShipping\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nJan 29, 2025 4:11 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpain’s Policía Nacional working in coordination with the Tax Authority reports it has conducted a series of arrests breaking up a gang smuggling cocaine hidden in industrial machinery from South America aboard ships arriving at Spanish ports.     "https://maritime-executive.com/article/fisherman-missing-and-presumed-dead-in-barents-sea-man-overboard": "Fisherman Missing and Presumed Dead in Barents Sea Man-Overboard\nGo\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nMedia Kit\nnews\nFeatures\nPodcasts\nMagazine\nNewsletter\nJobs\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nnews\nfeatures\nPodcasts\nmagazine\nnewsletter\nJobs\nadvertise\nsubscribe\nTOP STORIES\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSenate Committee Calls on FMC as it Explores Situation at the Panama Canal\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nProduct Tanker Towed to Marseille After Engine Room Fire\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nGlosten Joins Core Power's Nuclear Power Barge Project\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\n4323\nViews\nFisherman Missing and Presumed Dead in Barents Sea Man-Overboard\nThe Norwegian patrol vessel Barentshav, above, led the search on scene (Bjoertvedt / CC BY SA 3.0)\nPublished\nNov 18, 2022 1:40 AM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nA fisherman who went over the side of a trawler in the Barents Sea on Tuesday is presumed dead, according to the Northern Norway Rescue Center.\nJo Aron Kvinge Rogne, 26, was reported missing aboard the freezer trawler Langenes just before 2000 hours on Tuesday. A substantial search effort was launched, and eleven good samaritan fishing vessels answered the call for assistance. One of them was a Russian-flagged trawler, the Norskehavet.\nCoordinated by Norwegian authorities and the Norwegian patrol vessel Barentshav, this fleet fanned out in a line and swept the area in a deliberate search pattern. Two helicopters joined the operation as well.\nConditions were difficult, with strong winds and rough waves, according to the rescue center. No sign of the missing fisherman was found overnight, and the search was called off Wednesday afternoon.\nA crisis team was activated to assist the crew of the Langenes and the family of the victim.\n\"We have had the worst possible outcome of this tragic event,\" said Tore Roaldsnes, the general manager of operator Bluewild AS, speaking to Fiskeribladet. The company extended its condolences to the family of the victim and its thanks to the many vessels that helped out with the search.\nMORE TOP STORIES\nItalian Coast Guard Responds to Two Groundings in Two Days\nBulker Operator Claims Proof That Subsea Cable Damage Was Accidental\nSean Duffy Confirmed as U.S. Secretary of Transportation\nContainership Schedule Reliability Stabilized Absorbing Red Sea Diversions\nEDITORIALS TOP STORIES\nIs Russia Helping China Build a Hybrid-Nuclear Submarine?\nWhy Shared Governance Could Save Our Oceans\nBeijing Struggles to Control Provinces as They Expand Distant-Water Fleet\nOp-Ed: Tide is Turning on Maritime Corruption, But We Must Finish the Job\nAn IMO Commitment to Polar Fuels Could Cut Black Carbon Emissions\nSUBSCRIPTIONS\nSUBSCRIBE\nPrint\nDigital\nNewsletter\nRenew\nSubscribe Now\nRELATED STORIES\nShipping\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nJan 29, 2025 4:11 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpain’s Policía Nacional working in coordination with the Tax Authority reports it has conducted a series of arrests breaking up a gang smuggling cocaine hidden in industrial machinery from South America aboard ships arriving at Spanish ports.     "https://maritime-executive.com/article/five-danish-fishermen-charged-with-killing-a-shipmate": "Five Danish Fishermen Charged With Killing a Shipmate\nGo\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nMedia Kit\nnews\nFeatures\nPodcasts\nMagazine\nNewsletter\nJobs\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nnews\nfeatures\nPodcasts\nmagazine\nnewsletter\nJobs\nadvertise\nsubscribe\nTOP STORIES\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSenate Committee Calls on FMC as it Explores Situation at the Panama Canal\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nProduct Tanker Towed to Marseille After Engine Room Fire\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nGlosten Joins Core Power's Nuclear Power Barge Project\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\n5206\nViews\nFive Danish Fishermen Charged With Killing a Shipmate\nPublic domain / Pixabay\nPublished\nFeb 6, 2023 4:31 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nFive fishermen have been detained by authorities in the village of Thyboron, Denmark in connection with the violent death of a new shipmate.\nOn the morning of January 30, Danish authorities received a request for assistance from the fishing vesel Inger Katrine, which was operating in the North Sea. The crew reported that a crewmember was unresponsive and lifeless, and asked for a medevac. A helicopter flew the victim to a local hospital, where he was pronounced dead.\nWeather in the North Sea was foul at the time, and it was not safe for the Inger Katrine to return to port in Thyboron, nor was it practical for the authorities to board the vessel to investigate. She finally entered the harbor on Wednesday, and local police arrested her crew at the pier. The vessel and a fish hold full of plaice were detained while investigators scoured the ship for clues.\nOn Thursday, a local court heard charges that the crew had killed their crewmate by means of assault and strangulation. The coroner's autopsy report laid out details consistent with a violent attack, including bruising, bleeding in the throat, three fractured vertebrae and bleeding in the eyes from burst capillaries, according to TV Midvest.\nThe closed-door hearing lasted all day, and in the evening, the court ordered all five men held in custody for four weeks, in line with a request from prosecutors. All of the accused have pleaded not guilty to charges of manslaughter, and they have appealed the court's detention ruling.\nLocal media have identified the victim as Alf Villum Jensen, 41. His widow, Louise Villum Jensen, told local media that Alf was nervous before this trip.\n\"He had never met that crew before, but he said they had told him that in the last year they had never had a new man last more than a fortnight. I tried to cheer him up, said that it would be fine, because he was good at that. But I could tell he knew it wasn't going to go well,\" she told Dagbladet Ringkobing Skjern.\nMORE TOP STORIES\nItalian Coast Guard Responds to Two Groundings in Two Days\nBulker Operator Claims Proof That Subsea Cable Damage Was Accidental\nSean Duffy Confirmed as U.S. Secretary of Transportation\nContainership Schedule Reliability Stabilized Absorbing Red Sea Diversions\nEDITORIALS TOP STORIES\nIs Russia Helping China Build a Hybrid-Nuclear Submarine?\nWhy Shared Governance Could Save Our Oceans\nBeijing Struggles to Control Provinces as They Expand Distant-Water Fleet\nOp-Ed: Tide is Turning on Maritime Corruption, But We Must Finish the Job\nAn IMO Commitment to Polar Fuels Could Cut Black Carbon Emissions\nSUBSCRIPTIONS\nSUBSCRIBE\nPrint\nDigital\nNewsletter\nRenew\nSubscribe Now\nRELATED STORIES\nShipping\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nJan 29, 2025 4:11 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpain’s Policía Nacional working in coordination with the Tax Authority reports it has conducted a series of arrests breaking up a gang smuggling cocaine hidden in industrial machinery from South America aboard ships arriving at Spanish ports.     "https://maritime-executive.com/article/longliner-sinks-off-falklands-leaving-crew-adrift-in-extreme-weather": "Longliner Sinks off Falklands, Leaving Crew Adrift in Extreme Weather\nGo\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nMedia Kit\nnews\nFeatures\nPodcasts\nMagazine\nNewsletter\nJobs\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nnews\nfeatures\nPodcasts\nmagazine\nnewsletter\nJobs\nadvertise\nsubscribe\nTOP STORIES\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSenate Committee Calls on FMC as it Explores Situation at the Panama Canal\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nProduct Tanker Towed to Marseille After Engine Room Fire\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nGlosten Joins Core Power's Nuclear Power Barge Project\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\n16382\nViews\nLongliner Sinks off Falklands, Leaving Crew Adrift in Extreme Weather\nFile image courtesy Argos Froyenes\nPublished\nJul 23, 2024 3:49 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\n[Updated] The crew of a modern freezer-longliner were forced to abandon ship off the coast of the Falkland Islands yesterday, and local accounts report that at least eight lost their lives in \"extremely challenging\" weather conditions before they could be rescued.\nOn Sunday, the 2018-built fishing vessel Argos Georgia got underway from Port Stanley and headed out to her fishing grounds with 27 crewmembers on board. On Monday afternoon, she reported a serious flooding incident at a position about 200 miles to the east of the port. As rescue assets mobilized to the scene, the situation on board deteriorated, and the crew was forced to abandon ship into their life rafts. The vessel sank after they departed.\nThe British Forces South Atlantic Islands (BFSAI) responded by launching a long-range search aircraft, which located the rafts and kept watch on their position. A fisheries patrol vessel and two Good Samaritan fishing vessels also diverted to assist. The BFSAI attempted to launch a helicopter rescue mission later that night, but the flight had to be canceled because of severe and worsening weather conditions. Argentine outlet InfoBae reports that significant wave heights were as high as 25 feet.\nAccording to Spanish media, multiple crewmembers died in the accident. A Falkland Islands patrol vessel rescued 13 crewmembers from one raft, and a Good Samaritan fishing vessel rescued one survivor and recovered one deceased crewmember from a second raft. Seven other bodies were recovered as of Tuesday night, making eight fatalities and 14 known survivors in total. Five crewmembers remain missing.\nThe Falkland Islands government has not confirmed the details of the rescue operation, but said in a statement Tuesday that \"a number\" of crewmembers had been rescued. The search for the missing is still under way.\nArgos Georgia was a 160-foot freezer longliner built in Turkey. She was involved in the Patagonian toothfish fishery off South Georgia, and ten of her crewmembers were Spanish nationals from the Galician fishing industry, according to EFE.\n\"In these difficult times, the Committee on Fisheries offers its solidarity with the Galician people, so closely linked to the fishing sector and from which several of the missing crew members of the ship Argos Georgia come,\" said EP Committee on Fisheries chair Carmen Crespo. \"This accident highlights the harshness of fishing activity and the sacrifice and risk that sea professionals experience.\"\nMORE TOP STORIES\nItalian Coast Guard Responds to Two Groundings in Two Days\nBulker Operator Claims Proof That Subsea Cable Damage Was Accidental\nSean Duffy Confirmed as U.S. Secretary of Transportation\nContainership Schedule Reliability Stabilized Absorbing Red Sea Diversions\nEDITORIALS TOP STORIES\nIs Russia Helping China Build a Hybrid-Nuclear Submarine?\nWhy Shared Governance Could Save Our Oceans\nBeijing Struggles to Control Provinces as They Expand Distant-Water Fleet\nOp-Ed: Tide is Turning on Maritime Corruption, But We Must Finish the Job\nAn IMO Commitment to Polar Fuels Could Cut Black Carbon Emissions\nSUBSCRIPTIONS\nSUBSCRIBE\nPrint\nDigital\nNewsletter\nRenew\nSubscribe Now\nRELATED STORIES\nShipping\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nJan 29, 2025 4:11 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpain’s Policía Nacional working in coordination with the Tax Authority reports it has conducted a series of arrests breaking up a gang smuggling cocaine hidden in industrial machinery from South America aboard ships arriving at Spanish ports.     "https://maritime-executive.com/article/spanish-responders-refloat-fishing-vessel-after-fatal-capsizing?fbclid=IwAR2KF1GipOFYc0EYTz588Zt0m2o8metROFzpIRMPHDCdphG0RGkCnzFwTfs": "Video: Spanish Responders Refloat Fishing Vessel After Fatal Capsizing\nGo\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nMedia Kit\nnews\nFeatures\nPodcasts\nMagazine\nNewsletter\nJobs\nAdvertise\nSubscribe\nnews\nfeatures\nPodcasts\nmagazine\nnewsletter\nJobs\nadvertise\nsubscribe\nTOP STORIES\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSenate Committee Calls on FMC as it Explores Situation at the Panama Canal\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nProduct Tanker Towed to Marseille After Engine Room Fire\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\nGlosten Joins Core Power's Nuclear Power Barge Project\nPublished\nby\nThe Maritime Executive\n4212\nViews\nVideo: Spanish Responders Refloat Fishing Vessel After Fatal Capsizing\nImage courtesy Salvamento Maritimo\nPublished\nNov 14, 2022 4:31 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpanish rescue agency Salvamento Maritimo has refloated the wreck of a fishing vessel that capsized just off the coast of Almeria, completing the response to the casualty. The vessel's sinking claimed the life of the skipper.\nOn Thursday afternoon, the fishing vessel Bahía la Isleta was struck by a wave and capsized at a position about one mile offshore. The local office of the Guardia Civil received a call about the casualty at 1400 and notified the agency's maritime service. A rescue helicopter with a two-man dive team was dispatched quickly to the scene.\nImage courtesy Salvamento Maritimo\nTwo of the crewmembers from Bahía la Isleta survived the capsizing and self-rescued by swimming to safety on shore. However, the captain was trapped inside and went down with the ship.\nThe Guardia Civil's responders proceeded on the assumption that he could still be alive in an air pocket inside, and the dive team went down to inspect the wreck. The skipper had not survived; they recovered his body from within the boat and returned to the surface.\nAfter the search and recovery mission, the work turned to salvage. The boat was largely submerged in about 100 feet of water and posed a risk of pollution. The maritime captaincy of Almeria ordered it refloated and removed, and a salvage vessel belonging to Salvamento Maritimo took on the task.\nOn Saturday, Salvamento Maritimo's special operations group and the pollution-response vessel Clara Campoamor carried out the wreck removal using inflatable float bags. The recovery of the sunken vessel eliminates the possibility of further pollution and brings the salvage operation to a close.\nNuestro centro en #Almería coordinó ayer la operación de reflotamiento/izada/traslado de los restos del pesquero Bahía de lsleta.\nEn la complicada operación que acabó por la noche intervinieron el Grupo de Operaciones Especiales, el buque Clara Campoamor y la salvamar Algenib. pic.twitter.com/Obph6PITiA\n— SALVAMENTO MARÍTIMO (@salvamentogob) November 13, 2022\nSalvamar Algenib, con personal de operaciones especiales, realizando operaciones para mantener la flotabilidad del pesquero #BahialaIsleta, que volcó por un golpe de mar cuando faenaba a una milla de la costa de #LasNegras. pic.twitter.com/oyUhxdLcVh\n— SALVAMENTO MARÍTIMO (@salvamentogob) November 11, 2022\nMORE TOP STORIES\nItalian Coast Guard Responds to Two Groundings in Two Days\nBulker Operator Claims Proof That Subsea Cable Damage Was Accidental\nSean Duffy Confirmed as U.S. Secretary of Transportation\nContainership Schedule Reliability Stabilized Absorbing Red Sea Diversions\nEDITORIALS TOP STORIES\nIs Russia Helping China Build a Hybrid-Nuclear Submarine?\nWhy Shared Governance Could Save Our Oceans\nBeijing Struggles to Control Provinces as They Expand Distant-Water Fleet\nOp-Ed: Tide is Turning on Maritime Corruption, But We Must Finish the Job\nAn IMO Commitment to Polar Fuels Could Cut Black Carbon Emissions\nSUBSCRIPTIONS\nSUBSCRIBE\nPrint\nDigital\nNewsletter\nRenew\nSubscribe Now\nRELATED STORIES\nShipping\nSpanish Police Bust Smugglers Shipping Cocaine in Industrial Machines\nPublished\nJan 29, 2025 4:11 PM        \t\tby\nThe Maritime Executive\nSpain’s Policía Nacional working in coordination with the Tax Authority reports it has conducted a series of arrests breaking up a gang smuggling cocaine hidden in industrial machinery from South America aboard ships arriving at Spanish ports.     "https://mb.com.ph/2022/06/27/4-fishermen-dead-1-missing-as-boat-overturns-in-bataan/": "4 fishermen dead, 1 missing as boat capsizes in Bataan\nJanuary 29, 2025 9:47 pm         NewsBusinessEconomicsOpinionEntertainmentSportsTechnologyLifestyleSpecials    NewsBusinessEconomicsOpinionEntertainmentSportsTechnologyLifestyleSpecials        NationalNews  4 fishermen dead, 1 missing as boat capsizes in Bataan   BY  Martin Sadongdong Jun 27, 2022 02:23 PM\nFour fishermen died, one went missing, and 45 others were rescued when the fishing boat they were riding on suddenly turned turtle in Bagac, Bataan last week, the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) confirmed Monday, June 27.\nFishing boat Gra Twin Sister overturns in Bagac, Bataan on June 23, 2022 after being hit by strong waves. The boat was carrying 50 fishermen, of which, 45 were rescued, four died, and one went missing. (Photo courtesy of Philippine Coast Guard)\nAn incident report reaching the PCG headquarters said fishing boat “Gra Twin Sister” with 50 fishermen onboard encountered big waves which caused it to capsize at approximately 18 nautical miles from the shoreline of Barangay Saysain last June 23.\nThe fishermen came from Nasugbu, Batangas and sailed on June 22.\n\"Based on the testimonies of the survivors, their boat was hit by the waves. That was the reason why it capsized,\" PCG spokesperson Commodore Armand Balilo told reporters.\n\"Sometimes you really cannot predict the weather. According to them, the weather started out fine when they left but then the big waves came afterwards,\" he added.\nThe PCG said search and rescue (SAR) operations were ongoing to find the remaining missing fisherman whose identity was not disclosed.\nThe PCG deployed BRP Malabrigo (MRRV-4402) and Coast Guard helicopter CGH-154 for maritime and aerial search.\n“The SAR team advised all fisherfolks to immediately report to the nearest PCG unit if they saw the missing crew member,” the PCG said.\nrelated stories   related tags #PCG#Maritime accident#6272022#Gra Twin Sister#Philippine Coast Guard    our company disclosures terms & conditions privacy policy sitemap contact us rss feeds e-paper newsletter responsible disclosure policy  back to top\n© 2025 Manila Bulletin The Nation's Leading Newspaper.     "https://mb.com.ph/2022/09/05/body-of-missing-fisherman-found-in-antique/": "Body of missing fisherman found in Antique\nJanuary 29, 2025 9:47 pm         NewsBusinessEconomicsOpinionEntertainmentSportsTechnologyLifestyleSpecials    NewsBusinessEconomicsOpinionEntertainmentSportsTechnologyLifestyleSpecials        NewsVisayas  Body of missing fisherman found in Antique   BY  Philippine News Agency Sep 5, 2022 05:24 PM\nSAN JOSE DE BUENAVISTA, Antique (PNA) – The body of a missing fisherman was found in an advanced stage of decomposition in Libertad, Antique.\nMAP of Antique with the municipality of Libertad highlighted.\nBroderick Train, Provincial Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Officer (PDRRMO), said the fatality found lying on the shorelines of Barangay Banawon on Sunday morning, Sept. 4, was identified by relatives as Dionisio Bacaoco, 59, of Barangay Mapatag in Hamtic, this province.\n“Bacaoco was reported missing by his family on Aug. 23 and immediately, a search and rescue operation was conducted,” Train said in an interview on Monday, Sept. 5.\nThe incident was disseminated by the Hamtic Municipal DRRMO, Philippine Coast Guard, and local police.\nTrain said that a fisherman, also a resident of Barangay Mapatag, found Bacaoco’s boat within the vicinity of the seawaters in their barangay.\nHe added that rough sea conditions due to the southwest monsoon or “habagat” enhanced by severe tropical storm “Florita” could have caused the fishing boat to capsize.\n“The Coast Guard Station Antique issued a sea travel advisory canceling trips in Caluya, Libertad, and Culasi (towns) on Aug. 23,” he said.\nTrain reminded local fishermen to always adhere to Coast Guard station advisories to avoid untoward incidents.\nrelated stories       our company disclosures terms & conditions privacy policy sitemap contact us rss feeds e-paper newsletter responsible disclosure policy  back to top\n© 2025 Manila Bulletin The Nation's Leading Newspaper. His two companions returned safely.Police said the Coast Guard, maritime police, and the local Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office are conducting search and rescue operations for Rafol.        related stories   related tags #Missing person#Fisherman#Badoc#Ilocos Norte    our company disclosures terms & conditions privacy policy sitemap contact us rss feeds e-paper newsletter responsible disclosure policy  back to top\n© 2025 Manila Bulletin The Nation's Leading Newspaper.     "https://meaww.com/toshihiro-nishikawa-fisherman-feared-dead-after-brown-bear-spotted-with-boots-in-its-mouth": "Toshihiro Nishikawa: Missing fisherman feared dead after brown bear 'spotted with boots in its mouth’ - MEAWW\nREALITY TV\nTV\nMOVIES\nMUSIC\nCELEBRITY\nAbout Us\nContact Us\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms of Use\nAccuracy & Fairness\nCorrections & Clarifications\nEthics Code\nYour Ad Choices\n© MEAWW All rights reserved\nMEAWW.COM\n/\nNEWS\n/\nHUMAN INTEREST\nToshihiro Nishikawa: Missing fisherman feared dead after brown bear 'spotted with boots in its mouth’\nThe Hokkaido island is home to over 6,500 Ussuri brown bears and, in 2021, 14 people were killed or injured by bears in the area\nBY\nSRINIJA GRANDHI\nPUBLISHED\nMAY 18, 2023\nRepresentational photo (Getty Images)\nHOKKAIDO, JAPAN: Fears that a fisherman was eaten alive by a brown bear with \"boots hanging from its mouth\" has increased after a human head was also found in Lake Shumarinai in Japan. Toshihiro Nishikawa, 54, was dropped off at the isolated fishing area, but he never came back, leading to the incident being reported on Monday, May 15.\nLake Shumarinai is located on Hokkaido, Japan's northern island. According to recent sources, the island is home to over 6,500 Ussuri brown bears. In 2021, 14 people were killed or injured by bears in Hokkaido, according to official reports.\nREAD MORE\n'I saw his leg in bear’s mouth': Wheelchair-bound granddad saves boy, 10, from 250lb black bear attack\nTO KILL OR NOT TO KILL: Debate over killer bear rages on as victim's family against putting it down\nWhat happened to Toshihiro Nishikawa?\nAccording to authorities, Toshihiro Nishikawa, 54, went missing while fishing alone on Sunday, May 14, near Lake Shumarinai in the town of Horokanai. The boat operator who took the man to his destination reportedly saw a bear with fishing boots hanging from its jaws that day. The driver then made unsuccessful phone calls to Toshihiro, according to Kyodo News. Horokanai authorities subsequently initiated a bear hunt, which culminated in the shooting of an animal in the region later that evening. During the hunt, a human head was also uncovered near where the fisherman was last seen. Local authorities, however, have yet to establish whether the head belongs to Toshihiro, an Okoppe native. The lake, which lies in northern Hokkaido, attracts fishermen looking to capture trout, Japanese smelt, and the seldom encountered Sakhalin taimen.\nAre Ussuri brown bears dangerous?\nOne of the most vicious bear species on Earth is the Ussuri brown bear, sometimes called the Ezo brown bear, Russian grizzly bear, or black grizzly bear. They reside in the Ussuri area of the Amur Region, Sakhalin Island, Hokkaido, and Kunashir Islands, as well as in northwest China and on the Korean peninsula. According to a report by public broadcaster NHK, the number of bear sightings in Hokkaido this year has increased, with the police receiving 339 complaints as of May 11—40 more than they did during the same time frame last year when bears were observed a record 2,240 times.\nPOPULAR ON MEAWW\nMORE ON MEAWW",
    "https://menafn.com/1108145647/Indian-Fisherman-Dies-In-Karachi-Jail-After-Fall-Body-To-Be-Brought-To-India-April-29": "Indian Fisherman Dies In Karachi Jail 'After Fall', Body To Be Brought To India April 29\nعربي\nLog in\nRemember Me\nForgot  Username or Password\nNew Here?\nCreate an account\nHome\nNews\nNews by Industry\nNews by Region\nAmerican\nEurope\nArab World\nAsia\nAfrica\nRSS\nPress Distribution\nPress releases\nSubmit Your Articles/Press Releases/Reports\nPricing\nMarket Data\nEquities Market\nGlobal Indices\nMENA Indices\nQutoes & Charts\nEnd Of Day Stocks\nCurrencies\nCurrency Convertor\nCross Rates\nHistorical Currencies\nLibor\nMena Stocks\nCommodoties\nOil & Energy\nEconomic Calender\nResearch\nPremium Research\nFree Research\nCountries\nSaudi Arabia\nUAE\nBahrain\nQatar\nKuwait\nJordan\nOman\nEgypt\nLebanon\nIraq\nPalestine\nSyria\nTunisia\nAlgeria\nMorocco\nYemen\nSections\nEvents\nFinancial Glossary\nUS\nEurope\nArab\nAsia\nAfrica\n|           Politics\nEconomy\nOil&Energy\nEntertainment\nSport\nIndian Fisherman Dies In Karachi Jail 'After Fall', Body To Be Brought To India April 29\nDate\n4/27/2024 4:00:34 AM\nShare on Facebook\nTweet on Twitter\n(MENAFN- AsiaNet News) Vinod Laxman Koal, a 45-year-old fisherman from Dahanu, who was jailed in Karachi for violating international maritime boundaries, passed away last month after a fall, reports said. His unfortunate demise marks the first such incident for an Indian fisherman in a Pakistani jail this year. His mortal remains are set to be repatriated to India on April 29, while 35 Indian fishermen are expected to be released from Pakistani custody on April 30.   3 foreign-made revolvers, 120 9mm bullets & more: What CBI recovered in Bengal's Sandeshkhali raid   Koal, hailing from Goratpada hamlet in Dahanu taluka of Palghar district, worked on a fishing boat registered in Gujarat. He was arrested by the Pakistani Coast Guard in October 2022 for allegedly trespassing into Pakistani territorial waters. Tragically, Koal suffered a paralytic attack and collapsed while bathing on March 8. He was receiving medical treatment in a hospital within the Pakistani prison premises when he succumbed to his condition. The news of Koal's demise was informed to other Indian prisoners on March 17, who, with the help of unofficial channels, conveyed the message to Koal's family members in Goratpada. Concerned about the fate of Koal's remains, his family sought assistance from local MLA, who took up the matter with the central government. Subsequently, Indian authorities liaised with their Pakistani counterparts, resulting in an agreement to repatriate Koal's body to India. Jatin Desai, a representative of a social organization aiding prisoners in Pakistan, confirmed that Koal's body is scheduled to be handed over to Indian officials on April 29, likely in Amritsar, before being transported to Dahanu.   Chaos in Karnataka's Chamarajanagar: Villagers boycott Lok Sabha polls; Stone pelting, EVM damage reported   While Indian government officials initially encountered difficulties in identifying Koal's family, assuming he was a resident of Gujarat, they eventually located his relatives in Maharashtra. Koal is survived by his wife, three daughters, and two sons. Desai highlighted that despite discrepancies in his Aadhaar card, which stated Koal's age as 57, his family asserts that he was 45 years old at the time of his demise. Moreover, out of about 300 fishermen jailed in Pakistan, 35 individuals, including five from Dahanu in Palghar district, are slated for release and handover to Indian officials on April 30. These fishermen are expected to reunite with their families in the first week of May.MENAFN27042024007385015968ID1108145647\nLegal Disclaimer: MENAFN provides the information “as is” without warranty of any kind. But before officials could recover the cadaver, it was devoured by sharks.\nThe body, which was in a state of decomposition and missing its legs, was first spotted by fishermen, who reported the finding to the Yucalpetén naval base. The navy informed the state Ministry of Public Security, which dispatched a team to recover the body.\nHowever, before the team could do so, sharks attacked it and pulled it under the water, which SSP officials recorded on video. They were able to recover some body parts, giving them hints to the man’s identity.\nFrom what officials could see, the body was that of a bearded man with tattoos. Though no fishermen have been reported missing in the area, the body was presumed to belong to a fisherman who fell overboard three days ago, according to rumor.\nWith reports from La Verdad Noticias, El Universal\nMexico finds alleged cartel encampment on island by Texas border\nMND Staff -  January 29, 2025 0\nThe encampment appears to be the site from where alleged Mexican cartel members shot at Texas CPB agents on patrol Tuesday.\nWhite House: Trump ‘committed’ to leveraging 25% tariffs on Mexico, Canada\nMND Staff -  January 28, 2025 3\nPresident Sheinbaum said Monday that Mexico will seek dialogue with the Trump administration on the threatened tariff.\nTucson Samaritans: The volunteer group helping vulnerable migrants at the US-Mexico border\nMND Staff -  January 28, 2025 0\nThe group, founded in 2002, takes up to 14 trips into the Sonoran Desert each week to bring water, food, first aid and other essential items to migrants in need.\nFacebookTwitterLinkedinInstagram\nMexico's English-language newspaper\nAbout Us\nADVERTISE WITH MND\nSUBMISSIONS\nCOMMUNITY GUIDELINES\nSubscription FAQ's\nJobs\nContact\nPrivacy Policy\nFacebookTwitterLinkedinInstagram\nMexico News Daily - Property of Tavana LLC",

Click here to take our quiz and show off your knowledge!\nKhwairakpam Thoi (54) from Ithing Awang Leikai, tragically drowned in Loktak Lake, Bishnupur district during the massive storm.\nThe incident occurred during a storm that swept across the area early in the morning.\nAlso Read: Assam: Cop on election duty found dead in GolaghatReady for a challenge? Click here to take our quiz and show off your knowledge!\nAccording to Thoi’s family, he ventured out on the lake around 5 am to retrieve his fishing nets.\nWhile other fishermen sought refuge in their Phumsangs (floating huts) as the storm intensified, Thoi reportedly attempted to reach his nets when the weather seemed to calm slightly.\nDespite warnings from other fishermen to wait for the storm to subside completely, Thoi proceeded on the water.\nAlso Read: Assam | Ajmal spreading communal hatred among minorities: Pradyut Bordoloi\nWhen the storm cleared and other fishermen ventured out again, Thoi’s boat was found empty.\nA search ensued, and Thoi’s body was discovered underwater.\nThe Keibul Lamjao Police Station has registered a case regarding the incident.\nRelated\nLatest\nAssam: French embassy delegation begins flood management study in DibrugarhJanuary 29, 2025 11: 24 pm\nAssam: 8 tractors, 1 dumper, 1 JCB seized for violating traffic rules in BajaliJanuary 29, 2025 11: 00 pm\nTripura: 16th Finance Commission arrives, visits Paschim MajlishpurJanuary 29, 2025 10: 28 pm\nAssam: 21st Livon Mega Miss North East grand finale set for January 31 in GuwahatiJanuary 29, 2025 10: 01 pm\nTripura’s tableau secures second place at ‘Republic Day Parade 2025’January 29, 2025 9: 29 pm\nFacebook\nX\nInstagram\nWhatsApp\nOur PropertiesNortheast Now Assamese\nNortheast Jobs\nNortheast Tenders\nInnfinity\nAbout Us\nCopyright Policy\nDisclaimer\nAuthors\nCareer\nGrievance Redressal\nContact Us\n© 2025 NORTHEAST NOW NEWS\nPowered by Newspack",
    "https://neweralive.na/posts/pressure-group-demands-fishermans-death-investigation": "Pressure group demands fisherman’s death investigation – New Era\nNews\nNational\nCourts & Crime\nOpinions\nAgriculture\nBusiness\nInternational\nLanguages\nEenguhudana\nKhoekhoegowab\nRukwangali\nOtjiherero\nSilozi\nOmaudhano\nEenghundana Domalihafifo\nLifestyle\nMotoring\nSports\nYouth\nFocus\nArticles\nDownloads\nFeatured\nPhoto of The Week\nGallery\nPodcasts\nePaper\nElections\nPressure group demands fisherman’s death investigationHome\nNational\nPressure group demands fisherman’s death investigation\nNational2024-04-162024-04-16By Albertina NakaleKATIMA MULILO – The Namibian Lives Matter Movement is demanding the arrest of those responsible or involved in the mysterious death of Lubinda Samupwa, which occurred around Nkasa Rupara while on a fishing expedition last week.\nThe movement’s national executive chairperson Sinvula Mudabeti said they received information on 9 April 2024 about an encounter between three Namibian males that went fishing in the park, and encountered members of the environment and tourism ministry’s anti-poaching unit on 7 April 2024.\nContacted for comment yesterday, Zambezi control warden in charge of wildlife protection services  Morgan Sai-Sai confirmed the matter is under investigation, and did not want to jeopardise the process.\n“I can only confirm that the incident occurred in a protected area of Nkasa Lupara National Park. I am not sure of the details yet,” Sai Sai said.\nMeanwhile, Zambezi police spokesperson Kisco Sitali confirmed the incident yesterday, saying the body was found floating in water at Nkasa park.\n“The body was found in a decomposing state. No other visible injuries.\nThe drowning took place on Sunday [7 April 2024] at around 12h00. It was retrieved on 9 April 2024,” him confirmed.\nAccording to Sitali, the crime scene was attended by relevant officers, and the body was transported to Katima Mulilo. The autopsy is pending in the matter.\nThe next of kin have been informed, and police investigations continue.\nIt is alleged that the fishermen were fishing in the park, and the anti-poaching unit members from Namibia parks and wildlife found them fishing. They then tried to flee from the scene, prompting officials to fire warning shots.\nAfter encountering the anti-poaching unit, two of them were facing the direction from which the anti-poaching unit came, while their friend was facing the opposite direction.\nMudabeti said the two who were facing the anti-poaching unit jumped into the water while their friend on the other side, who did not see the anti-poaching unit coming, did not jump into the water. He surrendered with his hands in the air when the anti-poaching unit members pointed firearms at him.\nThe one who surrendered was warned that if he ran, he would be shot. He was thus instructed to walk towards the anti-poaching unit, which he complied with.\nOf the two who jumped into the water, one came out with his hands on his head, assuming a position of surrender, while being called to come towards the anti-poaching unit and was warned that if he ran, he would be shot, and he fully complied.\n“The first to surrender, who did not jump into the water, said to the anti-poaching unit that his other friend had not come out of the water, was still in the water, and informed them to retrieve his body, which they refused. The water was shallow, and the two survivors suggested that they use their fishing net to get their missing friend, but the anti-poaching unit refused to listen to the two survivors,” the movement alleges.\nMudabeti said after the survivors walked some metres under arrest, one of them checked behind, and he saw an object that resembled protruding parts of a human head and back floating in the water.\nHe apparently asked the anti-poaching unit to get to the object that he suspected was his friend.\nOne of the anti-poaching unit members said he also saw something that looked like a body, but his fellow officer refused to entertain even when his colleague insisted that he saw a person in the water.\n“Another officer asked the one who discharged his firearm if he indeed shot in the air because he saw something like a person too. The officer who shot maintained that he indeed shot in the air, and thus there was no need to search for the body of the missing person. A disagreement ensued between the anti-poaching officers as to whether to go back to the scene and search for the missing, or proceed with the two survivors,” he maintained. When the officers arrived at the camp, they left one of the survivors with one game ranger, and took the one who said he saw his friend so that he goes to search for his friend in the water.\nUpon arriving at the scene, the officers allegedly instructed the survivor to go into the water and search for his friend.\n“The survivor was very scared. He thought that they would shoot him too, and thus went into the water and searched for his missing friend in another direction because he feared that if he found him, the officers might shoot him too and accuse him of having attempted to run. The anti-poaching unit members then went back to the camp where they left the other survivor, and took both suspects to the Sangwali police station, charged them for illegal fishing and sent them home,” Mudabeti alleged.\nThe Namibian Lives Matter Movement is of the view that the anti-poaching unit was concerned about fining N$3 000 each of the survivors to instead of worrying about searching for the missing person, which shows how heartless they are.\nThe suspects then went home, and informed their elders of what transpired.\nThe elders went to the Sangwali police station to request the police to accompany them to the scene and retrieve the body of their missing relative, but the police allegedly refused to go with them.\nThe next morning, the police went to the scene with members of the community, and found the body of Samupwa.\nThe body was found in shallow water, which Mudabeti said rules out the possibility of drowning.\nThe body was taken to the police station.\nThe family was allegedly denied access to view the body until they almost became violent, which is when the police allowed a few members of the family to just view the face of the deceased, and not the whole body.\nThe stance of the movement is thus informed by these witness accounts as narrated and recorded by their regional leadership based in the Zambezi region, who were dispatched to the scene on 12 April 2024.\nThey also said the conduct of the anti-poaching unit also shows that they are very unprofessional. The movement is demanding the suspension of the commander of the patrol team of the anti-poaching unit who allowed his officers to open fire at an innocent and unarmed Namibian.\n“We demand the suspension of the Zambezi regional control warden for covering up this matter without alerting the police on time, who are constitutionally mandated to investigate cases of any crime. We demand the suspension of the shift commander at Sangwali police station who did not take the necessary action to accompany the family to the scene and retrieve the body of Lubinda Samupwa,” the movement petitioned.\nThey also request the inspector general of the Namibian Police to constitute an independent team of forensic investigation experts from the serious crime unit to be dispatched to the Zambezi region to carry out an independent, fair and impartial investigation on the death of Samupwa.\nPrevious PostKauandenge launches Nudo presidential bidNext PostCo-Creation hub grows startups\nRecent Posts\nNamibia’s unemployment rate hits 36.9%\nOmufekelwa momunyeka wokawe ta kala mokakuma\nEepelesenda 91 domaumbo momikunda odi na eepomba\nIikako itatu yosikola omumvo tagu     "https://news.abplive.com/tamil-nadu/two-fishermen-go-missing-near-tiruchendur-rescue-operation-underway-1546015": "Two Fishermen Go Missing Near Tiruchendur, Rescue Mission On\nEnglishहिन्दीमराठीਪੰਜਾਬੀবাংলাગુજરાતીநாடுదేశం\nAdvertise with us\nHome\nNews\nIndiaWorldElections\nElections\nBusiness\nBudgetCryptocurrencyPersonal FinanceMutual Funds\nEntertainment\nCelebrities NewsMoviesTelevisionOTTSouth CinemaHollywoodKorean\nSports\nIPLCricketFootball\nLifestyle\nAstro\nTechnology\nMore\nNewsIndiaWorldSportsCricketIPLHockeyFootballOlympicsLotteryBusinessPersonal FinanceIPOCryptocurrencyMutual FundsBudgetEntertainmentMoviesWeb SeriesCelebrities NewsKoreanSouth CinemaHollywoodOTTMovie ReviewTelevisionEducationJobsResultsTechnologyGadgetsChatGPTElectionsLifestyleTravelAstroBrand WireOffbeatStatesUP UKDelhi NCRNortheastAndhra PradeshKeralaTamil NaduTelanganaKarnatakaAgricultureTrendingHealthFact CheckExplainersCrimeAutoScienceReligion and SpiritualityEducation\nExplorer\nLive NowPremiumVideoReelsWeb StoriesPhoto GalleryPodcastMovie ReviewOpinion\nUseful\nIFSC Code Finder\nPin Code Finder\nHome Loan EMI Calculator\nPersonal Loan EMI Calculator\nCar Loan EMI Calculator\nEducation Loan EMI Calculator\nAge calculator\nBMI Calculator\nPetrol Prices\nDiesel Prices\nGold Prices\nSilver Prices\nAQI\nHomeTamil NaduTwo Fishermen Go Missing Near Tiruchendur, Rescue Operation Underway\nTwo Fishermen Go Missing Near Tiruchendur, Rescue Operation Underway\nThe district Collector Senthil Raj said that they have made efforts to rescue the missing fishermen despite the tough weather conditions.\nBy : ABP News Bureau | Updated at : 03 Aug 2022 11:23 AM (IST)\nThe fishermen in a fishing boat (file photo)\nChennai: Two fishermen of Amali Nagar near Tiruchendur went missing after the fiberglass country boat in which they were fishing capsized mid-sea on Monday night. The boat with four members capsized due to the rough weather. Of the four members, two of the fishers safely reached the shore but the remaining two fishermen went missing.\nAccording to a report in The Hindu, every day the residents of Amali Nagar would venture into the sea at midnight and reach the shore in the evening. On Monday too, fishermen ventured into the sea. Four fishermen identified as Aswin, Prasanth, Paulraj and Nithyanantham went together in the same boat but their boat suddenly got in a gale and capsized about 22 nautical miles off the shore.\nNithyanantham and Paulraj were rescued by fishermen in other boats. However, Aswin and Prasanth went missing.\nAlso Read | IMD Issues Red Alert For Four Tamil Nadu Districts For Next Two Days. Check Details\nThe fishermen then sent six mechanised boats to look out for the fishers. Based on the information, the district Collector K Senthil Raj informed Indian Coast Guard to look out for the fishermen. The ICG has pressed ships Aviraj and Aadhaesh and an aircraft and helicopter from INS Parundu in Ramanathapuram district for the search.\nSenthil Raj said that they have made efforts to rescue the missing fishermen despite the tough weather conditions.\nAlso Read | Madras HC Asks Archeological Dept To Take Over Temple With Buddha Statue\nMeanwhile, TN Opposition leader Edappadi Palaniswami accused TN government of failing to alert the fishermen in advance and expressed his concern over the missing fishermen.\nPublished at : 03 Aug 2022 11:24 AM (IST)\nTags :  Tamil Nadu Fishermen Edappadi Palaniswami Tiruchendur Fishermen Missing\nFollow Tamil Nadu News   on ABP Live for more latest stories and trending topics. BAYORANA fisherman died after being hit by lightning in Sitio Roma, Brgy. Balaring, Silay City, Negros Occidental, while his two brothers and a nephew, survived, Saturday.Ron Sabadisto, 44, was reported to have died on the spot. The survivors were identified as Stephen and Rodney Sabadisto, and their nephew Charlon Aristo.Stephen said Ron was hit in the head, while Rodney and Charlon, who were in the water, were rendered unconscious by the lightning shockwave.Rodney and Charlon were brought to the Teresita Lopez Jalandoni Provincial Hospital in Silay City by members of the Silay City Rescue Team.Stephen said the incident took place while they were seeking shelter in a fish pen because of the bad weather.*       ARCHIVES  Read Article by dateJanuary Reporting mistakes helps us improve the experience.Generate Key TakeawaysA search is underway after a fisherman vanished in Maryland, leaving behind an unmanned boat with the engines still running, according to the U.S. Coast Guard.State officials contacted the Coast Guard after someone reported finding a 21-foot boat “with no one on board” in the area of Anchor Marina, the Coast Guard said in an April 21 news release.The engines were on and a phone and fishing gear were on board the boat, officials said.AdvertisementAdvertisementAdvertisementThe missing man is 27-year-old David Rambo, of Wilmington, Delaware, officials said. He was wearing jeans and a maroon shirt when he was last seen, at about 11 p.m., and “was reported to have been fishing in the area of the mouth of North East Creek.”The Coast Guard is searching by boat and helicopter.     "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/india/-missing-kerala-fisherman-dies-in-pakistan-jail-body-to-be-buried-in-amritsar-anr-rv3mub": "'Missing' Kerala fisherman dies in Pakistan jail; body to be buried in Amritsar- Asianet Newsable\nMalayalamEnglishKannadaTeluguTamilBanglaHindiMarathi      Sign in with FacebookSign Out IndiaDefenceEntertainmentAutoVideosFootballSportsPhotosWorldLifestyleTechnologyBusinessCareerMarketsSIP Calculator Languages MalayalamEnglishKannadaTeluguTamilBanglaHindiMarathi  English News  India News    'Missing' Kerala fisherman dies in Pakistan jail; body to be buried in AmritsarA Kerala fisherman who was in the custody of the Pakistan Navy on suspicion of trespassing into its territorial waters reportedly passed away in jail. The deceased Zulfiqar (48) from Kappur died in Karachi jail, according to police sources.\nAishwarya Nair | First Published May 23, 2023, 12:16 PM IST | Last Updated May 23, 2023, 12:16 PM IST   Follow Palakkad: A Kerala fisherman who was in the custody of the Pakistan Navy on suspicion of trespassing into its territorial waters reportedly passed away in jail.\nThe deceased Zulfiqar (48) from Kappur died in Karachi jail, according to police sources.\nThe body of Zulfiqar will be received by his family in Amritsar; it won't be sent to Kerala. One of his brothers from abroad has arrived in Amritsar, and his remains will only be buried there. The Amritsar Collector received the mortal remains which were brought to Attara on the Punjab border on Monday.\nAccording to Zulfiqar's relatives, they haven't heard from him in the past five years. The family initially declined to obtain the body as they thought he might have connections to ISIS. However, when the family was informed by the authorities that a fisherman had passed away in a Pakistani prison, they agreed to receive his remains.\nAbdul Hamid, Zulfiqar's father, claimed that his son last travelled to the country in 2017. There hasn't been any information about his location since then. Despite the fact that the Special Branch and Intelligence Bureau (IB) came to look into him, the National Investigation Agency (NIA) has not yet arrived, according to Hamid.\n\"The Pakistan Maritime Security personnel arrested him for allegedly fishing in its territorial waters,\" the sources said.\nEarlier, the Pakistan government released 199 Indian fishermen who were detained for reportedly fishing illegally in Pakistani waters on Friday (May 12). The Pakistan officials had also confirmed the death of an Indian fisherman Zulfiqar, who died in a hospital in Karachi due to an illness.\nAlso read: Study reveals women more likely than men to die after heart attack;     "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/world/pakistan-to-free-199-indian-fishermen-on-may-12-one-dies-in-karachi-anr-ruc3ut#": "Pakistan to free 199 Indian fishermen on May 12; One dies in Karachi- Asianet Newsable\nMalayalamEnglishKannadaTeluguTamilBanglaHindiMarathi      Sign in with FacebookSign Out IndiaDefenceEntertainmentAutoVideosFootballSportsPhotosWorldLifestyleTechnologyBusinessCareerMarketsSIP Calculator Languages MalayalamEnglishKannadaTeluguTamilBanglaHindiMarathi  English News  World News    Pakistan to free 199 Indian fishermen on May 12; One dies in KarachiThe Indian government will receive these fishermen at the Wagah border after they are transported to Lahore.\nAishwarya Nair | First Published May 8, 2023, 3:31 PM IST | Last Updated May 8, 2023, 3:32 PM IST   Follow Karachi: Despite the death of an Indian civilian who was scheduled to be returned with them, Pakistani officials are still expected to carry out their goodwill gesture and release the 199 Indian fishermen who were detained for reportedly fishing illegally in Pakistani waters on Friday (May 12).\nAlso read: 'Boat tragedy is a man-made disaster': Opposition leader V D Satheesan\nThe appropriate government departments had instructed them to get ready for the release and repatriation of 199 fishermen on Friday, according to Kazi Nazir, a top police official in Sindh's jail and correctional department. The Indian government will receive these fishermen at the Wagah border after they are transported to Lahore. Currently, these fishermen are lodged at the Landhi jail here.\nHe said the goodwill gesture process appeared on the course although an Indian civilian prisoner, Zulfiqar, who was to be repatriated with the fishermen died in a hospital in Karachi on Saturday due to an illness.\n“According to officials at Landhi jail the Indian prisoner had complained about high fever and chest problems and his condition deteriorated last week so he was sent to the hospital where he passed away due to apparent lung infection,” he said.\nAccording to the Pakistan India People’s Forum for Peace and Democracy, at present 631 Indian fishermen and one civilian prisoner are still in the Landhi and Malir jails in Karachi despite completing their prison sentences.\nAdil Sheikh, who works with the forum in Karachi, said that these Indian fishermen all ended up in Pakistani jails after being arrested for allegedly violating the marine territorial demarcation treaty between Pakistan and India.\nWhile an estimated 83 Pakistani fishermen are in Indian jails, a total of 654 Indian fishermen are incarcerated in Karachi. 631 of the Indian fishermen's 654 sentences have been completed, and they are awaiting repatriation.\nAlso read: Ftune's Face Whitening Cream has been changing the skincare game for over 10,00,000 customers\nFor more reliable and latest news subscribe to Asianet Newsable WhatsApp channel by clicking here.fishermen in pakistanPak-India    Latest VideosFollow Us: Download App:          RELATED STORIES'Beyond my current scope': DeepSeek AI dodges questions on India-China border row, Kiren Rijiju & more (WATCH)Karachi violence: 42 killed, 233 injured in firing incidents since January 1Karachi gas crisis: Residents struggle with shortages amid rising costs, unsafe alternatives9 Indian nationals killed, several injured in road accident in Saudi Arabia's JizanWas Justin Trudeau lying? She said she last saw him on October 29, when she visited him at his home. He lives alone, and she in another community.\nJarvis does not have a cell phone. Venezuelan authorities are searching for a 60-year-old Maraval man and his Venezuelan friend who were kidnapped by pirates in March.\nPolice said Ranja Ali and an unknown Venezuelan man left the the Crews Inn fishing depot in boat named Chantel to fish on March 29.\nPolice were told Ali and his friend were asked by a Venezuelan woman living in Laventille to collect something from a relative who would be fishing nearby in Venezuelan waters.\nInvestigators said Ali's boat experienced mechanical problems and had to be towed to Venezuela by an unknown Venezuelan boater.\nWhen he did not return to Trinidad and a friend tried to contact Ali, it was reported that a man with a Spanish accent answered and told the caller that Ali and his Venezuelan friend were kidnapped, and demanded a ransom.\n>\nThe ransom was paid to the Venezuelan woman living in Laventille but he has not been released up to Tuesday morning.\nLocal authorities are working with Venezuelan law enforcement to find
