    "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/6/6/at-least-six-killed-as-fishing-boat-explodes-off-philippine-province-cebu": "At least six killed as fishing boat explodes off Philippine province Cebu | News | Al Jazeera\nSkip linksSkip to Contentplay Live Show navigation menuNavigation menuNewsShow more news sectionsAfricaAsiaUS & CanadaLatin AmericaEuropeAsia PacificMiddle EastExplainedOpinionSportVideoMoreShow more sectionsFeaturesEconomyHuman RightsClimate CrisisInvestigationsInteractivesIn PicturesScience & TechnologyPodcastsplay Live Click here to searchsearchNavigation menucaret-leftTrendingDRCDonald TrumpNorth GazaDeepSeekPhotoscaret-rightNewsAt least six killed as fishing boat explodes off Philippine province CebuCoastguard reports six rescued after blast and blaze on boat, which had apparently developed engine trouble.Rescuers from the Philippine coastguard carry a survivor of a vessel that caught fire in the waters off Naga city, Cebu [Philippine Coast Guard/Handout via AP]Published On 6 Jun 20246 Jun 2024At least six crew members of a fishing boat have been killed after an explosion and a fire on the vessel at sea off a central Philippine province.\nCoastguard officials reported the deaths on Thursday, adding that six crew had been rescued from the F/B King Bryan after the blast and resulting blaze the previous day about 8km (5 miles) off Naga city in Cebu province.Recommended Stories list of 3 itemslist 1 of 3Philippines plans vaccination drive as whooping cough outbreak claims liveslist 2 of 3Fleet of Philippine activists challenge Chinese Coast Guard in South Chinalist 3 of 3Philippines, US simulate mock invasions in largest ever war gamesend of list\nVideo and pictures issued by the coastguard show flames and smoke billowing from the fishing boat as rescuers scanned the waters in the darkness. Crew members with burn injuries were carried to safety by coastguard personnel.\nThe wooden-hulled boat, which had bamboo outriggers, apparently developed engine trouble, the ensuing disaster leaving some crew members injured, forcing others to jump into the sea in panic.\nAccording to coastguard officials, a passing tugboat helped put out the blaze and a search and rescue operation was launched.\nSurvivors\nSurviving crew members, including the skipper, were still being treated at a hospital or were too traumatised to tell investigators what set off the explosion and resulting fire. Advertisement\nOne of the injured crewmen was in critical condition at a hospital in Cebu.\nSea accidents are common in the Philippines because of frequent storms, poorly maintained boats, overcrowding and spotty enforcement of safety regulations.\nLast year, the M/V Esperanza Star ferry caught fire with 120 people on board while travelling from Siquijor province to Bohol province in the central Philippines – all were rescued.\nSource: Al Jazeera and news agenciesaj-logoaj-logoaj-logo Sponsored Content  Advertisement AboutShow moreAbout UsCode of EthicsTerms and ConditionsEU/EEA Regulatory NoticePrivacy PolicyCookie PolicyCookie PreferencesSitemapWork for usConnectShow moreContact UsUser Accounts HelpAdvertise with usStay ConnectedNewslettersChannel FinderTV SchedulePodcastsSubmit a TipOur ChannelsShow moreAl Jazeera ArabicAl Jazeera EnglishAl Jazeera Investigative UnitAl Jazeera MubasherAl Jazeera DocumentaryAl Jazeera BalkansAJ+Our NetworkShow moreAl Jazeera Centre for StudiesAl Jazeera Media InstituteLearn ArabicAl Jazeera Centre for Public Liberties & Human RightsAl Jazeera ForumAl Jazeera Hotel PartnersFollow Al Jazeera English:facebooktwitteryoutubeinstagram-colored-outlinerss© 2025 Al Jazeera Media Network",

    "https://www.azernews.az/nation/217328.html": "Two fishermen go missing in Caspian Sea\nAzernews.Az\nThursday January 30 2025\nLogin\nLatest\nNATION\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nOIL & GAS\nARMENIAN AGGRESSION\nARMENIAN-AZERBAIJANI CONFLICT\nEDITORIAL\nANALYSIS\nLIFESTYLE\nEVENTS\nHEALTHCARE\nCULTURE\nTRAVEL\nSPORTS\nOUR WRITERS\nTwo fishermen go missing in Caspian Sea\n12 November 2023 16:20 (UTC+04:00)\nTwo fishermen went missing in the Caspian Sea, the Azerbaijani\nMinistry of Emergency Situations told\nAzernews.\nThe \"112\" hotline of the Ministry of Emergency Situations\nreceived information about the disappearance of 2 fishermen in the\ndirection of Sabail region, Bibiheybat settlement in the Caspian\nSea.\nRegarding the information, the helicopter of the Aviation\nDepartment of the Ministry was involved in joint search\noperations.\nAt the moment, the search and rescue measures of citizens\nJafarov Vidadi Ali, born in 1954, and Hasanov Elvin Najafgulu, born\nin 1977, are being carried out.\n---\nFollow us on Twitter @AzerNewsAz\nTags:\nCaspian\nHere we are to serve you with news right now.     "https://www.azernews.az/region/223045.html": "Four dead, five missing in South Korea boat capsize\nAzernews.Az\nThursday January 30 2025\nLogin\nLatest\nNATION\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nOIL & GAS\nARMENIAN AGGRESSION\nARMENIAN-AZERBAIJANI CONFLICT\nEDITORIAL\nANALYSIS\nLIFESTYLE\nEVENTS\nHEALTHCARE\nCULTURE\nTRAVEL\nSPORTS\nOUR WRITERS\nFour dead, five missing in South Korea boat capsize\n11 March 2024 08:00 (UTC+04:00)\nSouth Korea's Coast Guard on Sunday confirmed the deaths of four\npeople in a fishing boat that had capsized off the southern coast\nof South Korea a day earlier, adding that rescue efforts for the\nfive missing crew are still ongoing, Azernews\nreports, citing Yeni Safak.\nRescue operations involving 20 ships and four planes were\nunderway in an underwater search for the missing crewmen,\nSeoul-based Yonhap News reported, citing Coast Guard officials.\nNine crew members, including seven Indonesians, were on board\nwhen the 29-ton vessel overturned in the morning in waters 68\nkilometers (42 miles) south of an island in Tongyeong, South\nGyeongsang Province.\nFour crew members, three of whom were unconscious, were found\ninside the vessel and transported to a hospital on Saturday.\nHowever, all four victims – the South Korean skipper and three\nIndonesians – were pronounced dead.\n---\nFollow us on Twitter @AzerNewsAz\nTags:\nSouth Korea\nHere we are to serve you with news right now.     "https://www.bairdmaritime.com/security/incidents/accidents/one-dead-after-fishing-vessel-capsizes-in-bay-of-biscay-off-france": "One dead after fishing vessel capsizes in Bay of Biscay off France\nSECURITYSHIPPINGOFFSHOREWORKBOATSPAXFISHINGTUGSDREDGE/CIVILSREGIONSREGIONSAUSMARINE (OCEANIA)USA/CANADAEUROPEASIAMIDDLE EAST/NORTH AFRICALATIN AMERICAAFRICAPOLARUNMANNEDYACHTSSHOP\nA French Navy H160 search and rescue helicopterFrench NavyAccidentsOne dead after fishing vessel capsizes in Bay of Biscay off FranceBaird MaritimePublished on: 21 Jan 2025, 9:22 amCopiedOne person is confirmed dead after a fishing vessel capsized in rough seas in the Bay of Biscay off France's western coast on Monday, January 20.French authorities first learned of the incident involving the gillnetter Rose des Vents at around 05:50 local time on Monday after an EPIRB alert was sent from the vessel and duly received by the Regional Operating Surveillance and Rescue Centre at Etel.A rescue boat and a French Navy helicopter were then sent to the area to render assistance to the crewmembers of the capsized vessel, which was then just off Oleron Island.Rose des Vents' captain, who was able to swim to shore following the incident, told local fire officials that their vessel was struck by a large wave, which then caused it to overturn. He and the only other crewmember, a 22-year-old deckhand, climbed onto the vessel's upturned hull shortly afterwards.The captain said another large wave later struck the vessel and swept both himself and the deckhand overboard. However, only the captain managed to climb back aboard the hull while the deckhand disappeared.A subsequent search operation by Good Samaritan vessels and helicopters concluded at around 12:30 when the missing deckhand was found unresponsive in the water. Tragically, he was pronounced deceased less than two hours later.EuropeFranceincidentsFrench NavyRose des Vents\nBaird Maritime\nBaird Maritime / Work Boat World\nwww.bairdmaritime.com\nINSTALL APP",
    "https://www.bairdmaritime.com/security/incidents/accidents/seven-dead-one-missing-after-fishing-boat-capsizes-off-gyeongju-south-korea": "Seven dead, one missing after fishing boat capsizes off Gyeongju, South Korea\nSECURITYSHIPPINGOFFSHOREWORKBOATSPAXFISHINGTUGSDREDGE/CIVILSREGIONSREGIONSAUSMARINE (OCEANIA)USA/CANADAEUROPEASIAMIDDLE EAST/NORTH AFRICALATIN AMERICAAFRICAPOLARUNMANNEDYACHTSSHOP\nThe overturned fishing vessel Geungwang following its collision with a sand barge off Gyeongju, South Korea, December 9, 2024. Seven of the vessel's eight-strong crew are confirmed dead.Korea Coast GuardAccidentsSeven dead, one missing after fishing boat capsizes off Gyeongju, South KoreaBaird MaritimePublished on: 10 Dec 2024, 4:14 amCopiedSouth Korea's Yonhap News Agency reports that seven people are confirmed to have died after a fishing vessel capsized in the waters off the southeastern city of Gyeongju on Monday, December 9.The incident occurred at around 05:43 local time on Monday when the 29-tonne fishing vessel Geungwang collided with a 456-tonne barge carrying a cargo of sand. The fishing vessel then overturned with its crew of eight still on board six kilometres off the coast.After learning of the incident, the Korea Coast Guard immediately deployed divers, 15 vessels, and six helicopters to the area as part of the search and rescue (SAR) effort.Coast guard SAR teams eventually located seven crewmembers inside the overturned fishing vessel. These seven individuals were found suffering from cardiac arrest and were then transported to hospital, where they were later pronounced deceased.Geungwang's crew at the time of the incident included three South Koreans and five foreign nationals. One crewmember, identified as an Indonesian national, remains unaccounted for, coast guard officials said.No injuries have meanwhile been reported among the 10 crewmembers on the barge.The incident is the fourth fatal fishing vessel capsizing to occur in South Korean waters since the beginning of the year. Monday's capsizing and the three separate incidents that occurred in March, September, and November have a combined death toll of at least 16.AsiaincidentsIndonesiaSouth KoreaKorea Coast GuardGeungwang\nBaird Maritime\nBaird Maritime / Work Boat World\nwww.bairdmaritime.com\nINSTALL APP",
    "https://www.bairdmaritime.com/security/incidents/accidents/two-dead-after-fishing-boat-capsizes-off-eastern-japan": "Two dead after fishing boat capsizes off eastern Japan\nSECURITYSHIPPINGOFFSHOREWORKBOATSPAXFISHINGTUGSDREDGE/CIVILSREGIONSREGIONSAUSMARINE (OCEANIA)USA/CANADAEUROPEASIAMIDDLE EAST/NORTH AFRICALATIN AMERICAAFRICAPOLARUNMANNEDYACHTSSHOP\nA Japan Coast Guard patrol vesselJapan Marine UnitedAccidentsTwo dead after fishing boat capsizes off eastern JapanBaird MaritimePublished on: 07 Jan 2025, 3:33 amCopiedThe Japan Times reports that two people are confirmed dead while three others have gone missing after a fishing vessel capsized off the coast of Ibaraki prefecture in eastern Japan on Monday, January 6.The incident occurred at around 02:08 local time on Monday when the 80-tonne purse seiner Ohama Maru No 8 overturned approximately 31 kilometres east of Kashima Port in the city of Kitaibaraki.The Japan Coast Guard led the subsequent search and rescue (SAR) effort, which also included some nearby Good Samaritan vessels. Ohama Maru No 8's 20-strong crew at the time of the incident included 15 Japanese and five Indonesian nationals. Of this number, 17 have been rescued while two are confirmed dead and three were reportedly thrown overboard and have not yet been found.The deceased and the missing crewmen have all been identified as Japanese nationals aged between 40 and 80.A survivor later told coast guard investigators that the vessel tilted heavily and overturned after one of its nets caught a large quantity of fish.The coast guard is continuing to conduct SAR operations off Kitaibaraki to attempt to locate the missing crewmen.The crews of other vessels that were also in the area when the capsizing occurred told local news outlet NHK that the conditions at the time were calm, making it unlikely that the weather was a contributing factor in the tragedy.AsiaJapanincidentsIndonesiaJapan Coast GuardOhama Maru No 8\nBaird Maritime\nBaird Maritime / Work Boat World\nwww.bairdmaritime.com\nINSTALL APP",
    "https://www.bairdmaritime.com/security/incidents/accidents/two-dead-one-hospitalised-after-crayfish-boat-capsizes-off-south-australia": "Two dead, one hospitalised after lobster boat capsizes off South Australia\nSECURITYSHIPPINGOFFSHOREWORKBOATSPAXFISHINGTUGSDREDGE/CIVILSREGIONSREGIONSAUSMARINE (OCEANIA)USA/CANADAEUROPEASIAMIDDLE EAST/NORTH AFRICALATIN AMERICAAFRICAPOLARUNMANNEDYACHTSSHOP\nBoats at an unidentified Australian port (representative photo only)Pixabay/moredelayAccidentsTwo dead, one hospitalised after lobster boat capsizes off South AustraliaBaird MaritimePublished on: 08 Jan 2025, 2:33 amCopiedTwo people are confirmed dead while a third has been hospitalised after a fishing vessel capsized off the tourist town of Beachport in South Australia on Monday, January 6.The South Australia Police said it learned about the incident at around 11:30 local time on Monday when it was called to a beach near Point Connor just south of Beachport after reports that a lobster fishing boat had capsized and three people were unresponsive on shore.A 59-year-old woman was taken to hospital in a stable condition. Sadly, however, two men, aged 82 and 69, respectively, were pronounced deceased at the scene.All three people are from Millicent, a town some 34 kilometres southeast of Beachport. The female survivor was also the wife of one of the deceased, 7News reports.Investigations into the circumstances surrounding the incident are ongoing with the assistance of the SA Police's Water Operations Unit. Police officials added that there are no suspicious circumstances in relation to the capsizing.AustraliaOceaniaSouth Australiaincidents\nBaird Maritime\nBaird Maritime / Work Boat World\nwww.bairdmaritime.com\nINSTALL APP",
    "https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-devon-65904041": "Friend says Devon fisherman who died saved him with maydaySkip to contentBritish Broadcasting CorporationWatch LiveHomeNewsSportBusinessInnovationCultureArtsTravelEarthVideoLiveHomeNewsIsrael-Gaza WarWar in UkraineUS & CanadaUKUK PoliticsEnglandN. Ireland PoliticsScotlandScotland PoliticsWalesWales PoliticsAfricaAsiaChinaIndiaAustraliaEuropeLatin AmericaMiddle EastIn PicturesBBC InDepthBBC VerifySportBusinessExecutive LoungeTechnology of BusinessFuture of BusinessInnovationTechnologyScience & HealthArtificial IntelligenceAI v the MindCultureFilm & TVMusicArt & DesignStyleBooksEntertainment NewsArtsArts in MotionTravelDestinationsAfricaAntarcticaAsiaAustralia and PacificCaribbean & BermudaCentral AmericaEuropeMiddle EastNorth AmericaSouth AmericaWorld’s TableCulture & ExperiencesAdventuresThe SpeciaListEarthNatural WondersWeather & ScienceClimate SolutionsSustainable BusinessGreen LivingVideoLiveLive NewsLive SportHomeNewsSportBusinessInnovationCultureArtsTravelEarthVideoLiveAudioWeatherNewslettersFriend says Devon fisherman who died saved him with mayday14 June 2023Irving of ExeterPeter Cloke was trapped in the cabin as the boat sank said his friendA man who died after his boat sank during a fishing trip has been thanked for saving a friend who was onboard.Seventy-four-year-old Peter Cloke's 20ft (6m) boat Petrel sank eight miles off Torquay on 19 May, but he put out a mayday call before it went down.His friend, who did not want to be named, told Mr Cloke's family the boat sank \"almost instantly\" and Mr Cloke had been trapped in the cabin.\"I owe him my life,\" the survivor told the family.\"I was only rescued because Peter managed to put out a mayday call just before the boat sank,\" he saidIrving of ExeterPeter Cloke's family said they could not understand why the Petrel sank so quicklyThe survivor said: \"Peter was unable to exit the cabin of the boat before it sank.\"He said: \"The ingress of water was slow at first but became catastrophic very quickly, upending and sinking the boat almost instantly.\"The body of Mr Cloke, from Ide near Exeter, Devon, was found 12 days later.His family - wife Sue, three grown-up children and four grandchildren - said he would be \"sorely missed\".They said: \"We are perplexed as to how Petrel, such a reliable and sold vessel, came to take on water and sink so quickly in calm conditions.\"The boat had been berthed in Exmouth Marina and had been recently serviced.Gareth Awbrey, chair of the Exmouth Deep Sea Fishing Club, said Mr Cloke \"loved his fishing\" and would be remembered \"for his willingness to help others, his smile and his impressive tally of fishing trophies over the years\".An inquest into the death has been opened and adjourned.Follow BBC News South West on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram.     "https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-south-scotland-64511914": "Berwickshire fisherman dragged to his death by creel ropesSkip to contentBritish Broadcasting CorporationWatch LiveHomeNewsSportBusinessInnovationCultureArtsTravelEarthVideoLiveHomeNewsIsrael-Gaza WarWar in UkraineUS & CanadaUKUK PoliticsEnglandN. IrelandN. Ireland PoliticsScotlandScotland PoliticsWalesWales PoliticsAfricaAsiaChinaIndiaAustraliaEuropeLatin AmericaMiddle EastIn PicturesBBC InDepthBBC VerifySportBusinessExecutive LoungeTechnology of BusinessFuture of BusinessInnovationTechnologyScience & HealthArtificial IntelligenceAI v the MindCultureFilm & TVMusicArt & DesignStyleBooksEntertainment NewsArtsArts in MotionTravelDestinationsAfricaAntarcticaAsiaAustralia and PacificCaribbean & BermudaCentral AmericaEuropeMiddle EastNorth AmericaSouth AmericaWorld’s TableCulture & ExperiencesAdventuresThe SpeciaListEarthNatural WondersWeather & ScienceClimate SolutionsSustainable BusinessGreen LivingVideoLiveLive NewsLive SportHomeNewsSportBusinessInnovationCultureArtsTravelEarthVideoLiveAudioWeatherNewslettersBerwickshire fisherman dragged to his death by creel ropes3 February 2023MaiBPeter Gray was dragged overboard when his ankle got caught in a rope on the Saint PeterA fisherman was dragged to his death after his ankle got caught in a rope shooting creels off his boat, a sheriff has concluded. Peter Gray, of Cove in Berwickshire, was trying to untangle creels on the Saint Peter when the accident occurred.It prompted a major rescue operation on 2 May 2021 near Torness Point when the boat was found unmanned.An inquiry concluded the use of \"deck dividers\" to keep workers clear of ropes might have avoided the accident.Sheriff Donald Corke also found that the 64-year-old's chances of survival were reduced by the absence of a boarding ladder, which might have allowed him to climb back on board, and the fact that he was not wearing a personal locator beacon.Mr Gray was found by a helicopter rescue crew several hours after going into the water and was flown to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh where he was pronounced dead. In his report into the accident, the sheriff said the shock of being immersed in cold water probably caused a fatal heart attack, possibly exacerbated by a history of heart disease. He recommended fishing boat owners should install deck dividers to improve safety and fit ladders or overside tyres so that anyone lost overboard could climb back onto a vessel. He also suggested people operating single-handed vessels in particular should carry personal locator beacons. Ireland PoliticsScotlandScotland PoliticsWalesWales PoliticsAfricaAsiaChinaIndiaAustraliaEuropeLatin AmericaMiddle EastIn PicturesBBC InDepthBBC VerifySportBusinessExecutive LoungeTechnology of BusinessFuture of BusinessInnovationTechnologyScience & HealthArtificial IntelligenceAI v the MindCultureFilm & TVMusicArt & DesignStyleBooksEntertainment NewsArtsArts in MotionTravelDestinationsAfricaAntarcticaAsiaAustralia and PacificCaribbean & BermudaCentral AmericaEuropeMiddle EastNorth AmericaSouth AmericaWorld’s TableCulture & ExperiencesAdventuresThe SpeciaListEarthNatural WondersWeather & ScienceClimate SolutionsSustainable BusinessGreen LivingVideoLiveLive NewsLive SportHomeNewsSportBusinessInnovationCultureArtsTravelEarthVideoLiveAudioWeatherNewslettersCyclone Ilsa: Stranded Indonesian fishermen rescued after six days without food18 April 2023Australian Maritime Safety AuthorityOne of the two fishing boats was washed ashore on Bedwell IslandEleven Indonesian fishermen have been rescued after surviving for six days without food or water on a tiny island off Australia's coast. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority said they were airlifted to safety on Monday from Bedwell Island, some 330km (205 miles) west of the town of Broome in Western Australia.But nine others are feared dead.The survivors said their two boats were hit by the powerful Tropical Cyclone Ilsa last week, sinking one boat.Nine of the 10 crew members on that vessel are still missing. The sole survivor is reported to have been in the ocean for hours, clinging onto a jerry can, before being picked up by the fishermen from the other boat, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) reported.That boat was pictured washed ashore on the small Bedwell Island. The surviving fishermen were eventually spotted by an Australian Border Force aircraft, and evacuated by a rescue helicopter to Broome, where they are being treated in hospital. They are \"all reported to be in good health despite their ordeal\", a Border Force spokesperson said, as quoted by the ABC, adding that the government was now working to \"repatriate the group as soon as practical\".Cyclone Ilsa, the strongest storm in the region in about 14 years, hit Western Australia last week - but it spared populated areas from major damage.Bedwell island lies near the Rowley Shoals - a series of coral reefs off Western Australia's coast.Powerful Cyclone Ilsa hits Western AustraliaWestern AustraliaIndonesiaRelatedThe newest victims of Australia's homelessness crisis30 Jul 2024AustraliaRare blind and hairy mole spotted in Australia9 Apr 2024AustraliaMissing family found alive in flooded outback14 Mar 2024AustraliaMore10 Jan 2025A purification ceremony to cleanse body and soulA purification ceremony in Bali is trending on TikTok.     "https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/local-news/tragedy-after-man-dies-fishing-8929827": "Tragedy after man dies on fishing boat off West Country coast - Bristol Live\nbristolpostLoad mobile navigationNewsLatest NewsBristol NewsBusinessCrimeEducationHealthPoliticsTraffic & TravelHistoryCelebs & TVPropertyMotoringJobsUK & World NewsNews By AreaExpandIn Your AreaWhat's OnWhat's On NewsFamily & KidsFilmFood & DrinkMusic & NightlifeShoppingStay InExpandCityRoversBearsPartner StoriesFootballFollow usBuy a PaperFuneral NoticesJobsBook an adBuy a photoAdvertise with usPropertyPublic NoticesDirectoryDatingNewsletter signupInYourAreamynewsassistantMarketplaceMirror BingoBeauty Box SubscriptionYimbly ShopBuy a photoMarketplaceContact UsAbout UsWork for usAdvertise with UsSubscriptionsCompetition RulesHow to ComplainCorrections and ClarificationsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy NoticeAI NoticeCookie NoticeRSS feedsNewsletters SignupSyndication & LicensingNotifications and Alerts help© 2025 Local World\nfrontpageNewsLocal NewsCoastguard\nNewsTragedy after man dies on fishing boat off West Country coastEmergency services rushed to the scene but sadly he died at the scenebristolpostBookmarkShareNewsByChloe Parkman09:00, 24 NOV 2023BookmarkCoastguard helicopter at the scene of a rescue (Image: Berry Head Coastguard)Get the latest Bristol Live breaking news on WhatsAppOur community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More infoJoin us on WhatsAppA man has died on a fishing boat following an emergency incident near Rame Head. The coastguard, RNLI and a naval vessel all rushed to the incident at around 2pm on November 21 after a mayday call was raised.  Police have confirmed that a man, aged in his 60s, died at the scene. His death is not being treated as suspicious and a file will be prepared for the coroner, report Cornwall Live. His heartbroken family have now been told the news by police, with specialist officers supporting them during this tragic time.  READ MORE:   West Country mum pulls teen out of school after disturbing social media video Bristol mum slams council after ceiling 'comes crashing down on daughter'  In a full statement, a spokesperson for Devon and Cornwall Police said: \"HM Coastguard contacted the police at around 4pm on Tuesday November 21 to request assistance following the death of a man onboard a vessel at sea, who was being brought to shore in Plymouth. \"A man in his 60s was confirmed deceased at the scene. His next of kin have been informed. The death is not being treated as suspicious and a file will be prepared for the coroner.\" A spokesperson for HM Coastguard said: “HM Coastguard is coordinating the response to a reported medical incident on board a fishing vessel south of Rame Head, near Plymouth. The alarm was raised with a mayday at about 1.55pm on 21 November. “The HM Coastguard search and rescue helicopter from Newquay has been sent, as well as the RNLI's all-weather lifeboat from Plymouth. A Danish naval vessel has also assisted.”Story SavedYou can find this story in  My Bookmarks.Or by navigating to the user icon in the top right.Follow BristolLiveFacebookX (Twitter)More OnAnglingCoastguard\nNewsallMost ReadMost RecentWeatherThe 11 counties in England set to wake up to snow tomorrowThe UK is facing a -6C weather bombDWP benefit increases in April 2025 - in Mexico in front of a fisherman, report says\nAlia Shoaib\n2023-01-28T10:29:01Z\nShare icon\nAn curved arrow pointing right.\nShare\nFacebook\nEmail\nX\nLinkedIn\nCopy Link\nlighning bolt icon\nAn icon in the shape of a lightning bolt.\nImpact Link\nSave Article Icon\nA bookmark\nSave\nRead in app\nA diver was decapitated by a 19-foot-long great white shark in Mexico in the first fatal shark attack of the year.\nBusiness Insider\nThis story is available exclusively to Business Insider\nsubscribers. Become an Insider\nand start reading now.\nHave an account? Log in.\nA great white shark decapitated a diver in Mexico in the first fatal attack of the year.\nWhen he was attacked, Manuel Lopez was diving to collect mollusks in Tobari Bay.\nDivers had been warned about sharks in the area, but Lopez continued as he needed to make a living.\nA 19-foot-long great white shark decapitated a diver in Mexico in the first fatal shark attack of the year.\nManuel Lopez was diving to collect mollusks in Tobari Bay when he was attacked and killed in front of a fisherman on January 5, according to Tracking Sharks.\"He was diving when the animal attacked him, impressively ripping off his head and biting both shoulders,\" Jose Bernal told the outlet, speaking for the fisherman.\nLocal divers had been warned about sharks in the area, Bernal said, which meant that most had not been in the water for days.However, Lopez decided to go ahead as he needed to make a living and sought to capitalize on increased demand amid a seafood shortage.He was collecting ax tripe, a scallop-like mollusk, which is collected at a depth of up to 59 feet in a process that can generate sounds and movement that can attract sharks, Tracking Sharks said.\nThe presence of sharks has meant thousands of fishermen have been staying onshore, and the government offers a stipend of 7,200 pesos ($384) per year to supplement their income. However, this amount is often not sufficient when there is no income from the sea, according to the outlet.Some local biologists have advised divers not to wear black wetsuits, as they might be mistaken for seals, and also recommend painting white stripes on the suits to look like a poisonous coral snake, per Tracking Sharks.Some fishing organizations have also called on the government to purchase devices that could deter sharks, such as shark shields or devices that emit electrical impulses that deter sharks.\nRead next\nMexico\nRecommended video\nThis story is available exclusively to Business Insider\nsubscribers. Kids\nCompetitions\nInsurance Quote\nJoburg ETC\n73-year-old fisherman dies at sea in the Western Cape\nPublished by Tauhira Ajam on October 17, 2023\nThe National Sea Rescue Institute (NSRI) responded to an alert that a 73-year-old fisherman from Mossel Bay was suffering a medical complaint off-shore between Agulhas and Hermanus in the early hours of Sunday morning.\nAlso read: Storm surges cause over 50 seals to be washed up on Cape Town beach\nThe NSRI EOC, Hermanus and Agulhas duty controllers coordinated with WC Government Health EMS metro control and an EMS duty doctor to assist the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre (MRCC) in executing the rescue operation just after 4am.\nIn cooperation with MRCC, the fishing vessel began making its way towards Hermanus, where a medical evacuation was being prepared.\nOn the way, however, crew members aboard the fishing vessel reported that the 73-year-old fisherman had sadly passed away.\nAn NSRI Hermanus rescue craft transported EMS rescue paramedics to the fishing vessel, where the man was declared deceased as a result of a medical condition.\nThe body was recovered and brought back to Hermanus by two police detectives who were ferried by NSRI and taken into the care of government health forensic pathology services.\nOur sincerest condolences to the loved ones of the deceased fisherman.\nAlso read:\nOne Le Roux stated that families of persons believed to be missing at sea in the vicinity have been notified to assist police and government Health Forensic Pathology Services with identification of the deceased. “Our thoughts are with those families in this difficult time.”\nMissing fisherman south of Cape Point\nMeanwhile, a search has ensued following reports of a man overboard and missing from a fishing vessel 11 nautical miles south of Cape Point.\nStation commander of the NSRI Simonstown, Darren Zimmerman, said the local fishing vessel that the fisherman had gone overboard from was engaged in a search and MRCC (Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre) had tasked another local fishing vessel to assist in the search. “The fisherman had reportedly fallen overboard while they were laying fishing gear. The alarm was immediately raised and the skipper had turned the vessel around and they had initiated a search,” said Zimmerman.\nHe added that upon arrival on the scene, they found that the casualty vessel had sustained fishing rope fouled around her propellors and although she was unable to actively continue to assist in the ongoing search, her crew were all on the lookout for their fellow ship mate. “The two NSRI sea rescue craft joined the second fishing vessel in an extensive search operation. The crews of at least seven fishing vessels that were in the vicinity at the time were keeping a lookout for the missing fisherman.”\n“Despite an extensive search there remains no sign of the missing fisherman,” he said.\nThe NSRI Simonstown and NSRI Hout Bay sea rescue craft returned to base in the early hours of the morning and local fishing vessels are continuing to keep a lookout for the missing fisherman.\nAlso read:\nBeached dolphin, fishermen, drowning couple – NSRI rescues in one day\nPicture: Cape {town} Etc gallery\nArticle written by Sinazo Mkoko\n← Previous Next →\nSubscribe Today\nNewsletter\nCapeTownETC\nAbout\nWebsite Privacy Policy\nCookies & Privacy Policy\nTs & Cs\nContact\nAdvertising\nSponsored\nGolf News\nCOVID-19 Corona Virus\nSouth African Resource Portal\nDaddy's Deals\nSubscribe to our Newsletter\ncheap cars for sale\ncheap cars for sale in western cape\ncheap cars for sale in cape town\nJoburg news\nNews in Johannesburg\nBikes for sale\nPowered By\nCAPE TOWN OFFICE:  36 Old Mill Road, Ndabeni, Maitland, 7405, Western Cape > Telephone: (021) 530 3300 > Fax: (021) 530 3333\n© Copyright 2023 CapeTown ETC\nPrimary Menu\nCulture\nCompetitions\nNews\nFood and Drink\nSecondary Menu\nHome\nNews\nWorld\nProperty\nTech\nSports\nWeather\nA slice of Gasant Abarder\nWhat’s On\nThings to do\nRestaurants\nShopping\nNightlife\nTravel\nWinelands\nOutdoor\nFamily & Kids\nCompetitions\nInsurance Quote\nJoburg ETC\nX\n﻿\nX\nSearch\n×\nShare your story!\nCLOSE\nX\n×\nWe only use cookies on this Site for particular features to work, the cookies do not collect and/or store any personal information about you.Ok",
    "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/lobster-fisherman-missing-acadian-peninsula-1.6834801": "2 lobster fishermen dead off Miscou Island on first day of season | CBC News\nContentSkip to Main ContentAccessibility HelphamburgerMenuWhen search suggestions are available use up and down arrows to review and enter to select.SearchSearchSign InQuick LinksNewsSportsRadioMusicListen LiveTVWatchnewsTop StoriesLocalClimateWorldCanadaPoliticsIndigenousBusinessThe NationalHealthEntertainmentScienceCBC News InvestigatesGo PublicAbout CBC NewsBeing Black in CanadaMore 2 lobster fishermen dead off Miscou Island on first day of season | CBC News LoadedNew Brunswick2 lobster fishermen dead off Miscou Island on first day of seasonTwo lobster fishermen who went overboard off Miscou Island, N.B., are dead, according to the RCMP. The two men went missing around 7:30 a.m. Saturday.Men went missing after going overboard around 7:30 a.m. SaturdayCBC News  · Posted: May 06, 2023 11:06 AM EDT | Last Updated: May 6, 2023The ages and names of the two men who died Saturday when their fishing boat capsized have not yet been released. (Gilles Landry/Radio-Canada )Social SharingTwo lobster fishermen from Lamèque, N.B., who went overboard off Miscou Island on New Brunswick's Acadian Peninsula are dead, according to the RCMP.The men, ages 33 and 58, disappeared around 7:30 a.m. Saturday.The 58-year-old man was found shortly after going overboard. The 33-year-old man was found after a short search, RCMP say.Both men were dead when they were located. The incident occurred approximately seven kilometres from shore.A third individual was also on board the boat but never went overboard.A helicopter, two airplanes, and three boats from the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre, along with several local fishing boats, assisted in the search.The Transport Safety Board of Canada and the provincial coroner have been called in to help investigate.Start of seasonSaturday marked the first day for lobster fishing in that area, which is Zone 23.Weather postponed the start of the season in the region for over a week.Local MP Serge Cormier issued a statement on his Facebook on Saturday afternoon.\"My thoughts and prayers are with the families, friends and the entire community of Miscou who are going through a difficult time due to an incident that occurred on a fishing boat this morning,\" he said.\"Fishing in our regions has been part of our culture for generations. Rest assured that all the communities of Acadie-Bathurst are at your side.\"ClarificationsAn earlier version of this story said the boat had capsized. What happened to the boat is under investigation.May 07, 2023 9:44 AM EDTWith files from Radio-CanadaCBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices|About CBC NewsCorrections and clarifications|Submit a news tip|Report errorFooter LinksMy AccountProfileCBC GemNewslettersAbout CBC AccountsConnect with CBCFacebookXYouTubeInstagramMobileRSSPodcastsContact CBCSubmit FeedbackHelp CentreAudience Relations, CBC P.O.     "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/ffaw-lark-harbour-1.7182323": "Uncle, nephew who died at sea in Lark Harbour tragedy remembered | CBC News\nContentSkip to Main ContentAccessibility HelphamburgerMenuWhen search suggestions are available use up and down arrows to review and enter to select.SearchSearchSign InQuick LinksNewsSportsRadioMusicListen LiveTVWatchnewsTop StoriesLocalClimateWorldCanadaPoliticsIndigenousBusinessThe NationalHealthEntertainmentScienceCBC News InvestigatesGo PublicAbout CBC NewsBeing Black in CanadaMore Uncle, nephew who died at sea in Lark Harbour tragedy remembered | CBC News LoadedNLUncle, nephew who died at sea in Lark Harbour tragedy rememberedTwo generations of a family were lost after a boat capsized on Newfoundland's west coast this weekend, leaving a community in mourning.FFAW says it'll be a difficult season for harvesters amid the deathsElizabeth Whitten   · CBC News  · Posted: Apr 23, 2024 3:16 PM EDT | Last Updated: April 23, 2024Social SharingTrevor Childs and his nephew Nicholas Skinner were the victims in this weekend's fatal boating incident on the west coast of Newfoundland. (Nautical Thrills/FaceBook)Two generations of a family were lost after a boat capsized on Newfoundland's west coast this weekend, leaving a community in mourning.On Sunday morning, after a vessel carrying six people capsized, the Canadian Coast Guard ship Cape Edensaw was dispatched from Lark Harbour to the west coast.The coast guard launched a fast rescue craft into the water, recovering two bodies.They were Trevor Childs and his nephew Nicholas Skinner, says Fish, Food & Allied Workers secretary-treasurer Jason Spingle.\"We had hoped that we wouldn't have to deal with this again. And we're here and we try to make the best of it. Again, in this case here too, two very young people, I think, makes it extra harder,\" Spingle told CBC News.In 2022, Childs spoke with CBC News while attending a fish harvester safety association symposium in St. John's.\"On the ocean the weather changes minute by minute. As for myself, I fish in an open boat so I'm always aware of the weather,\" Childs said at the time.Spingle said he knew Childs, describing him a \"beautiful person. Very mild mannered and soft spoken.\"A few years ago Spingle said he visited Childs's home and met his wife and children, and recalled he was happy with his life and loved fishing.\"We were talking about ... a good future for him and his family,\" said Spingle.He said a lot of people could relate to Childs, as a fish harvester from a rural town who was focused on his community, the outdoors and his family.\"It's just heartbreaking for them, right? Three small children,\" he said. \"It's just hard to take down, really hard to take down that they don't have him anymore.\"Spingle added that Childs's father is a recently retired harvester who was on the beach helping set the lobster traps and was there when the tragedy unfolded on Sunday.Difficult season aheadNews of the deaths travelled across Newfoundland and Labrador on Sunday and drew condolences from government officials and members of the fishing industry.Spingle says the tragedy impacts people beyond the fishery.\"This is going to be a difficult season for everyone in the Bay of Islands,\" he said.Residents of Lark Harbour have been rocked by the deaths of two fishermen after a vessel capsized on Sunday. (Colleen Connors/CBC)On Monday night, mourners held a private vigil to offer support to those grieving in Lark Harbour and York Harbour.\"'Reeling' is the only word to really use. Nobody expects to lose anyone, let alone on the first day of the season.… And the way it went down, from what I understand, is devastating,\" Lark Harbour Deputy Mayor Ria MacDonald told CBC News on Monday.\"'Devastating' is too light of a term. It feels like the rug has been pulled right out from underneath us.… To lose not one, but two from the same family, it's unreal. It doesn't feel real.\"Days after the deaths, details about the fatal incident are still unclear.Initially Capt. Trevor Ackland, spokesperson for the Joint Task Force Atlantic in support of the Joint Rescue and Coordination Centre in Halifax, told CBC News that four people had been airlifted from a beach on the west coast and brought to hospital after a vessel was found capsized.However, the DFO later amended this version of events and said the four were airlifted to shore where they were treated by paramedics.It is unclear if those four people had been on the boat with Childs and Skinner when it was capsized or if they ventured into the water to help the pair.The name of the vessel is also unknown, though officials initially reported it was called the Miss Jenny.'It doesn't feel real,' says Lark Harbour deputy mayor following death of 2 fishermen2 people dead after vessel capsizes on Newfoundland's west coastTransportation Safety Board spokesperson Hugo Fontaine said they were aware of the incident\"We are currently gathering information and assessing the occurrence. We haven't deployed investigators on site, and don't have much to share for now,\" he wrote in an email.Support for familiesSpingle said unfortunately, fatalities are a part of the industry, and the union has brought on measures to help their members through a life insurance policy as well as an accidental death and dismemberment policy.There is a financial amount set for a natural death as well as a death deemed accidental, which also covers funeral expenses, said Spingle. In this case, he views it as an accidental death case and that will give some support to the family in the short-term.In addition, he said this was a workplace fatality and there will be coverage under workers compensation through WorkplaceNL.\"So we'll make sure that people are helped out in any way they need to be,\" said Spingle.Spingle said he plans to attend the funeral to pay his respects on behalf of the union.Download our free CBC News app to sign up for push alerts for CBC Newfoundland and Labrador.     "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/fleur-de-lys-ship-sinking-1.6964855": "'Unbearable grief': 2 dead, 1 missing, 1 rescued after boat sinks off Fleur de Lys | CBC News\nContentSkip to Main ContentAccessibility HelphamburgerMenuWhen search suggestions are available use up and down arrows to review and enter to select.SearchSearchSign InQuick LinksNewsSportsRadioMusicListen LiveTVWatchnewsTop StoriesLocalClimateWorldCanadaPoliticsIndigenousBusinessThe NationalHealthEntertainmentScienceCBC News InvestigatesGo PublicAbout CBC NewsBeing Black in CanadaMore 'Unbearable grief': 2 dead, 1 missing, 1 rescued after boat sinks off Fleur de Lys | CBC News LoadedNL'Unbearable grief': 2 dead, 1 missing, 1 rescued after boat sinks off Fleur de LysTwo people are dead following the sinking of a commercial cod boat off the northeast coast of Newfoundland. \"The sea has brought us a lot of blessings but it can be a cruel master at times,\" says former premier Tom Rideout, describing the grief in his home community.Coast guard says multiple ships respondingRyan Cooke, Mike Moore  · CBC News  · Posted: Sep 12, 2023 8:34 PM EDT | Last Updated: September 13, 2023Social SharingFleur de Lys is a small coastal community on Newfoundland's Baie Verte Peninsula. (CBC )Two people are dead following the sinking of a commercial cod boat off the northeast coast of Newfoundland, according to the RCMP.One person has been rescued and one is still missing, the force said Wednesday morning.The bodies of the dead have been recovered, according to a spokesperson for the police.The RCMP said local fishermen rescued one person from the shoreline and recovered two people who had died. Emergency services staff assessed the survivor and determined the person did not require further medical attention.Mark Gould, deputy superintendent of maritime search and rescue in Newfoundland and Labrador, said Wednesday afternoon the rescue and recoveries happened before the coast guard was notified.\"A vessel of opportunity came upon the incident and responded and rescued the one individual and recovered the two others,\" Gould said.\"At that point they called Labrador Coast Guard radio, which was the first indication that we had of a distress situation.\"Gould said the search area includes rocky shoreline, which makes the situation difficult but aircraft have been able to search the shoreline effectively.The search for the remaining missing crew member is ongoing, with support from local communities and from as far away as Deer Lake, Grand Falls-Windsor and Springdale.Gould said sea conditions were favourable at the time of the sinking and have remained so during the search. He said the coast guard has been in touch with the next of kin throughout the search.WATCH | No cell service and rocky terrain among challenges in search for missing boater: Search for missing boater expands to nearby land as ‘survivability’ window closes1 year agoDuration 1:01Mark Gould of the Canadian Coast Guard’s Maritime Rescue Sub-Centre in St. John's, said no cell service and rocky terrain are among the challenges in the ongoing search for a missing person after a boat sank off Fleur de Lys.\"We are reaching the end of the survivability window. The best case for survivability for this individual would have been had he made it ashore,\" Gould said. \"All these incidents hit communities really hard.\"The four crew members are believed to be from the small towns of Fleur de Lys and Coachman's Cove, on Newfoundland's Baie Verte Peninsula, according to the local parish priest, Camillus Ekodobe.The 23-foot boat went down about less than two kilometres away from Fleur de Lys around 3 p.m. Tuesday afternoon — about 100 metres off the shoreline. Canadian Coast Guard vessels CCGS Earl Grey, CCGS Conception Bay and the CCGS Pennant Bay are in the area to aid in the search and rescue efforts, along with two auxiliary vessels and PAL Airlines.A Canadian Forces Cormorant helicopter returned to the air Wednesday morning. Three ground search and rescue teams are searching the immediate area on land, and the RCMP's underwater recovery team has been deployed.Local vessels have also been helping in the response.Priest describes dramatic sceneEkodobe, a Roman Catholic priest, was en route to Fleur de Lys on Tuesday evening for a wake. When he arrived at the church, he was surprised to find it already half full. That's when he learned of the sunken boat, and the rescue mission that was ongoing.\"You could feel the grief in the air. It was like a cold chill in the air for everybody,\" he said Wednesday morning. The wake was cancelled as people used the church while they waited for word on the fate of the four people on board. \"It was so bad for everybody. They were so sad,\" Ekodobe said. \"It was so unbearable.\"WATCH | 'Everybody feels it,' says Fleur dy Lys resident Tom Rideout on the deadly boat sinking: Deadly boat sinking ‘devastating blow,’ says Fleur de Lys resident and former premier1 year agoDuration 2:57Tom Rideout says every person in the small community is feeling the loss and grief after a boat sank off Fleur de Lys, on Newfoundland’s northeast coast.He said everyone is hoping for a positive outcome for the missing individual, despite the odds being stacked against them. \"Let it turn to good. Let it turn to good. That's what everybody is praying for.\"'Devastating blow'Former Newfoundland and Labrador premier Tom Rideout, who's from Fleur de Lys, called the tragedy a \"devastating blow\" to the community.\"Everybody feels it because everybody is friends and everybody is related,\" he said from his family home Wednesday morning.\"My next-door neighbour, who I can look out and see his house next to mine, two of those people are related to that household. So you can imagine what it's like, I'm sure, in a small, rural Newfoundland community where everybody knows each other and is affected so deeply by this.\"Canadian Coast Guard ships and a military helicopter are responding to a sunken vessel near Fleur de Lys.  (Simon Nakonechny/CBC)Life in the town has by and large always revolved around the sea, he said.\"The sea has brought us a lot of blessings but it can be a cruel master at times, and this community experienced that yesterday.\"The town is in shock, said Rideout.\"It's like we're all going around as zombies. We don't know what to do, we don't know what to say to each other,\" he said. \"When you see a person, you don't know where to start the conversation. It's a terrible, terrible tragedy for any community, but particularly a small community where everybody is so close-knit.\"The RCMP said the investigation into the cause of the sunken vessel is continuing with Transport Canada and Workplace N.L. The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner is also involved. Get the news you need without restrictions.     "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/search-ends-missing-fishermen-marys-harbour-1.6182124": "Search for missing Mary's Harbour fishermen resumes with aid of military, coast guard | CBC News\nContentSkip to Main ContentAccessibility HelphamburgerMenuWhen search suggestions are available use up and down arrows to review and enter to select.SearchSearchSign InQuick LinksNewsSportsRadioMusicListen LiveTVWatchnewsTop StoriesLocalClimateWorldCanadaPoliticsIndigenousBusinessThe NationalHealthEntertainmentScienceCBC News InvestigatesGo PublicAbout CBC NewsBeing Black in CanadaMore Search for missing Mary's Harbour fishermen resumes with aid of military, coast guard | CBC News LoadedNLSearch for missing Mary's Harbour fishermen resumes with aid of military, coast guardThe search for two missing fishermen from Mary's Harbour has resumed with the help of the Canadian Armed Forces and the coast guard Monday, after the official search off the coast of southern Labrador was called off Sunday night.Search resumed for the Island Lady and its 2 crew MondayCBC News  · Posted: Sep 20, 2021 6:42 AM EDT | Last Updated: September 20, 2021Marc Russell, left, and Joey Jenkins aboard the Island Lady. The pair was last heard from around 4 p.m. on Friday. (Submitted by Dwight Russell )Social SharingThe search for two missing fishermen from Mary's Harbour has resumed with the help of the Canadian Armed Forces and the coast guard Monday, after the official search off the coast of southern Labrador was called off Sunday night.In a Facebook post Monday, Labrador MP Yvonne Jones wrote that an RCAF maritime patrol plane and a coast guard vessel are now assisting in the search under the authorization of federal ministers after the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre in Halifax decided to end its search.\"After many hours overnight with the family, coast guard, the federal [and] provincial ministers and pressing forward, the JRCC would still not revert back to SAR and maintained their position to move to recovery operations,\" wrote Jones.\"I have been assured that the Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) will be continuing to assist RCMP and other partners in this effort. All support needed will be provided.… I am also assured that all other support will be provided and coordinated as required by the RCMP.\"The JRCC tweeted around 9 p.m. Sunday that it had suspended the search for the Island Lady following more than 48 hours of searching an area off Mary's Harbour spanning 4,500 nautical square miles, in an effort that involved \"a significant number\" of aircraft and vessels.Regrettably, based on the results of the exhaustive search by a significant number of SAR aircraft and vessels over the last 48+ hours, a search covering over 4500 sq NM, the search for the two missing fishers aboard the FV Island Lady has been suspended.&mdash;@hfxjrcc'We've lost valuable time'Two men from Mary's Harbour, Marc Russell and Joey Jenkins, were aboard the Island Lady. Shortly after the search first ended Sunday, Russell's father asked in a Facebook post for the search to be extended by 24 hours.Dwight Russell told CBC News Monday afternoon he and other family members and searchers wanted that extra day to be able to bridge from a JRCC-led effort into a localized one, but that didn't happen. \"It's a duplication of services that could have just been continued, but we've lost valuable time,\" said Russell.WATCH | Marc Russell's family speaks about the search for the missing fishermenMissing fishermen3 years agoDuration 5:55The family of missing fisherman Marc Russell ask for more time for the search effort.Marc Russell's mother held a picture of her son as she said Monday's federal election played a role in the search disruption. The family said they pressed federal departments like the office of the prime minister, and had politicians tell them the search would continue — just as the JRCC called it off.\"We feel lost within the process. There's a breakdown of information somewhere,\" Jeanette Russell said.Marc Russell is one of two fishermen from Mary's Harbour missing since Friday. (Submitted by Jeanette Russell)CBC News has asked the JRCC and Canadian Coast Guard for comment.The search for the fishing vessel and its crew began Friday evening after it did not return to port by 5 p.m. NT. Russell said the crew had called in to the local fish plant shortly before that to say they were coming home with their catch, and Jenkins had also placed a call to his partner.\"Whatever happened from that point on, we don't know,\" said Russell.Local fishing crews were first out on the water, and joined a few hours later by the JRCC, Canadian Coast Guard, PAL Airlines and the Royal Canadian Air Force.Dozens protest called-off searchJeannette Russell asked earlier Monday for people to protest the end of the official search.\"Please just help us find our boys, so we can bring them home,\" she said.On Monday afternoon more than 70 people holding signs and chanting did exactly that, blocking the entrance to coast guard headquarters in downtown St. John's\"That could be you or me one day,\" said Nick Windsor, holding a sign over his head that read \"Continue the Search.\"\"Whether it's a car accident or on a boat, we want to be rescued. To see them being left alone, that's the worst feeling you could ever feel in this world.\"Despite repeated attempts at the front gate, the demonstrators couldn't get the attention of anyone inside.\"This office here, to ignore us the way they are, that just shows what our government is actually like,\" said Windsor.More than 70 people showed up to protest the called-off search at the coast guard building in St. John's.  (Jeremy Eaton/CBC)MHA Lisa Dempster spoke to the crowd through a megaphone, calling the situation \"an emotional time for everyone.\"The representative for Cartwright-L'Anse au Clair says she made calls to try and get a meeting with the JRCC, but was told that couldn't happen due to ongoing federal election. \"This is about saving lives,\" Dempster said to the crowd.\"What happens when governments go into election mode. Do we stop searching for people? No we don't.\"In a joint statement, provincial Fisheries Minister Derrick Bragg and Justice Minister John Hogan said the province is doing everything it can to support search efforts. According to the statement the Emergency Services Division of the Department of Justice and Public Safety has been working with Canadian Coast Guard officials, the JRCC, the Marine Rescue Sub-Centre and others since Saturday morning. The ESD offered rotary-wing and fixed-wing aircraft to aid in the search.The statement said when the RCMP took over the search on Sunday night, the ESD engaged with the RCMP, Government Air Services and a volunteer group called the Civil Air Search and Rescue Association. On Monday morning, a government water bomber was deployed from Deer Lake.Boat not foundThe demonstrators, many with ties to the Russell and Jenkin's families or Labrador, held signs pleading to extend the search by 24 hours, arguing weather had posed a challenge for search teams earlier this weekend.\"The first day of searching was hampered by wind and fog, and we felt that enough wasn't done,\" Dwight Russell said Monday morning. A single blue fishing tub was found Sunday, with a second tub and some fishing buckets found later. The items are believed to be from the Island Lady.But Russell said the search hasn't turned up anything that conclusively proves the boat sank, or that the men went into the water. \"We haven't found any part of the boat or the life ring. There was survival suits aboard the boat. We haven't seen any of that,\" he said. \"They would have floated to the surface if something happened, we would think.\"Search for Mary's Harbour fishermen enters 2nd day as N.L. communities hold vigils overnightRussell thanked all those who helped search and support so far — more than half a dozen Labrador communities held vigils for the men Saturday night — but said there was \"a dire lack of resources to address this situation.\"\"We're angry at the situation, but we're not angry at anyone in particular ... we're just asking for some humanity to this situation,\" said Jeanette Russell.\"I could understand if these vessels were needed in a search somewhere else. That would be totally understandable. But ... there are no other events right now where they are needed.\"Dwight Russell said the current crisis shines a light on a severe shortage of search and rescue services along Labrador's coast.\"We need public pressure to change all this ... I want to bring my son home. We want to bring Joey home... it should never have come to this,\" he said.On Twitter, the JRCC said the matter has now been turned over to the RCMP as a missing persons at sea case. Read more from CBC Newfoundland and LabradorWith files from Jonny Hodder and Anthony GermainCBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices|About CBC NewsCorrections and clarifications|Submit a news tip|Report errorFooter LinksMy AccountProfileCBC GemNewslettersAbout CBC AccountsConnect with CBCFacebookXYouTubeInstagramMobileRSSPodcastsContact CBCSubmit FeedbackHelp CentreAudience Relations, CBC P.O. A Joint Rescue and Co-ordination Centre spokesperson says four people were alive when they were picked up by a Cormorant helicopter.4 survivors airlifted and brought to hospitalElizabeth Whitten   · CBC News  · Posted: Apr 21, 2024 2:00 PM EDT | Last Updated: April 23, 2024Social SharingA rescue operation is underway Sunday near Port au Port, N.L., between Molly Ann Cove and Rope Cove. (Submitted by Sam Anderson)Two people are dead following a vessel capsizing on Newfoundland's west coast Sunday morning, near the community of Lark Harbour.Long Range Mountains MP Gudie Hutchings posted on social media that two men had died.\"The sea giveth and the sea taketh away. I am devastated to hear two young men have perished at sea. All the love and prayers in the world are needed now for the families and the Lark Harbour community and fishing communities everywhere,\" she wrote in a post on X, formerly known as Twitter.The Fish, Food & Allied Workers union also sent its condolences to the families impacted by this tragedy and the communities of York Harbour and Lark Harbour\"One life lost at sea is always one life too many. These lives were far too young to go,\" said FFAW-Unifor's statement on Facebook.In a post on X, Long Range Mountains MP Gudie Hutchings posted her condolences and wrote that \"two young men have perished at sea.\" (Gudie Hutchings/X)In a post on the Lark Harbour Facebook page, the town said the town hall would be opened for people to gather Sunday evening \"as a gathering spot for our residents to support each other in this time of grief.\"Premier Andrew Furey also said his heart was with Lark Habour and he'd spoken with Mayor Maria MacDonald, as well as Hutchings and MHA Eddie Joyce. \"I will be there to support the community through this challenging time,\" he wrote.Four people airliftedCapt. Trevor Ackland, spokesperson for the Joint Task Force Atlantic in support of the Joint Rescue and Coordination Centre in Halifax, initially said four people were airlifted from a beach on the west coast and brought to hospital after the vessel was found capsized. The DFO later corrected this version of events, and said the survivors were airlifted to shore, where they were treated by paramedics.He said the centre responded to a call from the Maritime Rescue Sub-Centre in St. John's for assistance after reports of people in the water.A Cormorant helicopter has been dispatched to the scene. (Submitted by Sam Anderson)Ackland said a Cormorant helicopter was dispatched from the Search and Rescue Squadron in Gander to the scene, which was near Molly Ann Cove.\"Once they arrived on scene, they proceeded to pick up and airlift four persons that were located on a beach,\" Ackland told CBC News.Ackland said he couldn't speculate on fatalities but the four people were alive when they were airlifted.Fish harvester Sam Anderson was fishing in the area around Molly Ann Cove and Rope Cove around 11 a.m. Sunday when he spotted a cabin on fire on shore.He saw a couple of men on the beach, he said, with a capsized vessel nearby.\"We followed the procedure, you know, contacted the coast guard radio and we tried to get him. We couldn't get at him because the waters were too shallow and nothing we could do,\" Anderson told CBC News.He said it was a remote area with no roads.Download our free CBC News app to sign up for push alerts for CBC Newfoundland and Labrador. Click here to visit our landing page.ABOUT THE AUTHORElizabeth Whitten ReporterElizabeth Whitten is a journalist and editor based in St. John's.CBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices|About CBC NewsCorrections and clarifications|Submit a news tip|Report errorFooter LinksMy AccountProfileCBC GemNewslettersAbout CBC AccountsConnect with CBCFacebookXYouTubeInstagramMobileRSSPodcastsContact CBCSubmit FeedbackHelp CentreAudience Relations, CBC P.O. (Jeorge Sadi/CBC)Social SharingThe body of a missing fisherman has been found off the coast of Yarmouth, N.S.The Joint Rescue Coordination Centre said the 52-year-old was found at 2 p.m. AT Friday by search and rescue personnel. JRCC spokesperson Lt.-Cmdr. Brian Owens offered his condolences to the family, friends and community of the fisherman.\"This has been a very difficult time for them all and our hearts and thoughts go out to them as they now deal with this situation,\" he said.\"Certainly we can't imagine what they're going through, but we're at least glad that they were able to have some closure to this.\"Owens did not have specific information readily available about where the man's body was found.He said crew on the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Clarks Harbour found some items floating on the water. \"That enabled us to then significantly reduce the search area and commit more assets to that specific area,\" Owens said.A Cormorant helicopter searched nearby and found the man's body in open water. A Cormorant helicopter, seen here in a file photo, found the man's body in open water off the coast of Yarmouth, N.S. (Brent Ruskin/CBC News)The man was the captain of a fishing vessel identified as the Miss Janet, which was travelling from Shelburne to Saulnierville.The man's identity has not been released at the request of his family.He was one of four crew on board the boat.Three of the men had gone to sleep Wednesday night, leaving the captain in the wheelhouse. But when one of the crew woke up at 3:30 a.m., the captain was gone and a distress call was made.The band office of the Sipekne'katik First Nation confirmed the man is a member of the community. Several fishermen from Sipekne'katik were assisting in the search Thursday.\"We are focused on supporting our community at this time,\" Chief Mike Sack said in a statement to CBC News.The Fisheries Safety Association of Nova Scotia issued a statement of condolences Friday afternoon. It said it was working with the Workers' Compensation Board of Nova Scotia to have grief counselling services made available for the crew, the family and friends of the captain and Sipekne'katik First Nation community members.MORE TOP STORIESHalifax Harbour Bridges hopes to stop big vehicles from getting stuck at tiny tollsAfghan family 'thankful' to settle in Halifax after escaping KabulSpurred by granddaughter's death, MLA asks for review of N.S. bereavement leave provisionsBill banning protests at health-care sites won't apply to labour actionN.S. reports 18 new cases of COVID-19 on FridayWith files from Frances WillickCBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices|About CBC NewsCorrections and clarifications|Submit a news tip|Report errorFooter LinksMy AccountProfileCBC GemNewslettersAbout CBC AccountsConnect with CBCFacebookXYouTubeInstagramMobileRSSPodcastsContact CBCSubmit FeedbackHelp CentreAudience Relations, CBC P.O.     "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/treal/fishing-boat-sinks-la-tabatiere-1.6977742": "3 dead after fishing boat sinks near Quebec's Lower North Shore | CBC News\nContentSkip to Main ContentAccessibility HelphamburgerMenuWhen search suggestions are available use up and down arrows to review and enter to select.SearchSearchSign InQuick LinksNewsSportsRadioMusicListen LiveTVWatchnewsTop StoriesLocalClimateWorldCanadaPoliticsIndigenousBusinessThe NationalHealthEntertainmentScienceCBC News InvestigatesGo PublicAbout CBC NewsBeing Black in CanadaMore 3 dead after fishing boat sinks near Quebec's Lower North Shore | CBC News LoadedMontreal3 dead after fishing boat sinks near Quebec's Lower North ShoreThree survivors have been taken to hospital in Corner Brook, N.L.Silver Condor capsized off La Tabatière, 6 crew found in the waterCBC News  · Posted: Sep 25, 2023 3:39 PM EDT | Last Updated: September 25, 2023The crew of the Carly M Paige coast guard boat (shown) helped with the search for the fishing vessel that capsized off La Tabatière. (Radio-Canada)Social SharingThree people are dead after a fishing vessel capsized and sank just off La Tabatière, on Quebec's Lower North Shore, Quebec provincial police say. Three others were taken to hospital in Corner Brook, N.L.The Canadian Coast Guard says the vessel was the 18-metre-long Silver Condor, from Blanc-Sablon, Que. The ship was built in 1983 and rebuilt in 2005.\"It's definitely difficult, it's a small community so any loss affects many people,\" said Blanc-Sablon Mayor Andrew Etheridge.He told CBC that his cousin, a father of three, was among those who died.A distress signal was received around 2:30 a.m. Monday morning. Two Coast Guard vessels and an Armed Forces Cormorant helicopter were dispatched to the scene. The ship went down about 20 nautical miles (37 kilometres) offshore, in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, according to the Coast Guard.The cause of the sinking remains unknown, but police believe there was no criminal cause.A coroner will be assigned to the case, and there will be investigations by the Transportation Safety Board (TSB) and Quebec's workplace safety board, the CNESST.The TSB said it is still gathering information to determine if an investigation will be warranted.with files from Rachel Watts, Radio-Canada and the Canadian PressCBC's Journalistic Standards and Practices|About CBC NewsCorrections and clarifications|Submit a news tip|Report errorRelated StoriesVideo Wreck of 150-year-old unlucky ship found off Lake Superior's Shipwreck CoastFooter LinksMy AccountProfileCBC GemNewslettersAbout CBC AccountsConnect with CBCFacebookXYouTubeInstagramMobileRSSPodcastsContact CBCSubmit FeedbackHelp CentreAudience Relations, CBC P.O. Staff\nOctober 3, 2023 / 2:24 PM CDT\n/ CBS Minnesota\nBodies of 2 men recovered from St. Croix River near Hudson\nBodies of 2 men recovered from St. Croix River near Hudson\n00:23\nHUDSON, Wis. — The bodies of two men were recovered Tuesday from the St. Croix River near Hudson.The St. Croix County Sheriff's office says authorities were alerted at about 9:35 a.m. to a fishing boat that was driving in circles near Troy Beach, with a body in the water nearby.\nWater rescue operation on the St. Croix River.\nWCCO\nWashington County Sheriff's deputies were first to hit the water and found the boat about 650 yards from shore, but weren't able to initially locate a body.At about 12:12 p.m., the county's dive team recovered a man's body. About six hours later, the body of another man was recovered. The water in that area is between 30-40 feet deep.On Wednesday, the St. Croix County Sheriff's Office identified the men as 51-year-old Demetrius Kekedakis and 65-year-old Perry Montpetit, both from Hudson.\nThe circumstances surrounding the drownings are still under investigation.MORE NEWS: Terry Martin expected to change plea to guilty for stealing \"The Wizard of Oz\" ruby slippers\nMore from CBS News\nFishermen rescued from St. Croix River after truck goes through thin ice\nWoman charged in deadly downtown Minneapolis apartment fire\nPolice search for motorist who collided with LRT train in St. Paul\nMinnesota Yacht Club Festival announces 2025 lineup\nWCCO Staff\nThe WCCO Staff is a group of experienced journalists who bring you the content on WCCO.com.\nTwitter\nFacebook\nInstagram\n© 2023 CBS Broadcasting Inc.     "https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202309/24/WS650fce1ba310d2dce4bb780b.html": "Fishing boat sinks, leaving 1 dead, 7 missing - Chinadaily.com.cn\nSearch\nHOME\nCHINA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nLIFESTYLE\nCULTURE\nTRAVEL\nVIDEO\nSPORTS\nOPINION\nREGIONAL\nFORUM\nNEWSPAPER\nMOBILE\nGlobal EditionASIA\n中文双语Français\nHOME\nCHINA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nLIFESTYLE\nCULTURE\nTRAVEL\nVIDEO\nSPORTS\nOPINION\nREGIONAL\nFORUM\nNEWSPAPER\nChina Daily PDF\nChina Daily E-paper\nMOBILE\nChina\nNews\nSociety\nInnovation\nHK/Macao\nCross-Strait\nCover Story\nPhoto\nEnvironment\nHealth\nMilitary\nVideo\nHome\n/ China\n/ Society\nHome\nChina\nSociety\nFishing boat sinks, leaving 1 dead, 7 missing\nBy Zhang Xiaomin |\nchinadaily.com.cn |\nUpdated: 2023-09-24 13:50\nShare\nShare - WeChat\nCLOSE\nA fishing boat capsized and sank off the coast of Dalian, Liaoning province, on Saturday morning, resulting in one confirmed death and seven others on board missing.\nThe Liaoning Maritime Search and Rescue Center received the report from the Dalian Maritime Search and Rescue Center at about 11 am on Saturday, saying that a collision between a Dandong-registered fishing boat and a cargo ship occurred in the Dalian Lushun sea area, resulting in the fishing boat capsizing and sinking. The fishing boat was carrying eight people at the time, while the crew of the cargo ship remained unharmed.\nPromptly responding to the accident, local authorities in Liaoning initiated search and rescue operations and coordinated efforts with multiple organizations. As of Saturday evening, one person had been confirmed dead, while seven others remained missing. The search and rescue operation is still ongoing.\nAccording to the Dalian Maritime Bureau, the fishing boat capsized at about 10:50 am on Saturday. All passing vessels are urged to remain vigilant and assist in the search efforts.\nAs of Sunday noon, no more information was released.\nPhoto\nWuxi dazzles the world at Spring Festival Gala\nPeople stick to their posts on Chinese New Year's Eve\nPeople have reunion meals on eve of Spring Festival\nHappy Year of the Snake\nHappy Year of the Snake\nApple orchards mitigate soil erosion\nLatest\nVisitors explore Spring Festival temple fair in Beijing\nWuxi dazzles the world at Spring Festival Gala\nJoin Yuanxi to celebrate the Year of the Snake\nXi Jinping on love for family and nation\nPeople stick to their posts on Chinese New Year's Eve\nPeople have reunion meals on eve of Spring Festival\nState Council News\nHappy Spring Festival 2025\nChinese premier holds symposium with foreign experts in China\nChinese leaders extend Spring Festival greetings to retired senior officials\nExclusive\nChina's 24 Solar Terms and intangible cultural heritage\nTaiwan actress Ji Tian-yu shares her Spring Festival tradition\nRailway police: guardians of Spring Festival travelers\nNewsmaker\nAthlete stands firm on his Chinese identity\nPassion for butterflies prompts life-changing decision\nTen photos you don't wanna miss\nTen photos from across China: Jan 17 – 23\nSpecial Coverage\n2025 Spring Festival travel rush\n25th anniversary of Macao SAR\nTop\nBACK TO THE TOP\nEnglish\n中文\nHOME\nCHINA\nWORLD\nBUSINESS\nLIFESTYLE\nCULTURE\nTRAVEL\nVIDEO\nSPORTS\nOPINION\nREGIONAL\nFORUM\nNEWSPAPER\nChina Daily PDF\nChina Daily E-paper\nMOBILE\nCopyright 1995 - . (PHOTO / XINHUA)DALIAN — Four people have been confirmed dead and three others are still missing on a sea angling trip in waters near the northeastern Chinese city of Dalian, the local rescue center said Monday.Dalian maritime search and rescue center received a report at 11 pm Sunday that a boat with seven people on board was missing in waters near Dalian, Liaoning province.As of 10:10 am Monday, four people had been found dead, and three others were still missingREAD MORE: Capsized Chinese fishing vessel drifts over 100 nautical milesThe center dispatched rescue vessels and asked nearby ships to join the search.     "https://www.citizen.co.za/review-online/news-headlines/local-news/2023/11/09/fisherman-57-drowns-in-nwanedi-dam/": "Fisherman (57) drowns in dam in Limpopo | Review\nThursday, January 30 2025\nFacebookXYouTubeInstagramThe Citizen\nMenu\nSearch for\nNews\nLocal news\nSchools\nBusiness\nNetwork News\nClassifieds\nView Classifieds\nPlace an ad\nRequest a quote\nLifestyle\nLifestyle News\nGet It\nKids\nHomes\nMotoring\nMotoring News\nUsed Cars For Sale\nNew Cars For Sale\nDemo Cars For Sale\nSport\nNetwork News Sport\nLocal Sport\nPromotions\nSpecials\nTheo Goosen Estate Agents & Auctioneers\nJob Seekers – LIMPOPO\nSTAY INFORMED with- Limpopo notices\nReview Deals\nMunicipal Demarcation Board\nAbout Us\nThe Citizen\nPolokwane\n20\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t℃\nSearch for\nHome/News/Local News/Fisherman (57) drowns in dam in Limpopo\nLocal News\nFisherman (57) drowns in dam in Limpopo\nShumani Phaswana ran into trouble during his second attempt of trying to launch his self-made boat.\nNovember 9, 2023\nDovhani Nengovhela\n1 minute read\nFacebook\nX\nLinkedIn\nTumblr\nPinterest\nWhatsApp\nTelegram\nShare via Email\nPrint\nPolice's search and rescue workers retrieve the body from the water.\nLIMPOPO – Even though Shumani Phaswana was unemployed, this did not prevent him from making a meaningful life for himself and those close to him. The 57-year-old man from Muswodi Tshisimani would often venture to the local Nwanedi Dam and fish, keeping some of his catch for himself and selling the rest to the community.\nLast Sunday, however, Phaswana went to the dam as usual with a friend and tried to launch his self-made boat onto the water. He, however, ran into trouble during his second attempt and the boat sank, causing him to drown.\nPolice’s search and rescue workers retrieve the body from the water.\nNews about the drowning reached the village and neighbouring villages instantly via social media, and within a very short space of time, a crowd of onlookers flocked to the dam. Many believe the dam has seen far too many drownings, and they blame government for not doing enough to deny people access to the dam.\nPolice spokesperson Brig Hlulani Mashaba confirmed the incident. “We have opened an inquest and appeal to residents not to venture into deep waters, either for fishing or swimming, as there is always the danger of drowning and being attacked by animals such as crocodiles and hippos.”\nFamily spokesperson and cousin of the deceased, Jeremiah Makhado, said he last spoke to Phaswana on the day before he died.\n“He was in such good spirits, and I was shocked to receive the bad news on Sunday. This is very hard on the family. He has left a big void in our hearts.”\nJames Muthathedzwa, who was at the dam to comfort the grieving family, said the dam served no purpose to the community and that it should be fenced off.\n“So many lives have been lost here. It worries us that government is still mining soil from the dam, without even considering the safety of the community. Many children risk their lives swimming in these dangerous waters and the worst is still to come if nothing is done here.”\nPhaswana was buried at Muswodi Tshisimani on Saturday.\nFor more breaking news follow us on Facebook Twitter Instagram or join our WhatsApp group\nAt Caxton, we employ humans to generate daily fresh news, not AI intervention. Happy reading!\nStay in the know.     "https://www.citizen.co.za/review-online/news-headlines/local-news/2024/03/14/double-tragedy-at-dam/": "Father and son drown while fishing at dam in Limpopo | Review\nThursday, January 30 2025\nFacebookXYouTubeInstagramThe Citizen\nMenu\nSearch for\nNews\nLocal news\nSchools\nBusiness\nNetwork News\nClassifieds\nView Classifieds\nPlace an ad\nRequest a quote\nLifestyle\nLifestyle News\nGet It\nKids\nHomes\nMotoring\nMotoring News\nUsed Cars For Sale\nNew Cars For Sale\nDemo Cars For Sale\nSport\nNetwork News Sport\nLocal Sport\nPromotions\nSpecials\nTheo Goosen Estate Agents & Auctioneers\nJob Seekers – LIMPOPO\nSTAY INFORMED with- Limpopo notices\nReview Deals\nMunicipal Demarcation Board\nAbout Us\nThe Citizen\nPolokwane\n20\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t℃\nSearch for\nHome/News/Local News/Father and son drown while fishing at dam in Limpopo\nLocal News\nFather and son drown while fishing at dam in Limpopo\nThe man's other son stayed behind on the embankment where he remained overnight waiting for their return.\nMarch 14, 2024\nDovhani Nengovhela\n1 minute read\nFacebook\nX\nLinkedIn\nTumblr\nPinterest\nWhatsApp\nTelegram\nShare via Email\nPrint\nPolice divers retrieve one body from the water.\nLIMPOPO – Double tragedy struck when both the 58-year-old Laxon Madzingira and his 28-year-old son, Effort Madzingira from Tshifulanani outside Thohoyandou drowned while fishing at Albasini Dam on Friday.\nFrom what could be established, the father, accompanied by his two sons, set out on a boat to fish.\nThe other son, Spadon Madzingira stayed behind on the embankment. When they did not return, he was left waiting throughout the night with no information of their whereabouts.\nWhen CV visited the scene, Madzingira’s son-in-law, Gilbert Muzuru said that they were struggling to come to terms with their sudden and tragic loss.\n“We received the sad news from the son that accompanied them. He said it was heart-breaking, and he waited for them the whole night, but they never returned. His father had been a fisherman for years. We are just left with many questions about how it happened.”\nAccording to Vhembe police spokesperson WO Vuledzani Dathi, the Makhado police were investigating the incident.\nHe confirmed that the body of the 28-year-old man was found by a resident who had gone to the dam to fish.\n“Mr de Jager, also a fisherman, was removing the fishing nets from the water when he noticed the hand of a human. He then drove the boat closer.\n“He contacted the local police station to report the incident and when we arrived at the dam, we retrieved the body from the water.”\nThe body was taken to the Elim government mortuary for an autopsy and further police investigations.\nDathi said the team, comprising the police, EMS workers and police divers were alerted that another body was spotted floating in the dam on Sunday. The body of the father was subsequently retrieved.\n“No foul play is suspected, and we identified the victim as Laxon Madzingira. Further police investigations showed that the two deceased fishermen were father and son.”\nFor more breaking news follow us on Facebook Twitter Instagram or join our WhatsApp group\nAt Caxton, we employ humans to generate daily fresh news, not AI intervention. Happy reading!\nStay in the know.
