The sole deckhand on board was unable to recover the skipper, who was later airlifted to hospital by a search and rescue helicopter but could not be revived.\nSafety issues\nPioneer had a low bulwark at its aft deck, which did not prevent the skipper’s fall into the water\nThe skipper was not wearing a personal flotation device\nCritical safety equipment was either missing, incorrectly fitted or out of date\nCollectively, a number of deficiencies identified indicated that Pioneer was being operated with a low standard of safety management\nThe instructions to Maritime and Coastguard Agency surveyors did not contain robust guidance to ensure that successive surveys were completed to a consistent standard\nRecommendations\nA recommendation (2024/169) has been made to the Maritime and Coastguard Agency to revise its guidance to surveyors to provide clear instructions on how to complete surveys and inspections.\nRelated publications\nA safety flyer to the fishing industry was produced with this report, signposting the importance of a well maintained vessel that is fit to go to sea.\nMAIB report 1/2013 - St Amant\nMAIB report 8/2019 - Fram of Shieldaig\nUpdates to this page\nPublished 4 December 2024\nContents\nExplore the topic\nMaritime accidents and serious incidents\nIs this page useful?\nMaybe\nYes this page is useful\nNo this page is not useful\nThank you for your feedback\nReport a problem with this page\nHelp us improve GOV.UK\nDon’t include personal or financial information like your National Insurance number or credit card details.\nThis field is for robots only.     "https://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/2023/05/31/hawaii-man-dead-wife-remains-missing-after-charter-boat-sinks-off-alaska/": "Hawaii couple among 3 dead after fishing charter boat capsizes in Alaska\nSkip to contentHI Now DailyContestsJoin Our TeamAdvertise with UsLiveNewsFirst Alert WeatherSunriseSportsEntertainmentKitchen ScrapsPodcastsHI Now DailyAbout UsHomeWatch LiveNewsLocal HeadlinesNational NewsHNN InvestigatesPriced Out of ParadiseThis Is NowSubmit Your Photos!Latest NewscastsFirst Alert WeatherWeather UpdatesSurf ReportWeather 101HNN Hurricane CenterTsunami CenterTrafficSunriseAs Seen On SunriseHealthier HawaiiWhat's TrendingHoward's Business ReportSmart Money MondayCelebrating Fil-Am HistoryHawaiian Word Of The DaySpecial ReportsSpotlight NowPodcastsHawaii News NowIsland Beat'Muthaship' with Stephanie Lum'The Other Side of Paradise' with Lynn KawanoHNN OvertimeHNN Off-Air'Tell Me A Story' with Jim MendozaSportsHNN OvertimeThe EddieHonolulu MarathonScoringLiveWarrior NationGridiron PicksKitchen ScrapsEntertainmentNa Hoku Hanohano AwardsKeiki HulaCheap EatsPacific PulseKupuna PowerK5 MeleTeen TalkContestsHI Now DailyHI Now JapanTalk StoryCommunityMy Life. Just ListenCalendarEventsHonolulu PrideActivitiesAbout UsAnchors & ReportersNews DepartmentSales DepartmentJoin Our TeamEEO Public File ReportsTV GuideTV ListingsKHNL Antenna TVTerry's TakeHoliday ProgrammingTelemundo HawaiiNextGen TVZeam - News StreamsPowerNationCircle CountyGray DC BureauInvestigateTVWatching Your WalletDigital Marketing4 weather alerts in effectDismiss Weather Alerts Alerts BarHawaii couple among 3 dead after fishing charter boat capsizes in AlaskaOfficials in Alaska say three people have died and two others remain missing after a boat capsized on Sunday. (Source: KHNL)By Annalisa BurgosPublished: May. 31, 2023 at 11:21 AM HST|Updated: Jun. 1, 2023 at 8:47 AM HSTEmail This LinkShare on FacebookShare on X (formerly Twitter)Share on PinterestShare on LinkedInHONOLULU (HawaiiNewsNow) - Three people are dead, including a couple from Hawaii, and two others are missing after the fishing charter boat they were on sank off Alaska on Sunday, according to officials and family members on Wednesday.Alaska State Troopers identified the couple as 57-year-old Maury Agcaoili and wife 53-year-old Danielle Agcaoili, of Waipahu.The Agcaoilis were both passengers on the boat, along with Danielle’s sister 56-year-old Brandi Tyau and Brandi’s partner 61-year-old Robert Solis, both from California.On Wednesday evening, troopers recovered two female bodies from the sunken vessel that are believed to be Danielle and Brandi. They’re being transported to the State Medical Examiner’s Office in Anchorage for examination and positive identification.Solis and the boat captain 32-year-old Morgan Robidou, of Sitka, remain missing.The sisters’ parents and brother were also on the trip with them but had taken a separate vessel, according to Jim Solis, the brother of Robert Solis.The U.S. Coast Guard said it received a call Sunday night from Kingfisher Charters reporting that a 30-foot aluminum charter boat with five people on board had not returned from a day fishing trip.Using both air and vessel search crews, the Coast Guard found the charter boat partially submerged off Low Island, approximately 10 miles west of Sitka. Crews also recovered Maury Agcaoili’s body in the same area.The Coast Guard searched a total of roughly 825 square miles over the course of more than 20 hours.The search for the missing individuals was suspended around 9:30 p.m. Monday.“Suspending a search is never an easy decision,” said Darwin Jensen, captain of the Port Southeast Alaska, in a statement. “We extend our deepest sympathy to the loved ones during this difficult time. Our sincere thanks to community partners and the good Samaritan vessels who rapidly responded to help in the search.”A Coast Guard spokesman said the swells were between 6 to 11 feet on the day of the sailing, rougher than normal, and that Alaska weather conditions are unpredictable. There was no advisory and sailings are at the captain’s discretion.In a statement, Kingfisher Charters said it is “devastated by the loss of the guests and captain of the Awakin. We are fully cooperating with the U.S. Coast Guard in its investigation of this tragic event and hope that it furnishes answers to the questions as to how it occurred.”A relative told HNN Wednesday Danielle’s body has since been recovered. In Hawaii, an outpouring of condolences from the community.Pearl City High School’s band director shared the news with parents in an email, writing that the Agcaoilis were active volunteers and their children Jarek and Jessika had been members of the band. A few band parents are hosting a meal rotation to help the children.Danielle worked in the Residential Services Division at First Hawaiian Bank. CEO Bob Harrison extended condolences to family and friends, saying in a statement that “she was a beloved member of our First Hawaiian Bank ‘ohana. We are keeping Dani, her husband, and her family members in our thoughts and prayers during this difficult time.”Alaska State Troopers said salvage crews are working to bring the boat to Sitka so officials can conduct a full investigation.A statement has been made on behalf of the Agcaoili family:The family of Maury and Danielle Agcaoili appreciates all of the kind words and condolences during this difficult time. Their family and friends will remember them as loving and encouraging parents. We ask that people respect the families privacy as they continue to grieve.Family of Maury and Danielle Agcaoili(Agcaoili family)Copyright 2023 Hawaii News Now.     "https://www.hindustantimes.com/cities/mumbai-news/fisherman-drowns-another-swims-to-safety-after-boat-capsizes-off-versova-shore-in-mumbai-search-underway-for-third-101691347514854.html": "1 dead, 1 missing as fishing boat capsizes off Versova | Mumbai news - Hindustan Times\nExplore\nSearch\nThursday, Jan 30, 2025\nNew Delhi oC\nSubscribe\nGames\nE-Paper\nSign in\nMy Account\nStart 14 Days Free Trial\nSubscribe\nEnjoy unlimited access\nSubscribe Now! Get features like\nAd lite\nA Minimal Ad Experience\nHT Premium Articles\nExpertly crafted articles\nQuickreads Segment\nNews brief in summary format\nHT E-paper\nAccess digital news experience\nStart 14 Days Free Trial\nHome\nBudget 2025\nDelhi Election 2025\nGames\nHT Photo Contest\nHT Premium\nHoroscope 2025\nHTCity\nLong Weekend Planner 2025\nLoan ₹10 Lakh\nIndia\nWorld\nReal Estate\nPowered by\nEntertainment\nTrending\nAstrology\nLifestyle\nEducation\nBusiness\nCities\nLatest News\nMahakumbh 2025 LIVE\nSri Lanka Vs Australia LIVE\nBudget 2025 Expectations LIVE\nDeepSeek FAQs\nPhotos\nCentury of Leadership\nWeb Stories\nSports\nDelhi News\nMumbai News\nBengaluru News\nTechnology\nQuickreads\nDaily Digest\nFollowing\nGames\n+ 11 more\nCentury of Leadership\nWeb Stories\nSports\nDelhi News\nMumbai News\nBengaluru News\nTechnology\nQuickreads\nDaily Digest\nFollowing\nGames\n1 dead, 1 missing as fishing boat capsizes off Versova    ByMegha Sood, Linah Baliga      Aug 07, 2023 12:15 AM IST        Read this news in brief form              Share Via         Copy Link           While the survivor Vijay Bamania, 35, swam for hours to reach the shore late that night, the body of Vinod Goel, 45, was found at Silver Beach, Versova, on Sunday morning. The search for the third fisherman, Usmani Bhandari, 22, who is suspected to have drowned, is under way         Mumbai: One fisherman drowned while another swam to safety after their fishing boat capsized in the sea around three kilometres off the Versova shore on Saturday evening.        According to the Versova police, the incident took place on Saturday evening when four fishing boats from Versova village set out into the sea. Each boat had three men. “Sensing a high tide and strong wind, three of the four boats returned to the shore,” said Ganesh Pawar, senior police inspector at Versova police station. “After reaching the shore, they realised that one boat was missing. One of the fishermen on it, Vijay Bamania, swam to the Madh Island coast and informed us later about the capsizing of his boat.” (Vijay Bate/HT Photo)    While the survivor Vijay Bamania, 35, swam for hours to reach the shore late that night, the body of Vinod Goel, 45, was found at Silver Beach, Versova, on Sunday morning. The search for the third fisherman, Usmani Bhandari, 22, who is suspected to have drowned, is under way.   According to the Versova police, the incident took place on Saturday evening when four fishing boats from Versova village set out into the sea. Each boat had three men. “Sensing a high tide and strong wind, three of the four boats returned to the shore,” said Ganesh Pawar, senior police inspector at Versova police station. “After reaching the shore, they realised that one boat was missing. One of the fishermen on it, Vijay Bamania, swam to the Madh Island coast and informed us later about the capsizing of his boat.” On receiving the alert, the police immediately informed the fire brigade, the Coast Guard and other agencies and launched a search operation for the two missing fishermen. The police said that Bamania had been admitted to hospital, as he was suffering from fatigue. “On Sunday morning, Goel’s body was washed ashore at Silver Beach in Versova,” said Pawar. “We are in the process of registering a case of accidental death and are in the midst of finding out more about the accident from Bamania.” The search operation for Bhandari was conducted by firemen and lifeguards using a ring buoy and ropes along with fishing boats. Indian Navy and helicopters were also deployed to trace the missing fishermen. The search operation was stopped at 1 pm on Sunday on account of high tide and resumed again by 2.30 pm. Santosh Sawant, deputy Chief Fire Officer, Zone 1, told HT, “From 1 pm to 2.30 pm on Sunday, the Mumbai fire brigade was making inquiries, but it was high tide and the police prevented us from carrying out search operations. We then called divers. The Navy was called and a search operation began through helicopters. In the evening we recovered one body.”       Recommended Topics    Share this article       Read this news in brief form              Share Via         Copy Link               Fisherman      Fishing Boat              Catch every big hit, every wicket with Crickit, a one stop destination for Live Scores, Match Stats, Infographics & much more.     "https://www.hindustantimes.com/cities/others/fishing-trawler-collision-off-gujarat-coast-leaves-one-fisherman-missing-seven-rescued-by-another-vessel-101692868724005.html": "7 fishermen rescued, 1 missing after trawler collides with ship near Okha coast - Hindustan Times\nExplore\nSearch\nThursday, Jan 30, 2025\nNew Delhi oC\nSubscribe\nGames\nE-Paper\nSign in\nMy Account\nStart 14 Days Free Trial\nSubscribe\nEnjoy unlimited access\nSubscribe Now! Get features like\nAd lite\nA Minimal Ad Experience\nHT Premium Articles\nExpertly crafted articles\nQuickreads Segment\nNews brief in summary format\nHT E-paper\nAccess digital news experience\nStart 14 Days Free Trial\nHome\nBudget 2025\nDelhi Election 2025\nGames\nHT Photo Contest\nHT Premium\nHoroscope 2025\nHTCity\nLong Weekend Planner 2025\nLoan ₹10 Lakh\nIndia\nWorld\nReal Estate\nPowered by\nEntertainment\nTrending\nAstrology\nLifestyle\nEducation\nBusiness\nCities\nLatest News\nMahakumbh 2025 LIVE\nSri Lanka Vs Australia LIVE\nBudget 2025 Expectations LIVE\nDeepSeek FAQs\nPhotos\nCentury of Leadership\nWeb Stories\nSports\nDelhi News\nMumbai News\nBengaluru News\nTechnology\nQuickreads\nDaily Digest\nFollowing\nGames\n+ 11 more\nCentury of Leadership\nWeb Stories\nSports\nDelhi News\nMumbai News\nBengaluru News\nTechnology\nQuickreads\nDaily Digest\nFollowing\nGames\n7 fishermen rescued, 1 missing after trawler collides with ship near Okha coast    ByHT Correspondent      Aug 24, 2023 03:31 PM IST        Read this news in brief form              Share Via         Copy Link           Officials said that seven of the eight individuals on board were rescued by the crew of another fishing vessel – Al Madad, while the search for one missing person was on         A fishing trawler collided with a ship off the Okha coast in Dev Bhoomi Dwarka district in Gujarat in the early hours of Thursday morning, leading to the destruction of the fishing boat - Faizal Mustafa, officials said.        Seven of the eight fishermen on board the trawler were rescued by the crew of another fishing vessel – Al Madad (HT Photo)    Officials said that seven of the eight fishermen on board the trawler were rescued by the crew of another fishing vessel – Al Madad, while the search for one missing person was on.    “The incident took place around 4-4:30am (on Thursday). Seven crew members have been successfully saved, while the search continues for the one remaining fisherman. The Indian Coast Guard has deployed a boat, and an aerial survey is underway with the assistance of a chopper,” said Ashok Sharma, collector, Dev Bhoomi Dwarka district.  Sharma said the identity of the vessel with which the fishing boat collided is not known yet and an investigation is on to find out more details of the incident.  The missing crew member has been identified as Bandari Akbar Abu, said an official aware to the matter.  “The other seven crew members are now seeking refuge on board Al Madad. The distressed crew members were fortunate enough to be rescued by Al Madad, which happened to be nearby at the time of the accident,” the official added.     "https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/3-fishermen-missing-after-boat-capsizes-off-odisha-coast-5-rescued-101695141128800.html": "3 fishermen missing after boat capsizes off Odisha coast; 5 rescued | Latest News India - Hindustan Times\nExplore\nSearch\nThursday, Jan 30, 2025\nNew Delhi oC\nSubscribe\nGames\nE-Paper\nSign in\nMy Account\nStart 14 Days Free Trial\nSubscribe\nEnjoy unlimited access\nSubscribe Now! Get features like\nAd lite\nA Minimal Ad Experience\nHT Premium Articles\nExpertly crafted articles\nQuickreads Segment\nNews brief in summary format\nHT E-paper\nAccess digital news experience\nStart 14 Days Free Trial\nHome\nBudget 2025\nDelhi Election 2025\nGames\nHT Photo Contest\nHT Premium\nHoroscope 2025\nHTCity\nLong Weekend Planner 2025\nLoan ₹10 Lakh\nIndia\nWorld\nReal Estate\nPowered by\nEntertainment\nTrending\nAstrology\nLifestyle\nEducation\nBusiness\nCities\nLatest News\nMahakumbh 2025 LIVE\nSri Lanka Vs Australia LIVE\nBudget 2025 Expectations LIVE\nDeepSeek FAQs\nPhotos\nCentury of Leadership\nWeb Stories\nSports\nDelhi News\nMumbai News\nBengaluru News\nTechnology\nQuickreads\nDaily Digest\nFollowing\nGames\n+ 11 more\nCentury of Leadership\nWeb Stories\nSports\nDelhi News\nMumbai News\nBengaluru News\nTechnology\nQuickreads\nDaily Digest\nFollowing\nGames\n3 fishermen missing after boat capsizes off Odisha coast; 5 rescued    ByDebabrata Mohanty      Sep 19, 2023 10:02 PM IST        Read this news in brief form              Share Via         Copy Link           Jagatsinghpur SP Rahul PR said the eight fishermen had been fishing in the sea for the last two days and were returning when their vessel capsized after hitting a sand bar         Bhubaneswar: Three fishermen have gone missing after a fishing boat capsized in the sea near Paradip port on Tuesday.        Five fishermen were rescued by a joint team of Coast Guard, Marine Police, Paradip Port Authority, and CISF personnel. (Videograb/PTI)    Jagatsinghpur superintendent of police (SP) Rahul PR said eight fishermen were returning to the shore after fishing in the sea for the last two days when their trawler capsized after hitting a sand bar.   “After the trawler capsized, a rescue operation was launched by the Coast Guard, Marine Police, Paradip Port Authority, and CISF. Due to the timely intervention of CISF and the Port, five fishermen could be rescued,” said the SP. A chopper of the Indian Coast Guard was pressed into service. The police officer said three fishermen were missing and marine police officers were trying to ascertain if they were able to swim to safety. The boat owner Purendra Biswal said the fishermen had repeatedly asked the administration to carry out dredging at the mouth of the sea but this wasn’t done, lealeading to the incident.     "https://www.huffpost.com/entry/deadliest-catch-star-nick-mavar-dead-at-59_n_666dbff6e4b08d957ddf1691": "'Deadliest Catch' Star Nick Mavar Dead At 57 | HuffPost Entertainment\nSkip to Main Content×Main MenuU.S. EditionNewsU.S. NewsWorld NewsBusinessEnvironmentHealthSocial JusticeCrimePoliticsCongressExtremismOpinionEntertainmentCulture & ArtsMediaCelebrityTV & FilmBooksLifeStyle & BeautyFood & DrinkParentingTravelWellnessRelationshipsMoneyHome & LivingWork/LifeShoppingVoicesBlack VoicesQueer VoicesLatino VoicesIndigenous VoicesAsian VoicesWomen's VoicesHuffPost PersonalNEW: GamesHoroscopesVideoFrom Our PartnersMy 5-To-9NewslettersInternationalU.S.U.K.EspañaFranceΕλλάδα (Greece)Italia日本 (Japan)한국 (Korea)Follow UsTerms | Privacy PolicyPart of HuffPost Entertainment. ©2025 BuzzFeed, Inc. All rights reserved.×What's Hot\nLog InGo Ad-FreeNEWSPOLITICSENTERTAINMENTLIFEPERSONALVOICESSHOPPINGGAMESU.S. EditionOpen editions submenuEntertainment obituarydeadliest catch'Deadliest Catch' Star Nick Mavar, 59, Dies At Alaskan BoatyardThe longtime fisherman fell from a ladder Thursday while having a heart attack.By Marco MargaritoffTrends ReporterJun 15, 2024, 02:47 PM EDTLEAVE A COMMENTLOADINGERROR LOADINGNick Mavar, a longtime fisherman whose tenacious deckhand years were chronicled in the Discovery Channel reality series “Deadliest Catch,” died Thursday in Alaska, Bristol Bay Police Chief Jeffrey Eldie confirmed Friday to Deadline. He was 59 years old.His nephew Jake Anderson, who appeared with Mavar on the show and previously credited Mavar for helping him through substance abuse struggles, told The New York Times on Saturday that Mavar suffered a heart attack while on a ladder at a boatyard in Naknek, Alaska and fell onto a dry dock.Advertisement\nMavar was pronounced dead at a local hospital.“The passing of Nick Mavar spread through the fishing community like wild fire,” Sig Hansen, captain of the “Northwestern” ship featured on the show, shared Friday. “This is no surprise because of how well known and respected he was by the fishing fleet.”Mavar starred in 98 episodes across 17 seasons of “Deadliest Catch” and appeared in several of its popular spinoffs. He worked aboard the Northwestern and its equipment until 2020, when he left the show after his appendix ruptured while filming.Mavar sued Hansen last year for $1 million for failing to have an adequate plan for ship workers’ medical care, Alaska Public Media reported. Hansen reportedly argued in court last year that the show’s production company and medical provider were to blame for the ship’s COVID-19 protocols, which delayed Mavar’s care.Advertisement\nView this post on Instagram            A post shared by Nick Mavar (@mavarnick360) The fisherman was injured while filming an episode in 2011, when a storm loosened a large hook that hit Mavar in the face, and broke his nose. That incident, as well the appendix scare, were both documented on the show.His death comes nearly four years after 33-year-old “Deadliest Catch” deckhand Nick McGlashan died of a reported drug overdose — and days after Captain “Wild” Bill Wichrowski shared his prostate cancer diagnosis in a preview of the show’s current season.Advertisement\nMavar spent his final years golfing and captaining his own salmon boat in Bristol Bay. He is survived by his wife, father, two children from a previous marriage, a stepdaughter and three siblings. His nephew remembers him as “a fisherman through and through.”“[T]he camera was something that was just there,” Anderson told the Times.Related obituarydeadliest catchRussell Crowe Mocks 'Madame Web' Star For Her Disappointment With Comic Book MoviesRob Schneider Is Getting Roasted For Saying 'Asshole' Will Smith Should've Been ArrestedGoldie Hawn Says She And Kurt Russell Have Had 2 Home Invasions Since 2020 Go to HomepageLEAVE A COMMENTSuggest a correction|Submit a tipAdvertisement\nFrom Our Partner\nFrom Our Partner\nHuffPost Shopping'sBest FindsNewsletter Sign UpEntertainmentDon't miss a beat. Tours\nReykjavík City Tours\nSouth Coast Tours\nNature Baths\nNorthern Lights Tours\nIce Cave Tours\nWhale Watching Tours\nMulti-day\nPackages\nFood & Drink\nCar Rentals\nFlights\nAirport Transfer\nMade in Iceland\nSubscribe\nMy account\nNews, Society\nSearch Area Expanded as Missing Fisherman Still Not Found\nBy Ragnar Tómas\nPhoto: Icelandic Coast Guard/Facebook.\nDecember 6, 2022\nThe Coast Guard has expanded the search area in its effort to find a missing fisherman who fell overboard last Friday. A prayer service was held for the man in Grindavík on Sunday.\nMost extensive search effort in years\nThe search continues for a fisherman who fell overboard just outside Faxaflói Bay on Friday afternoon. The man, a Grindavík resident and father of three, was a fisherman on the longline fishing boat Sighvatur GK-57, which is owned and operated by the Grindavík-based fishing company Vísir hf. The police have interviewed the ship’s captain and have deemed the incident a “tragic accident,” Vísir reports.\nRead More: A Brief History of Iceland’s Maritime Safety and Survival Training Centre\nThe search effort is the most extensive of its kind in years, Guðmundur Birkir Agnarsson, Director of Operations with the Icelandic Coast Guard, told the hosts of the radio programme Morgunútvarpið yesterday morning. On Saturday, fifteen boats participated in the search – among them the patrol ship Þór – in addition to two helicopters.\nGiven how many days have passed since the man fell into the sea, the Coast Guard has expanded the search area from 10 x 10 nautical miles to 18 x 18 nautical miles. Ásgeir Erlendsson, Public Relations Officer for the Icelandic Coast Guard, told Mbl.is yesterday that search conditions have been relatively good, despite not having found the man.\nPrayer service in Grindavík\nA prayer service was held for the fisherman in Grindavík on Sunday. Fannar Jónsson, Mayor of Grindavík, told Vísir that the community was ‘deeply saddened’ and that all they could do was wait.\nAccording to Fannar, the prayer service was well attended, for an event such as this has an outsized effect on such a small community:\n“Yes, it’s very hard. You have a big family and friends … the crew, the company, and the sailor’s family, they’re all hurting. But there’s a solidarity and a unity among the community, whenever something like this happens.”\nCoast Guard, Fannar Jónsson, Faxaflói, fisherman, Grindavík, missing, search effort, Sighvatur GK-57, Vísir\nSign up for our weekly newsletter\nGet news from Iceland, photos, and in-depth stories delivered to your inbox every week!\nEmail\nSign up\nSubscribe to Iceland Review\nIn-depth stories and high-quality photography showcasing life in Iceland!\nSubscribe\nRelated News\nNews\nPtarmigan Take Over Grindavík\nNews\nFamous Cat Missing\nNature\nWater Cannons Used to Cool Lava Near Blue Lagoon, Infrastructure\nFrom the Travel Desk\nPartnerships\nRaise the anchor with Viggson Sailing in Iceland\nPlaces\nA Guide to Gullfoss: Iceland’s Most Iconic Waterfall\nPlaces\nThe Lava Tunnel in South Iceland\nLatest news\nIceland to Compete in First Semi-Final Night at Eurovision 2025Meteorologist Warns Of Weather Chaos This WeekendNBA Star Jeremy Pargo To Play For GrindavíkDrifting Boat Rescued Off Snæfellsnes PeninsulaSperm Whale Beaches on Northwest Shore\nIceland Review – Helping you discover since 1963\nNews\nMagazine\nAsk Iceland Review\nIn Focus\nTravel Tips & Info\nBook Tours\nNews\nMagazine\nAsk Iceland Review\nIn Focus\nTravel Tips & Info\nBook Tours\nAbout Us\nWork with Us\nPrivacy Policy\nOur History\nSign Up For Our Newsletter\nAbout Us\nWork with Us\nPrivacy Policy\nOur History\nSign Up For Our Newsletter\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYoutube\n© 2024 - Iceland Review ehf.     "https://www.icsf.net/newss/bangladesh-fisherman-shot-dead-by-pirates-in-coxs-bazar/?utm_source=mailpoet&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=South+Asia+News+Alerts": "Bangladesh: Fisherman shot dead by pirates in Cox’s Bazar – ICSF\nhttps:/icsf.net/news\nHomepageNewsICSF NewsSouth Asia News AlertBangladesh: Fisherman shot dead by pirates in Cox’s Bazar Bangladesh: Fisherman shot dead by pirates in Cox’s Bazar\nViews:523\nA group of armed pirates shot dead a fisherman in Sonadia Channel in the Bay of Bengal in Maheshkhali, Cox’s Bazar early Thursday (November 7).\nThe deceased was known as Mokarram, son of late Jafar Ahmed, hailed from Azim Uddin Sikderpara of Uttar Dhurung union in Kutubdia.\nAbdul Halim, chairman of the union parishad, said that Mokarram Majhi was shot by pirates in the western part of Sonadia while fishing in the sea. Several other fishermen are missing in this incident.\nQuoting fishermen, a local person named the fishermen went fishing at the Bay on the trawler late on Wednesday night. Armed pirates attacked the trawler. Mokarram was shot at that time. Banshkhali police station Officer-in-Charge (OC) Saiful Islam said on information, police recovered the body.\nURL:  https://www.risingbd.com/english/country/news/108295\nICSF\nInternational Collective  in Support of Fishworkers\nNews\nYemaya Newsletter\nSAMUDRA Report\nOUR WORK\nRight to Resources\nGender in Fisheries and Aquaculture\nDisasters and Climate Change\nDecent Work\nFisheries Trade\nAquaculture\nBiodiversity\nAbout ICSF\nSSF Guidelines\nICSF Campaigns\nResources\nICSF Archives\nSign-up for News Alerts\n×\nName*\nEmail*\nPlease tell us about your work  This helps us network better\nNature of Work\nCountry*\nAfghanistan\nAfghanisthan\nAfrica\nAlaska\nAlbania\nAlgeria\nAmerica\nAmerican Samoa\nAndaman and Nicobar Islands/India\nAndaman Nicobar Islands/India\nAndhra Pradesh\nAndhra Pradesh/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Odisha/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Tamil Nadu/Puducherry\nAngola\nAnguilla\nAntarctica\nAntigua and Barbuda\nArctic Ocean\nArgentina\nArunachal Pradesh/India\nASEAN\nAsia\nAssam/India\nAustralia\nAustralia.     "https://www.icsf.net/newss/bangladesh-fishermen-in-deepening-misery/?utm_source=mailpoet&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=South+Asia+News+Alerts": "Bangladesh: Fishermen in deepening misery – ICSF\nhttps:/icsf.net/news\nHomepageNewsICSF NewsSouth Asia News AlertBangladesh: Fishermen in deepening misery Bangladesh: Fishermen in deepening misery\nViews:365\nFishermen of the country are a community time forgot. They are among the poorest of this poor country. They are also engaged in one of the most hazardous occupations. It is they who brace themselves for the deadliest storms and tidal bores and as a result hundreds die every year in the Bay or in the turbulent Padma while catching fish.\nBrief news items routinely report a large number of fishermen as missing and there is hardly any follow-up story on their ultimate fate. Another menace they have to live with is attack and looting by Myanmar pirates as well as their Navy. On Wednesday, a fisherman was killed and two others received gunshot wounds after Myanmar Navy chased and opened fire at six Bangladeshi fishing trawlers near Saint Martin’s Island in the Bay of Bengal.\nThe government fails to take up the matter with the Myanmar government. As if fishermen’s lives are the most expendable in the country. This indifference would be more inexcusable when set against their massive contribution to the life and economy of the country. According to the fisheries department, there are an estimated 1.8-million registered fishermen in Bangladesh. They are mostly self-employed or employed by some other fishermen.\nSixty-seven per cent of the people’s animal protein intake, 2.43 per cent of national GDP and 22.14 per cent of the agricultural GDP and 1.05 per cent of foreign exchange earnings come from the fishery sector. And the credit for the sector’s significant contribution to economy primarily goes to the fishermen. But the politics of change or economics of change pass them by. One does not even hear of the NGOs taking up any programme for development of this luckless lot. Moreover, due to their economic vulnerability, many in society tend to look down upon them.\nThey rarely receive the same recognition as farmers and other rural communities. Apparently, their connection with those in power is too weak to advocate for their needs effectively. Annually, the fishermen face a 147-day fishing ban, which includes a 22-day ban on catching hilsa in October, a 60-day ban on catching jatka (hilsa fry) during March and April, and a 65-day ban from May 20 to July 23.\nThese bans are essential for the breeding and conservation of marine life and ensuring sustainable fisheries. In the meantime, how do the fishermen survive and feed their families? When these restrictions are enforced, the fishing community is pushed to the brink of survival, as the government-provided food assistance during these periods is inadequate.\nAs a 22-day ban on catching Hilsa began from Saturday (October 12) midnight, fishermen in the coastal region once again are voicing concern about their impending economic hardship. There is a call for increased food assistance and cash aid during the ban, access to life-saving equipment, deep-sea weather signal broadcasting, and loans on easy term, just to weather the storm. Against this bleak backdrop, the government’s plan to introduce insurance coverage for fishermen is a welcome development.\nThe Financial Institutions Division (FID) has been tasked with developing a project to implement the insurance scheme through the state-run Jiban Bima Corporation (JBC). If effectively implemented, this coverage would provide a vital safety net for fishermen and their families in cases of accidents, illness, or death.\nWithout such protection, these families are left financially vulnerable when disaster strikes, sinking them further into poverty. Offering insurance would also help mitigate the long-term economic hardship of the fishing communities entirely dependent on fishing for survival. As a fish-loving nation it is essential that fishermen are given every consideration and protection.\nURL:  https://thefinancialexpress.com.bd/views/opinions/fishermen-in-deepening-misery\nICSF\nInternational Collective  in Support of Fishworkers\nNews\nYemaya Newsletter\nSAMUDRA Report\nOUR WORK\nRight to Resources\nGender in Fisheries and Aquaculture\nDisasters and Climate Change\nDecent Work\nFisheries Trade\nAquaculture\nBiodiversity\nAbout ICSF\nSSF Guidelines\nICSF Campaigns\nResources\nICSF Archives\nSign-up for News Alerts\n×\nName*\nEmail*\nPlease tell us about your work  This helps us network better\nNature of Work\nCountry*\nAfghanistan\nAfghanisthan\nAfrica\nAlaska\nAlbania\nAlgeria\nAmerica\nAmerican Samoa\nAndaman and Nicobar Islands/India\nAndaman Nicobar Islands/India\nAndhra Pradesh\nAndhra Pradesh/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Odisha/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Tamil Nadu/Puducherry\nAngola\nAnguilla\nAntarctica\nAntigua and Barbuda\nArctic Ocean\nArgentina\nArunachal Pradesh/India\nASEAN\nAsia\nAssam/India\nAustralia\nAustralia.     "https://www.icsf.net/newss/bangladesh-myanmars-arakan-army-abducts-20-fishermen-from-naf-river/?utm_source=mailpoet&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=South+Asia+News+Alerts": "Bangladesh: Myanmar’s Arakan Army abducts 20 fishermen from Naf river – ICSF\nhttps:/icsf.net/news\nHomepageNewsICSF NewsSouth Asia News AlertBangladesh: Myanmar’s Arakan Army abducts 20 fishermen from Naf river Bangladesh: Myanmar’s Arakan Army abducts 20 fishermen from Naf river\nViews:261\nTwenty fishermen have been abducted from the Naf river in Teknaf of Cox’s Bazar by the Arakan Army, a rebel group in the Rakhine State of Myanmar, said Teknaf UNO. The incident took place between 3:30-4:00pm yesterday at Naikhyongdia point, an estuary of Naf river of Teknaf, confirmed Adnan Chowdhury, Teknaf upazila nirbahi officer.\nHe said a group of armed Arakan Army men detained 20 fishermen from 15 boats. According to the latest information, the fishermen along with the boats were kept on the Fatunia (Pa Nyaung) canal adjacent to the Naf river, he added.\nThe fishermen were fishing in Myanmar waters when they were abducted, Adnan said. The names of the arrested fishermen are not yet known, he said, adding that Border Guard Bangladesh are trying to rescue them.\nMaungdaw township and a large part of Rakhine State opposite to the Bangladesh border have been captured by the Arakan Army in recent months after fierce fighting with the Myanmar troops. Fighting is still ongoing between the two forces across the border.\nOn October 9, Myanmar Navy captured 58 fishermen on six trawlers from the Bangladesh part of the Bay of Bengal between St Martin’s Island and Myanmar.\nAmong them, one person was killed and two others were injured by Myanmar Navy firing. Later on, October 10, Myanmar Navy returned the fishermen in two phrases along with the body of the deceased.\nBesides, the Arakan Army has abducted several Bangladeshi nationals including fishermen on several occasions. The Bangladeshis were returned at BGB’s initiative.\nURL: https://asianews.network/myanmars-arakan-army-abducts-20-bangladeshi-fishermen-from-naf-river/\nICSF\nInternational Collective  in Support of Fishworkers\nNews\nYemaya Newsletter\nSAMUDRA Report\nOUR WORK\nRight to Resources\nGender in Fisheries and Aquaculture\nDisasters and Climate Change\nDecent Work\nFisheries Trade\nAquaculture\nBiodiversity\nAbout ICSF\nSSF Guidelines\nICSF Campaigns\nResources\nICSF Archives\nSign-up for News Alerts\n×\nName*\nEmail*\nPlease tell us about your work  This helps us network better\nNature of Work\nCountry*\nAfghanistan\nAfghanisthan\nAfrica\nAlaska\nAlbania\nAlgeria\nAmerica\nAmerican Samoa\nAndaman and Nicobar Islands/India\nAndaman Nicobar Islands/India\nAndhra Pradesh\nAndhra Pradesh/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Odisha/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Tamil Nadu/Puducherry\nAngola\nAnguilla\nAntarctica\nAntigua and Barbuda\nArctic Ocean\nArgentina\nArunachal Pradesh/India\nASEAN\nAsia\nAssam/India\nAustralia\nAustralia.     "https://www.icsf.net/newss/bangladesh-safety-of-fishermen-in-the-bay-of-bengal/?utm_source=mailpoet&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=South+Asia+News+Alerts": "Bangladesh: Safety of fishermen in the Bay of Bengal – ICSF\nhttps:/icsf.net/news\nHomepageNewsICSF NewsSouth Asia News AlertBangladesh: Safety of fishermen in the Bay of Bengal Bangladesh: Safety of fishermen in the Bay of Bengal\nViews:567\nAlong Bangladesh’s 710 kilometre coastline, several million people from the 14 coastal districts and 49 Upazilas are estimated to depend directly or indirectly on marine fishing for their livelihood– either for the whole or part of the year. The government’s Marine Fisheries Department states that Bangladesh is now the fifth largest marine fishing country in the world in terms of tonnage caught. However, commercial marine fishing is considered to be one of the most hazardous occupations worldwide. Is anything known about the health and safety status of the fishermen of the Bay of Bengal? How many of the fishermen get killed or maimed on the job while supplying fish protein for the country’s people?\nEvent #1: December 7, 2021– Due to the rough weather, a trawler carrying 21 fishermen capsized in the Bay of Bengal near Barguna’s Patharghata area, and 20 fishermen went missing.\nEvent #2: March 28, 2022– Indian Coast Guard rescued 19 fishermen who were deserted in Indian waters in the Bay of Bengal. The Bangladeshi fishermen, who started from Cox’s Bazar were marooned as their wooden trawler developed a mechanical problem. The trawler had been floating for more than 20 days. The exhausted fishermen had nothing to eat. They were provided with first aid, food, and water by the Indian Coast Guard.\nEvent #3: February 6, 2022– A total of 144 fishermen were rescued after the drowning of 11 trawlers in the Bay of Bengal. The bodies of the two dead were handed over to their families. They were rescued from Pathorghata in Barguna by the Fishermen’s Trawler Owners’ Association and the Dublarchor Fisherman Group.\nEvent #4: November 29, 2021– Bangladesh Navy rescued 14 fishermen alive from a fishing boat that had been floating for eight days in the Bay of Bengal, 140 km away from Cox’s Bazar.\nEvent #5: March 28, 2022– Some seven fishing trawlers went missing in the Bay of Bengal due to rough weather. At least seven fishermen were considered missing, according to the Bangladesh Coast Guard. The trawlers disappeared in the Bhashanchar route after starting from Banshkhali Upazila of Chattogram.\nAround 17 million people (with about 1.5 million women) are engaged in fishing, fish farming, fish handling, and processing for their livelihood in Bangladesh. The fisheries sector contributes 4 per cent to the GDP while the agricultural sector contributes around 15 per cent to the GDP. Around 4.5 million tonnes of fish were harvested in 2017-18, of which 655,000 tonnes came from the Bay of Bengal, almost 16 per cent of the total production. Bangladesh earned taka 4,310 crores from exporting almost 70.95 thousand tonnes of fish, shrimp, and other fisheries or fishery products during 2019-20 and this is 1.40 per cent of the total national export earnings. The country has seen a rise in fish capture, fish culture, and marine fish production, and in terms of distribution, inland capture accounts for 28 per cent,  inland culture 57 per cent, while the rest is marine capture.\nIt is difficult to count how many people rely exclusively on fisheries or related activities in Bangladesh but a great portion is involved in subsistence fisheries on its flood plains. Fisheries and related activities support more than 7 per cent of the country’s population. The number of fishermen increases dramatically between June to October each year because of the seasonal patterns of fish harvesting. In terms of marine fishing, at present, there are 255 registered trawlers out of which 236 are used for fishing only. Of those, around 35 are shrimp trawlers, 52 bottom trawlers, 68 midwater transformed trawlers, 53 midwater trawlers, and 28 trial trip bottom trawlers. In addition, there are 67,669 mechanised and non-mechanized boats that are engaged in fishing. Currently, more than 600,000 people are engaged in shrimp farming activities alone.\nSeveral studies conducted in the United States (US) confirmed that commercial fishing is still one of the most dangerous occupations. During 1992-2008, an average of 58 reported deaths occurred (128 deaths per 100,000 workers) annually among commercial fishermen, compared with 5,894 deaths (four per 100,000 workers) in all other sectors in the US. To assess the hazards and risk factors, US CDC collected and analysed fatality data during 2000-2009: out of 504 fatalities, most (52 per cent) occurred following a vessel disaster (e.g., sinking, capsizing, or other events when the crew had to abandon ship) or a fall overboard (31 per cent).\nSome risk factors and causes identified for marine fishing by research studies include– 1) fishing vessels often manned by fewer individuals, 2) working with heavy-duty equipment, 3) working in unsafe environments, 4) working for very long hours, 5) economic pressures forcing inappropriately geared vessels to operate, 6) vessels not fit, not allowed or not safe going further out in sea than permitted. Deaths among the marine fishermen resulted from a wide variety of situations involving 1) vessel loss, 2) falls overboard, 3) fire and explosions, 4) cable entanglements, and 5) gas exposure. In many cases, the real causes or circumstances remained unknown as autopsies are difficult for drowning or hypothermia cases and decomposition and animal predation of the dead bodies made the investigation obscured.\nThings must be much worse in Bangladesh for its commercial marine fishermen. Research findings will help with the development of effective prevention measures and practices through the delivery of appropriate safety awareness training. Studying the marine fishermen is important to characterise potential influences on or barriers to safety to design interventions that can alter safety practices and behaviours. The Bangladesh Coast Guard (USCG) can conduct periodic surveys on fishing hazards.\nAll training programmes must target increasing the awareness among fishermen about the severe occupational risks inherent in their work. Fishing community trust and collaborative partnerships are essential to the success of such initiatives. Simple, yet appropriate training and awareness measures must incorporate visual and written safety messages that can favourably influence attitudes, beliefs, and behavioural intent related to high priority risk factors as identified by fishermen. Opportunities exist and strategies are needed for improving the safety of fishermen in the Bay of Bengal.\nURL: https://thefinancialexpress.com.bd/views/safety-of-fishermen-in-the-bay-of-bengal-1649258919\nICSF\nInternational Collective  in Support of Fishworkers\nNews\nYemaya Newsletter\nSAMUDRA Report\nOUR WORK\nRight to Resources\nGender in Fisheries and Aquaculture\nDisasters and Climate Change\nDecent Work\nFisheries Trade\nAquaculture\nBiodiversity\nAbout ICSF\nSSF Guidelines\nICSF Campaigns\nResources\nICSF Archives\nSign-up for News Alerts\n×\nName*\nEmail*\nPlease tell us about your work  This helps us network better\nNature of Work\nCountry*\nAfghanistan\nAfghanisthan\nAfrica\nAlaska\nAlbania\nAlgeria\nAmerica\nAmerican Samoa\nAndaman and Nicobar Islands/India\nAndaman Nicobar Islands/India\nAndhra Pradesh\nAndhra Pradesh/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Odisha/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Tamil Nadu/Puducherry\nAngola\nAnguilla\nAntarctica\nAntigua and Barbuda\nArctic Ocean\nArgentina\nArunachal Pradesh/India\nASEAN\nAsia\nAssam/India\nAustralia\nAustralia. (Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka)\nICSF Publications and Films Alerts (Quarterly)",
    "https://www.icsf.net/newss/gujarat-26-indian-fishermen-died-in-pakistan-custody-in-last-10-years/?utm_source=mailpoet&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=South+Asia+News+Alerts": "Gujarat: 26 Indian fishermen died in Pakistan custody in last 10 years – ICSF\nhttps:/icsf.net/news\nHomepageNewsICSF NewsSouth Asia News AlertGujarat: 26 Indian fishermen died in Pakistan custody in last 10 years Gujarat: 26 Indian fishermen died in Pakistan custody in last 10 years\nViews:292\nAt least 26 Indian fishermen have died in Pakistan custody in 10 years after being apprehended for allegedly violating the country’s territorial waters, the Indian government has confirmed even as the family of a Gujarat fisherman who died in Pakistan jail around a month ago is still waiting for his mortal remains. In reply to an application filed under the Right to Information (RTI) Act, 2005, the Indian High Commission in Islamabad has said that a total 24 Indian fishermen died in Pakistan jails between January 2014 and December 2023.\nThe RTI application was filed by a Mumbai-based journalist and peace activist, Jatin Desai, who has been working for the welfare of fishermen. Desai, who has also served as general secretary of the Indian chapter of the India-Pakistan People’s Forum for Peace and Democracy (PIPFPD), said with two more deaths this year, so far 26 fishermen have died in about 10 years.\n“On March 17 this year, Vinod Laxman Kol, a fisherman from Maharashtra’s Palghar died in a Pakistan jail and his mortal remains were handed over to his family members only on May 1. Suresh Nathu Solanki, a fisherman hailing from Gir Somnath district of Gujarat died in a Pakistan jail on September 5,” Desai told The Indian Express. The activist had also sought names of fishermen who died in Pakistan jails, date of their deaths and date on which their mortal remains were repatriated to India. However, the high commissioner declined to share that information. “Information sought is exempt under Section 8(1)(j) of the RTI Act 2005,” Dinesh Singh Rawat, second secretary and Central Public Information Officer (CPIO) in the Indian High Commission in Islamabad, stated in his reply dated September 26. Section 8(1)(j) of RTI Act provides for exemption from disclosure of information which “relates to personal information the disclosure of which has no relationship to any public activity or interest, or which would cause unwarranted invasion of the privacy of the individual unless the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer or the appellate authority, as the case may be, is satisfied that the larger public interest justifies the disclosure of such information.”\nAdvertisement\nIndia and Pakistan have disputes over the alignment of the notional International Maritime Boundary Line (IMBL) at the Arabian Sea off Kutch coast in Gujarat. Therefore, Pakistan Marine Security Agency (PMSA) apprehends a few hundred fishermen every year for allegedly crossing over to the Pakistan side of the IMBL. Similarly, every year, a few dozen Pakistani fishermen are arrested by the Indian authorities for allegedly violating territorial waters of India. Of late, it has been observed that it takes many weeks for mortal remains of fishermen to be repatriated from Pakistan. “In the case of the Gujarat fisherman who died in September, his nationality had already been verified. Yet his body has not been handed over to his family members a month after his death. This is a violation of human rights,” said Desai.\nA senior fisheries officer in state government said: “The fisherman’s family reached out to us a few days ago, seeking information about his reported death in Pakistan jail. However, we have received no formal communication from the government of India.”\nURL: https://indianexpress.com/article/cities/ahmedabad/26-indian-fishermen-died-in-pak-custody-in-last-10-years-rti-9604420/\nICSF\nInternational Collective  in Support of Fishworkers\nNews\nYemaya Newsletter\nSAMUDRA Report\nOUR WORK\nRight to Resources\nGender in Fisheries and Aquaculture\nDisasters and Climate Change\nDecent Work\nFisheries Trade\nAquaculture\nBiodiversity\nAbout ICSF\nSSF Guidelines\nICSF Campaigns\nResources\nICSF Archives\nSign-up for News Alerts\n×\nName*\nEmail*\nPlease tell us about your work  This helps us network better\nNature of Work\nCountry*\nAfghanistan\nAfghanisthan\nAfrica\nAlaska\nAlbania\nAlgeria\nAmerica\nAmerican Samoa\nAndaman and Nicobar Islands/India\nAndaman Nicobar Islands/India\nAndhra Pradesh\nAndhra Pradesh/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Odisha/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Tamil Nadu/Puducherry\nAngola\nAnguilla\nAntarctica\nAntigua and Barbuda\nArctic Ocean\nArgentina\nArunachal Pradesh/India\nASEAN\nAsia\nAssam/India\nAustralia\nAustralia.     "https://www.icsf.net/newss/myanmar-fishermen-suffering-from-diarrhoea-off-ye-township-coast/?utm_source=mailpoet&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=South+Asia+News+Alerts": "Myanmar: Fishermen suffering from Diarrhoea off Ye Township coast – ICSF\nhttps:/icsf.net/news\nHomepageNewsICSF NewsSouth Asia News AlertMyanmar: Fishermen suffering from Diarrhoea off Ye Township coast Myanmar: Fishermen suffering from Diarrhoea off Ye Township coast\nViews:178\nCases of diarrhoea are spreading amongst fishermen working on fishing boats and their attached rafts, operating offshore of Ahsin Village in Ye Township, Mon State.\nIn the last week of September, two fishermen contracted diarrhoea whilst at sea. The disease spread around the boat and its attached rafts and by 11 October 40 fishermen were suffering from diarrhoea.\nThe boat docked at Ahsin Village and  those suffering from severe symptoms were taken for further treatment to Ye Township People’s Hospital, where they are being monitored and treated under quarantine.\nFor some of those suffering from diarrhoea the symptoms seem to clear up before recurring a few days later. So far, the only cases were contracted whilst the sufferers were at sea and there has been no transmission of diarrhoea reported in Ahsin Village.\nAlso, in the last week of September, a fisherman who docked in Ahsin Village died from diarrhoea. The use of seawater for washing and toilets; and eating improperly cleaned or cooked seafood like sea snails and fish, may have contributed to the spread of diarrhoea amongst the fishermen, according to locals.\nIn mid-September an outbreak of diarrhoea amongst fishermen in the waters off the coast of Kyaikkhami Town in Thanbyuzayat Township, Mon State, killed six fishermen and infected about another 150.\nURL: https://www.bnionline.net/en/news/fishermen-suffering-diarrhoea-ye-township-coast\nICSF\nInternational Collective  in Support of Fishworkers\nNews\nYemaya Newsletter\nSAMUDRA Report\nOUR WORK\nRight to Resources\nGender in Fisheries and Aquaculture\nDisasters and Climate Change\nDecent Work\nFisheries Trade\nAquaculture\nBiodiversity\nAbout ICSF\nSSF Guidelines\nICSF Campaigns\nResources\nICSF Archives\nSign-up for News Alerts\n×\nName*\nEmail*\nPlease tell us about your work  This helps us network better\nNature of Work\nCountry*\nAfghanistan\nAfghanisthan\nAfrica\nAlaska\nAlbania\nAlgeria\nAmerica\nAmerican Samoa\nAndaman and Nicobar Islands/India\nAndaman Nicobar Islands/India\nAndhra Pradesh\nAndhra Pradesh/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Odisha/India\nAndhra Pradesh/Tamil Nadu/Puducherry\nAngola\nAnguilla\nAntarctica\nAntigua and Barbuda\nArctic Ocean\nArgentina\nArunachal Pradesh/India\nASEAN\nAsia\nAssam/India\nAustralia\nAustralia.     "https://www.independent.co.ug/fpu-three-fishermen-die-trying-to-escape-arrest-on-lake-albert/": "FPU: Three fishermen die trying to escape arrest on Lake Albert\nThursday , January 30 2025\nThe Independent Uganda: You get the Truth we Pay the Price\nHOME\nNEWS\nTHE NEWS TODAY\nNEWS ANALYSIS\nCOVID-19 UPDATES\nAFRICA\nWORLD\nRWANDA ED\nTECH NEWS\nENTERTAINMENT\nARTICLES 2008-2015\nTHE LAST WORD\nIN THE MAGAZINE\nCOLUMNISTS\nAndrew Mwenda\nConversations with Dr. Kizza Besigye\nCharles Onyango Obbo\nDerek Nseko\nAlfred Geresom Musamali\nLydia Mirembe\nSamson Tinka\nJackson Oboth\nOlivia Nalubwama\nDavid Birungi\nGünter Zittel\nJohn K Wasikye\nSarah M. Chelangat\nIsaac Teko\nOTHERS\nDominic Muwanguzi\nDavid Birungi\nDr Geoffrey Onegi Obel\nFrederick Golooba Muteebi\nJenkins Kiwanuka\nPro. Morris Ogenga Latigo\nMwambustya Ndebesa\nBob A Kasango\nDavid Chandi Jamwa\nMorrison Rwakakamba\nKavuma Kaggwa\nJoseph E Stiglitz\nCOMMENT\nBUSINESS\nHEALTH\nTOURISM\nSPORTS\nJOBS\nLatest News\n20 killed in plane crash in South Sudan\nMuseveni says ready to step in to end DR Congo chaos\nPOWERBALL jackpot of UGX 1.1 billion is up for grabs!\nEcobank launches ‘KIGGALE ne Ecobank’ campaign to help clients reach 2025 goals\nThe Fed is running scared of Trump\nUPDF rules out DRC pull out\nAKOPE: Pearl Of Africa series is dream come true for Ugandan golf professionals\nUN evacuates staff to Uganda following conflict in eastern DR Congo\nUganda Airlines suspends flights to Kinshasa after violent protests\nCongo fighting raises risk of virus leaks\nHome / NEWS / FPU: Three fishermen die trying to escape arrest on Lake Albert\nFPU: Three fishermen die trying to escape arrest on Lake Albert\nThe Independent\nNovember 10, 2023\nNEWS\nLeave a comment\nLake Albert\nKampala, Uganda | THE INDEPENDENT | Three fishermen are reported to have died after jumping into Lake Albert to avoid being arrested by Fisheries Protection Unit-FPU personnel.\nOn Wednesday, four fishermen Richard Onen 25, Samson Jatho 35, Godfrey Obedirwoth 28, and Muzamil Jakisa all attached to Mbegu B landing site in Kabale sub county went fishing.  While on the lake, they were arrested by the fisheries protection unit-FPU personnel who were patrolling the lake and accused them of using illegal fishing gear.\nThe FPU personnel who were being commanded by Corporal Siraj Katosi decided to take the suspects to their detach at the Kasio landing site. However, while on the lake, all the suspects reportedely jumped into the Lake Albert waters fearing to be detained.\nJakisa managed to swim up to the shores, FPU said, while the rest of his colleagues are reported to have drowned.\nMoses Onen, the LCI Chairperson for Mbegu B landing site said that after a search was conducted on the lake by local fishermen, the body of Onen was found floating on the lake near Mbegu landing site on Thursday while the two bodies are still missing.\nJulius Hakiza, the Albertine Region Police spokesperson says that the marine police and fishermen have teamed up to search for the two remaining missing bodies.\nAccording to Hakiza, they have started investigating the actions of the FPU operatives.\nIn November 2021, a fisherman died in Lake Albert in Hoima district after seeing an approaching crew of Fisheries Protection Unit -FPU personnel.   The deceased was only identified as Owonda, attached to Kijangi landing site in Tonya parish Buseruka sub-county in Hoima district.\nOn the fateful day, the deceased together with three other fishermen whose names were not established had gone fishing when they saw the FPU operatives who accused them of using illegal fishing gear.\nAfter seeing the FPU operatives challenging them, Owonda jumped into the lake and died on the spot.\nIn 2017, President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni directed Uganda Peoples Defense Forces-UPDF soldiers to deploy on all the lakes in the country to combat illegal fishing practices to protect the fish resources that were under threat of depletion.\nHowever, the Fisheries Protection Unit-FPU has since been under the spotlight for torturing and extorting money from fishermen.\nThe fishermen claim that instead of prosecuting them in courts of law, the soldiers have resorted to battering them in front of their family members and friends, which deprives them of their dignity but the FPU has always denied the allegations leveled against them by the fishermen.\n****\nURN\nShare on: WhatsApp\nfishermen FPU Lake Albert 2023-11-10\nThe Independent\nShare\nFacebook\nTwitter\nGoogle +\nLinkedIn\nTags fishermen FPU Lake Albert\nLoading...\nRelated with EC over voter update exercise\nJanuary 29, 2025\nLeave a Reply Cancel reply\nYour email address will not be published.     "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/indians-abroad/story/another-fisherman-dies-in-pak-jail-third-death-in-a-th-2386174-2023-05-29#": "Another Indian fisherman dies in Pak jail, third death in a month - India Today India TodayAaj TakGNTTVLallantopBusiness TodayBanglaMalayalamNortheastBT BazaarHarper's BazaarSports TakCrime TakAstro TakGamingBrides TodayCosmopolitanKisan TakIshq FMIndia Today HindiReader’s DigestIndia TodayAaj TakGNTTVLallantopBusiness TodayBanglaMalayalamNortheastBT BazaarHarper's BazaarSports TakMagazineLive TVSearchSEARCHSIGN INEdition ININUSHome TVLive TVPrimetimeElectionsDelhiMaharashtraJharkhandMagazineLatest EditionInsightBest CollegesLife+StyleIndiaSouthGlobalAll World NewsUS NewsCanada NewsUK NewsChina NewsIndians AbroadBusinessAll SportsSports TodayCricketFootballTennisTechnologyEntertainmentShowbuzzBollywoodHollywoodOTTLatest ReviewsNewspresso SpecialsPodcastsFirst Things FastSunday SpecialHistory of ItNewsMoDIUInteractivesOpinionGamesVideosShort VideosFact Check Other NewsEducationIt's ViralScienceHealthAutoLaw TodayEnvironmentCitiesWeatherWeb StoriesHoroscopesDownload AppFollow Us On:   NewsWorldIndians AbroadAnother Indian fisherman dies in Pak jail, third death in a monthAnother Indian fisherman dies in Pak jail, third death in a monthPakistan continues to illegally detain more than 400 Indian prisoners in its jails even after the prisoners have completed their sentences, sources said.Listen to StoryLive TVShareAdvertisementSeveral fishermen continue to be in Pak jails despite their sentences being over (Representational)Geeta MohanNew Delhi,UPDATED: May 29, 2023 23:41 ISTAn Indian fisherman serving his time in Pakistan's jail died on Sunday. He is the third Indian fisherman to die in Pak custody in a month and fourth in two months. The other Indian fishermen who have died in the last two months are Bichan Kumar alias Vipan Kumar (died on April 4), Zulfiqar (died on May 6), and Soma Deva (died on May 8).advertisementThree other Indian fisherman are in serious condition in Pakistan, sources said.What is unfortunate is that Jetha had already completed his sentence and, according to sources, Pakistan continues to illegally detain more than 400 Indian prisoners in its jails even after the prisoners have completed their sentences.Also Read | Never saw Sahil, we demand justice: Mother of minor girl stabbed to death in DelhiSenior journalist Jatin Desai, who has been following the story of fishermen on both sides of the border, told India Today TV, “It's a sad state of affairs. The family members of Indian fishermen who are in Pakistan's custody are worried. In the absence of communication, they are always worried about their near and dear ones who are in Pakistan's jails.”“India and Pakistan must allow a team of doctors to visit the other country to check on their own prisoners. It will also give some confidence to the family members,” Desai added.advertisementAlso Read | Delhi killer Sahil's last Instagram post featured hookah party, Sidhu Moose Wala song“It's just terrible. Even after the completion of sentence and the confirmation of nationality, keeping them in jails is a violation of the Agreement on Consular Access, 2008. It must be implemented in letter and spirit,” Desai said.According to Section 5 of the Agreement on Consular Access, 2008, “Both governments agree to release and repatriate persons within one month of confirmation of their national status and completion of sentences.”Also Read | Dangal on Delhi streets: Wrestlers detained, Jantar Mantar cleared out, and a vow to return | A recapPublished By: Sahil     "https://www.inewsguyana.com/decomposed-body-of-missing-fisherman-found-along-corentyne-foreshore/": "Decomposed body of missing fisherman found along Corentyne foreshore - INews Guyana\nHome\nNews\nLocal News\nRegional News\nWorld News\nPolitics\nCrime\nCourt\nBusiness\nMining\nHealth\nThe Piper\nOpinion\nLetters\nSports\nContact us\nSearch\n24\nC\nGeorgetown, Guyana\nWednesday, January 29, 2025\nHome\nEntertainment\nEnvironment\nAdvertise\nContact\nSign in\nWelcome! Log into your account\nyour username\nyour password\nForgot your password? Get help\nPassword recovery\nRecover your password\nyour email\nA password will be e-mailed to you.\nINews Guyana\nHome\nNews\nLocal News\nRegional News\nWorld News\nPolitics\nCrime\nCourt\nBusiness\nMining\nHealth\nThe Piper\nOpinion\nLetters\nSports\nContact us\nHome  latest news  Decomposed body of missing fisherman found along Corentyne foreshore\nlatest newsLocal News\nDecomposed body of missing fisherman found along Corentyne foreshore\nNovember 18, 2023 0\nDead: Mahindranouth Jaipaul\nThe badly decomposed body of missing fisherman, Mahindranouth Jaipaul, 56, Mon Repos North, East Coast Demerara (ECD), was found on Friday along the Eversham foreshore Corentyn, Berbice.\nThe man went missing after the boat in which he and his crew were fishing, reportedly sank last Sunday.\nJaipaul along with his crewmates left their Mon Repos homes on Wednesday and headed out to sea, aboard a fishing vessel with licence number SK 1798.\nAccording to the boat’s owner, Totaram Ramdharry, of Number 65 Village, Corentyne, the boat captain, who goes by the name “Joe” of Mon Repos had been working on one of his boats since May of this year.\nHe said at about 03:00h on Sunday, he received a telephone call informing him that the boat was taking in water after the outboard engine had stopped working.\nAccording to the fisherman/businessman, he advised his workmen to see how best they could deal with the issue and even recommended getting rid of the seine to ease the weight of the boat.\nMeantime, efforts were made to find a boat in the area to rescue the crew but before they could find one, the vessel went down. The incident occurred on the Corentyne River just off Port Nickerie in the Dutch-speaking territory.\nThree members of the crew reportedly used the icebox to float. However, Jaipaul was not with them, as he reportedly disappeared during the dark hours in the rough waters.\nDuring a search, the $11 million boat was discovered but it was completely wrecked. “We can’t do nothing, I tell them search for the man because that is material things so fishing work a go, we na get insurance or nothing,” Ramdharry said.\nMeanwhile, on Friday, the man’s body washed ashore. It was positively identified by the now-dead man’s brother. He said the black short pants, a red T-shirt, and also a cut on his chest allowed him to do so.\n“Well everybody feel please because we thought we would have never found him. Because in them situation that you don’t find them back. So, everybody feel please so that we can do the last rites,” the brother told this publication. Jaipaul had been a fisherman for the past 17 years.\nA post-mortem examination is expected to be conducted on Monday.\n---\nShare this:Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)\nRelated\nSHARE\nFacebook\nTwitter\ntweet  Previous articleCarbon credit fund: Transparency is not being compromised – VP assures diplomatic communityNext articleDiplomacy is our first line of defence but GDF must be vigilant at borders – PM Phillips INEWS\nRELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR\nCrime\nMother of 7 brutally murdered months after leaving abusive relationship\nlatest news\nGECOM urges registrants to uplift ID cards\nlatest news\nJapanese firm identified to inspect used vehicles before import into Guyana\nRecent Articles\nMother of 7 brutally murdered months after leaving abusive relationship\nCrime INEWS -     "https://www.jagonews24.com/en/national/news/66910": "Fisherman who was injured in tiger attack dies\nDhaka, Thursday, 30th January 2025\nToggle navigation\nNational\nPolitics\nBiz-Econ\nInternational\nSports\nEntertainment\nEducation\nFeature\nSci-Tech\nArchive\nবাংলা\nNational\nFisherman who was injured in tiger attack dies\nUpazila Correspondent Mongla, Bagerhat\nPublished: 18 February 2023, 05:24 PM\nA fisherman, who was injured by a tiger in the Sundarbans in Bagerhat, died at Dhaka Medical College Hospital on Friday night.\nDeceased Anukul Gain, 30, was the son of late Mukunda Gain, a resident of Amurbunia village in Morrelganj upazila of Bagerhat.\nMd Shahjahan, an official at Ziudhara station (Mongla) under Sundarban East Forest Division, Bagerhat confirmed the matter.\nEarlier on January 27, a tiger attacked Anukul when he went to Sudirerchila canal to catch fish, leaving him injured.\nHe was first taken to Morrelganj Upazila Health Complex and then, to Khulna Medical College Hospital.\nOn the same day, he was sent to Dhaka Medical College Hospital for better treatment where he passed away yesterday while undergoing treatment.\nAbu Hossain Sumon/SU\nEntertainment\nLifestyle\n1\nPori Moni surrenders, gets bail\n2\nWon’t work in this country again, says an angry Pori Moni\n3\nPori Moni faces arrest warrant\n4\nIranian pop singer Tataloo sentenced to death for blasphemy\n5\nMan who stabbed Saif Ali Khan arrested after over 70 hours\n6\nSaif Ali Khan injured in robbery attempt at Mumbai home\nSee More\n1\nOlympic hypocrisy? Education\nEnvironment\nWebinars\nMore\nFootball\nLetters\nAdvertorial\nColumns\nEditorial\nSupplements\nEpaper\nClassifieds\nDesign Week\nLatest News\nAugust 24, 2023\nJDF joins search and rescue operations for missing  fishermen\nKINGSTON, Jamaica – The Jamaica Defence Force (JDF) is currently engaged in a search and  rescue (SAR) operation to locate Denroy Morgan and Hillroy Reid, two Clarendon fishermen who have been missing since Wednesday, August 16, 2023.\nReports are that Morgan and Reid left Rocky Point, Clarendon, on  Monday, August 14, to go crab hunting in Manatee Bay. When they did not return by  the stipulated time on Wednesday, August 16, a family member alerted the Lionel Town  police and a search ensued.\n“Over the past several days, the JDF has deployed aircraft and patrol vessels from the Jamaica  Defence Force Air Wing and the Jamaica Defence Force Coast Guard respectively, in an  extensive search for the missing fishermen and their vessel. To date, nothing has been found,” the JDF said in a statement on Thursday.\n“The JDF is urging fisherfolk and citizens traversing the seas, cays and points offshore  Jamaica to be on the lookout for these missing men and their vessel and provide any  information they might have to the JDF Tipline at (876) 837-8888 or Police Emergency  Number 119,” it added.\nThe JDF went on to say that it is committed to using its assets to safeguard and preserve the lives and livelihoods  of all Jamaicans.\n{\"website\":\"website\"}{\"jamaica-observer\":\"Jamaica Observer\"}\n0 Comments · Make a     "https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2024/03/04/japan/japan-fatal-boat-accident/": "One dead, 24 rescued off Japanese fishing boat - The Japan Times\nSubscribe\nDigital\nPrint\nJanuary 30, 2025\nSubscribe\nDigital\nPrint\nTrump 2.0\nFuji TV\nTariffs\nLatest News\nDeep Dive\nToday's print edition\nHome Delivery\nJAPAN\nPolitics\nSociety\nCrime & Legal\nScience & Health\nExplainer\nHistory\nWORLD\nPolitics\nCrime & Legal\nScience & Health\nSociety\nASIA PACIFIC\nPolitics\nCrime & Legal\nScience & Health\nSociety\nBUSINESS\nCompanies\nEconomy\nMarkets\nTech\nSPORTS\nSumo\nSoccer\nBaseball\nBasketball\nTennis\nOlympics\nMore sports\nOPINION\nEditorials\nCommentary\nEnvironment\nCLIMATE CHANGE\nEnergy\nSUSTAINABILITY\nWILDLIFE\nEARTH SCIENCE\nLIFE\nTravel\nDigital\nFood & Drink\nStyle & Design\nLanguage\nLifestyle\nCULTURE\nFilm\nBooks\nMusic\nArt\nTV & Streaming\nStage\nEntertainment news\nCOMMUNITY\nVoices\nIssues\nHow-tos\nOur Lives\nMy Account\nMy Bookmarks\nLogout\nSubscribe for more access\nJAPAN\nOne dead, 24 rescued off Japanese fishing boat\nThe fishing vessel had engine trouble on Sunday off the Kozushima island in the Izu the archipelago.\n|   Jiji\nAFP-Jiji\nSHARE/SAVE\nTwitter\nFacebook\nLinkedIn\nEmail\nPrint\nBookmark story\nMar 4, 2024\nOne person died and 24 others were rescued on Monday after a fishing boat lost power and drifted onto rocks in rough seas off Japan, the coast guard said. Dramatic television footage showed the 56-meter vessel on its side being pounded by waves as the crew huddled on deck and a helicopter hovered overhead. The tuna-fishing ship's crew included five Japanese nationals and 20 Indonesians. According to a coast guard spokesman, the vessel had engine trouble on Sunday afternoon off the Izu archipelago south of Honshu. In an operation involving patrol boats and helicopters, all but one of the crew members had been rescued by Monday morning, he said. The body of the missing Japanese crew member was later found.\nKEYWORDS\nmarine accidents(https://www.japantimes.co.jp/tag/marine-accidents),                                         fishing(https://www.japantimes.co.jp/tag/fishing),                                         Izu islands(https://www.japantimes.co.jp/tag/izu-islands)\nIn a time of both misinformation and too much information, quality journalism is more crucial than ever.By subscribing, you can help us get the story right.\nSUBSCRIBE NOW\nWith your current subscription plan you can comment on stories. Online\nPosted\nNEW ORLEANS — The Coast Guard is searching for a 35-year-old fisherman who fell overboard early Saturday. Officials say the man fell from the commercial fishing vessel Miss Winnie roughly 138 miles southwest of Port Fourchon.They were called around 2 a.m. from another vessel, who told them the vessel Miss Winnie had reported the man overboard.Coast Guard District Eight watchstanders launched a Coast Guard Aviation Training Center Mobile HC-144 Ocean Sentry aircrew, a Coast Guard Air Station Corpus Christi HC-144 Ocean Sentry aircrew and the Coast Guard Cutter Jacob Poroo.Watchstanders have also been transmitting an urgent marine information broadcast to mariners.The Coast Guard will continue to monitor severe weather conditions in the area and search as weather conditions permit.\nCopyright 2023 Scripps Media, Inc. KelownaCitiesVernonPentictonKamloopsVictoriaPrince GeorgeAuctionsSubscribeProvincial Election\nShare on Facebook\nKamloops\nposted Jun 21, 2023 @ 11:55am by\nCheyanna Lorraine\nSearch continues for 2 missing fisherman last seen on Stump Lake near Merritt\nThe BC RCMP’s Underwater Recovery Team has been called in to help with the search for two men who were last seen fishing on Stump Lake. In the early hours of Tuesday morning, the Merritt RCMP were notified that the two Lower Mainland men were missing.\nA release issued on Wednesday says the two men had been last seen by friends, fishing late into the evening in a small aluminum boat. When they didn’t return after dark, friends began to search for them but were unsuccessful and eventually called police. The Kamloops Search and Rescue team was also notified and joined in the search for the two men, alongside Police Dog Services. An extensive ground, water and air search was conducted.  Debris belonging to the missing fisherman was found floating near the North end of the lake but neither the fishermen, nor their boat have been located. \"We are not releasing the names of the missing fishermen at this time,” says S/Sgt. Josh Roda, detachment commander with the Merritt RCMP.  \"We want to give the families privacy while they try to comprehend what took place.” Search efforts will continue at the lake in the coming days. If you are recreating in the Stump Lake area and find debris that you believe may be associated with the missing fishermen, contact the Merritt RCMP at (250) 378-4262.\nIf you get value from KelownaNow and believe local independent media is important to our community we ask that you please consider subscribing to our daily newsletter.\nEmail Address *\nIf you appreciate what we do, we ask that you consider supporting our local independent news platform.\nSend your comments, news tips, typos, letter to the editor, photos and videos to news@kelownanow.com.\nUpdating Stories\n0°\nWed2℃Thu0℃Fri3℃Sat3℃Sun2℃Mon-5℃\nRecent Livestream\nTop Stories\nUPDATE: Bennett Bridge reopens to traffic after bomb scare forces 10-hour closure\nMissing snowboarder, 21, found dead at BC resort\nDowntown Kelowna’s newest ramen spot was born in Japan\nTrump bump: US citizenship renunciation inquiries surge in Canada, lawyers say\n3 officers injured during arrest of ‘distraught man’ at Kelowna McDonald's\nCanadian teen brain-injured in Caribbean bar attack back home but missing skull piece\nCanada stops letting cross-border hikers enter BC via Pacific Crest Trail\nEby says US tariff could hit harder than 2008 recession, vows pandemic-style relief\nFollow Us\nPrivacy Policy",
    "https://www.kompas.id/baca/english/2023/10/18/en-kapal-nelayan-terbalik-di-cilacap-1-tewas-dan-2-orang-masih-dicari?open_from=Section_English": "Fishing Boat Capsizes in Cilacap, 2 Dead and 1 Person Still Wanted - Kompas.id     Menu   Cari             English Fishing Boat Capsizes in Cilacap, 2 Dead and 1 Person Still Wanted   TEKS          ›  English›Fishing Boat Capsizes in...  Iklan     Fishing Boat Capsizes in Cilacap, 2 Dead and 1 Person Still Wanted   Two fishermen died and another person is still being sought after their boat capsized in Cilacap waters.    Audio Berita        This article has been translated using AI.  See Original .  About AI Translated Article   Please note that this article was automatically translated using Microsoft Azure AI, Open AI, and Google Translation AI. We cannot ensure that the entire content is translated accurately. If you spot any errors or inconsistencies, contact us at hotline@kompas.id, and we'll make every effort to address them. Thank you for your understanding.   By WILIBRORDUS MEGANDIKA WICAKSONO  · 3 minutes read   TEKS        The following article was translated using both Microsoft Azure Open AI and Google Translation AI. The original article can be found in Kapal Nelayan Terbalik di Cilacap, 2 Tewas dan 1 Orang Masih DicariARSIP BASARNAS CILACAPThe condition of a fishing boat that overturned on Wagir Indah Beach, Adipala, Cilacap, Central Java, on Wednesday (18/10/2023).— The ship involved in the accident is named \"Tri Laksana\". Head of Cilacap Search and Rescue Office, Adah Sudarsa, stated that the ship is believed to be unable to withstand the force of pulling the net, causing it to lose balance to the point of capsizing and being carried away by the current to the shore.An accident occurred on Wednesday at 07.30 AM WIB. There were 9 people on board. Six of them survived, two died, and one is still missing and being searched for by the Joint SAR Team.Also read: High Waves Make Fishermen's Search Difficult in CilacapARSIP BASARNAS CILACAPResidents and a joint SAR team hauled a capsized fishing boat at Wagir Indah Beach, Adipala, Cilacap, Central Java, on Wednesday (18/10/2023).The identities of the survivors are Farid (31), Arjun (22), Tusmin (60), and Dul Rohim (55). The four of them are residents of Brebes. There are also Roni (32) and Musa (65) from Cilacap. The deceased victims are named Slamet (62) and Alfin Rastoni B Darmo (60) from Brebes. \"Meanwhile, one person who is still missing is named Edi Suwaryo (55) from Brebes,\" said Adah.According to Adah, currently the Joint SAR Team has combed the surface of the water using LCR (landing craft rubber) around the location of the incident and pulled the ship's net. It is feared that the victim was caught in the net.Apart from that, the Joint SAR Team also combed the land area around the incident location. \"We have sent a rescue team to the location of the incident to look for one crew member, complete with SAR equipment in the water,\" he said.Also read: 9 Days Missing, Cilacap Fisherman Found DeadSaeful Anwar from the Public Relations department of Basarnas Cilacap stated that, from the information gathered by his team, the fishermen did not wear safety jackets or life rafts when they were at sea. This incident adds to the list of accidents caused by not using safety equipment while at sea.Previously, a jellyfish hunter fisherman at Bunton Beach, Cilacap, was found dead after being submerged for nine days. On Monday (16/10/2023), Basarnas SAR Office in Cilacap received information from the SAR potential regarding the discovery of a corpse in the waters of Lengkong, Cilacap.ARSIP BASARNAS CILACAPThe Joint SAR Team is searching for a jellyfish hunter who reportedly went missing at Bunton Beach, Cilacap, Central Java, on Wednesday (11/10/2023).After undergoing forensic tests by authorized personnel, the body was identified as Marto Miardi (61) from Mertasinga, North Cilacap District, according to Adah. It is known that on Sunday (10/8/2023), the victim went to sea to search for jellyfish. However, on Monday (10/9/2023) morning, only a broken boat belonging to a fisherman without an engine was found around Bunton Beach.As reported previously (Kompas.id, 11/10/2023), according to data from Basarnas Cilacap, there were 41 incidents handled by Basarnas Cilacap during January-September 2023.A total of 41 incidents consisted of 5 ship accidents, 1 natural disaster, 33 events endangering human lives, as well as 2 accidents requiring special handling. Out of this number, there were 144 victims with details of 98 survivors, 31 deaths, and 15 people declared missing.Sometimes you don't even care about your own safety.Compared to 2022, there were 66 incidents with a total of 54 fatalities, 8 missing persons, and 318 survivors. Meanwhile, in 2021, there were 55 incidents with 46 survivors, 43 fatalities, and 17 missing persons.The Chairman of the Indonesian Fishermen Association in Cilacap Regency, Sarjono, once mentioned that traditional fishermen still ignore their own safety as they do not always wear life jackets.\"We have been instructed many times that when going to sea, we must wear a safety jacket for protection. Sometimes you don't even pay attention to your own safety, it's said to be complicated, even though it's important. \"Even if you can't swim, if you get into the sea, you'll definitely float,\" said Sarjono (Kompas.id 26/7/2023).
