    "https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1176140": "Fisherman killed, 2 others injured in Samar blast fishing | Philippine News Agency\nGOV PH\nOpen GOV.PH Menu\nHome\nAbout\nSubscription\nTransparency\nContact\nSearch\nPerform Search\nHome\nAbout\nSubscription\nTransparency\nContact\nSearch\nPerform Search\nOpen GOV.PH Menu\nHome\nNational\nProvincial\nOpinion\nBusiness\nFeatures\nHealth\nForeign\nSports\nTravel\nEnvironment\nSciTech\nHome\nNational\nProvincial\nOpinion\nBusiness\nFeatures\nHealth\nForeign\nSports\nTravel\nEnvironment\nSciTech\nFisherman killed, 2 others injured in Samar blast fishing\nBy Sarwell Meniano\nJune 8, 2022, 2:31 pm\nShare\nShare\nX (formerly Twitter)\nViber\nEmail\nILLEGAL FISHING. A fishing boat intercepted by the fishery law enforcers in Sto. Niño, Samar in this Jan. 28, 2021 photo. On June 7, a fisherman was killed while two others were hurt when they went dynamite fishing in the seawaters of Sto. Niño, Samar. (Photo courtesy of Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources)\nTACLOBAN CITY – A fisherman was killed while two others were hurt while engaged in dynamite fishing in the seawaters of Sto. Niño, Samar on Tuesday, the Philippine National Police (PNP) has reported.Emiliano Davila, 40, was about to throw the ignited gelatin sticks when it exploded, wounding two others who were standing on the motorized boat, police said on Wednesday.Other blast victims were his cousins Rolan Davila, 28 and Jorgie Davila, 31.All victims are residents of coastal Ilijan village in Sto. Niño, Samar, some 10 kilometers away from the town center.Davila died on the spot while the two other fishermen suffered multiple injuries and were rushed to the Calbayog City District Hospital for treatment.Samar provincial fishery officer Marlon Sale admitted that dynamite fishing is rampant in the island towns of the province despite the information drive and enforcement activities of local government units.“It has been the habit of some of our fishermen in Samar to resort to blast fishing to catch more. Even those who have received livelihood assistance from the government also engaged in illegal activities,\" Sale said in a phone interview.The deep seawaters of Sto. Niño town is known for its abundant harvest of sardines and spinefoot fish.Sale said the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (BFAR) has already trained teams in the local government to enforce fishery laws within the municipal waters.However, sea patrol is not sustained due to limited resources and different priorities of the local government.“We are working with the local government to ensure that those caught engaged in illegal fishing will be held liable,” he added.The official warned that those caught in blast fishing are liable to immediate imprisonment under section 92 of the Fisheries Code.Once proven administratively, municipal fishermen will be fined PHP30,000 while commercial fishers are bound to pay more from PHP300,000 to PHP3 million. the prison term ranges from five to 10 years.The BFAR regional office condemned the continued use of explosives, noxious, or any poisonous substances in fishing.“It does not only damage our fishery resources, but also result in the loss of human lives. BFAR continues to remind the public, especially our fisherfolk that the illegal practice of using these substances will always bring harm to the environment and human lives,” the regional office's statement showed. (PNA)\nRelated Articles\nIlocos police seizes over P1-B shabu, marijuana in 2024\nJanuary 10, 2025 6:01 pm\nFishCore project to boost livelihood of Ilocos fisherfolk\nDecember 11, 2024 10:05 pm\nNavy rescues fisherman adrift for 2 days off Tawi-Tawi\nDecember 5, 2024 2:09 pm\nSurigao Norte farmers highlight gov’t support at post-SONA forum\nNovember 28, 2024 9:49 pm\nComments\nThe Philippine News Agency is a web-based newswire service of the Philippine government under the\nsupervision of the News and Information Bureau (NIB) of the Presidential Communications Office (PCO).\nGovernment Links\nOffice of the President\nOffice of the Vice President\nSenate of the Philippines\nHouse of Representatives\nSupreme Court\nPresidential Communications Office\nCopyright 2025 Philippine News Agency.     "https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1184834": "Missing Laoag fisherman found dead off neighboring Pasuquin | Philippine News Agency\nGOV PH\nOpen GOV.PH Menu\nHome\nAbout\nSubscription\nTransparency\nContact\nSearch\nPerform Search\nHome\nAbout\nSubscription\nTransparency\nContact\nSearch\nPerform Search\nOpen GOV.PH Menu\nHome\nNational\nProvincial\nOpinion\nBusiness\nFeatures\nHealth\nForeign\nSports\nTravel\nEnvironment\nSciTech\nHome\nNational\nProvincial\nOpinion\nBusiness\nFeatures\nHealth\nForeign\nSports\nTravel\nEnvironment\nSciTech\nMissing Laoag fisherman found dead off neighboring Pasuquin\nBy Leilanie Adriano\nSeptember 28, 2022, 5:53 pm\nUpdated on September 28, 2022, 8:01 pm\nShare\nShare\nX (formerly Twitter)\nViber\nEmail\nSEARCH AND RESCUE. Search and rescue teams scour the coastal waters off Barangay 34-B Gabu Norte in Laoag City to look for a missing fisherman on Wednesday (Sept. 28, 2022). A helicopter from the Office of the Civil Defense has been requested to help in the operation. (Photo courtesy of Laoag City)\nLAOAG CITY – The body of a fisherman who went missing off the coast of this city was found Wednesday afternoon.According to the City Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office (CDRRMO), the fisherman, identified as 34-year-old Mike June Ranada, went fishing with other companions early Tuesday morning in the brackish waters off Barangay 34-B Gabu Norte when big waves reportedly smashed into and swept his boat away.Fellow fishermen later found Ranada's body floating off the coast of Pasuquin town, north of Laoag, Elviro Agoo, village chief of Barangay Davila in Pasuquin said.Authorities said the victim's body was immediately airlifted via a Philippine Air Force chopper.The Ilocos Norte government had also earlier requested the Office of the Civil Defense to provide a helicopter to help in the search and rescue operation.     "https://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/news/body-recovered-after-man-goes-overboard-near-bodega-bay/": "Body recovered after man goes overboard near Bodega Bay - The Press Democrat\nSkip to content\nSkip to footer\nShow Menu\neEdition\nToday's weather:  and\nNotification Tray\nLog In\nRegister\nAccount Menu\nLink Your Account\nMy Account\neEdition\nLog Out\nSubscribe\nNews\nObits\nLegacy Obits\nNewsmaker Obits\nSports\nBusiness\nOpinion\nNapa\nReal Estate\nFood & Wine\nDining\nA&E\nEvents Guide\nFun\nDaily Crossword\nWord Games\nComics\nContests\nSudoku\nHoroscope\nPolitical Cartoons\nFree Games\nClassified\nPlace a classified ad\nPlace a legal ad\nSee our ads\nSee Our Legal Ads\nJobs\nNewsletters\nFind it Fast\nSSU Cuts\nSchool Closures\nSDC\nTrump's 1st 100 Days\nImmigrant Communities\nComics\nContests\nSupport Local Journalism\nFor Subscribers\nBody recovered after man goes overboard near Bodega BayThe U.S. Coast Guard had sent out an emergency alert of a man overboard Friday morning, according to another boater.EMILY WILDERTHE PRESS DEMOCRAT February 25, 20223 minute read\nAuthorities recovered a body Friday afternoon after searching for a commercial crab fisherman reported overboard near the southern end of Bodega Bay.\nThe search was launched after the young skipper’s boat was found adrift, with no one inside, local fishermen said.\nCoast Guard officials confirmed a search and rescue operation began about 9:15 a.m. Friday by Elephant Rock, near Tomales Point within Point Reyes National Seashore. The Sonoma County Sheriff’s Office helicopter participated in the operation.\n“We took a missing persons report this morning. We had Henry 1 and our boating unit searching for the missing boater,” said Sgt. Juan Valencia, spokesman for the Sonoma County Sheriff's Office.\nThe man’s identity has yet to be released pending notification of family. The Sheriff’s Office is leading the investigation into the death.\nThe Coast Guard assisted the Sheriff’s Office search and in turn called on others on the water to help locate the missing crabber.\n“The local fishing community helped out with the search plan of it, passing information about last communication with (the missing captain) at 9 p.m. last night,” a Coast Guard spokesperson said. “However, they did not suspect anything wrong until the report of the adrift vessel.”\nRon Keith first learned of the situation while whale watching with his 13-year-old son, Kaden. He said he heard through radio chatter a boat was adrift near Elephant Rock with no one on board about 10 minutes before the official pan-pan, a distress alert sent by the Coast Guard.\n“We went by there and circled the boat a few times and honked the horn” before the Coast Guard arrived, Keith said. “He still had his running lights on.”\nKeith also recalled a crab trap in the water had still been hooked to the boat’s winch.\nUpon arriving in the area, Coast Guard officers found the boat’s engine still running.\n“We suspected the captain fell off the vessel at some point,” the spokesperson said.\nAircraft from the San Francisco Coast Guard station located the person in the water about 1 mile from the boat. Crew on a Coast Guard boat recovered him from the water and “discovered obvious signs of death,” according to the spokesperson.\nBodega Bay Fire Protection District paramedics pronounced the person deceased at the dock.\nMembers of the fishing community said the man was known to fish alone, despite pleas from his friends not to do so, said Dick Ogg, a well-known veteran fisherman.\n“One mistake, and you’re dead,” Ogg said, describing the man as a very close friend. “We deal with this every day. It’s just horrible.”\nLocal fishermen also said the boat was allowed to run ashore despite having people in the vicinity willing to tow it and Coast Guard personnel onshore, at one point.\nThe vessel eventually grounded on Kehoe Beach, at the Point Reyes National Seashore, a hard-to-reach spot where it’s likely to break up, littering the ocean and preventing the family of the fisherman from selling it or any of the crab on board, Ogg said.\nAn official with the Coast Guard responded that the station’s single boat crew had located the body before they were able to begin towing the vessel to safe harbor.\n“We determined that the victim was to be taken back to (emergency medical services) rather than tow the vessel,” the official said.\n“We cannot task commercial fisherman with towing. Nor were we aware of anyone on scene with the capability to tow the vessel. We did not intervene with any civilian attempts to tow the vessel.”\nBy the time the boat crew was available to return and tow the vessel, the winds had picked up, according to the official.\n\"The adrift vessel was rapidly drifting towards the shore and we were not able to bring the vessel in tow,“ the official said.\nMarco Galazzo, general manager of the Tides Wharf and Restaurant in the small community of Bodega Bay, confirmed he also heard a man had gone overboard. He shared he was shaken and was anxiously awaiting further information.\nYou can reach Staff Writer Emily Wilder at 707-521-5337 or emily.wilder@pressdemocrat.com. On Twitter @vv1lder.\nPowered by trinityaudio.ai\nUPDATED: Please read and follow our commenting policy:\nThis is a family newspaper, please use a kind and respectful tone.\nNo profanity, hate speech or personal attacks. RESISTANCE\nAL-AQSA FLOOD\nFROM BEIRUT\nUNSCRIPTED\nWOMEN OF RESISTANCE\nDOCUMENTARIES\nBREAKING NEWS\n#\nNews\n/\nYemen\nFisherman killed, two others wounded as US Navy fires on boat off Yemen's Arabian Sea coast: Media reports\nTuesday, 01 November 2022 4:21 PM  [ Last Update: Tuesday, 01 November 2022 4:21 PM ]\nIn this file picture, fishermen sit in docked boats at the fishing port in Hudaydah, Yemen, on November 21, 2021. (Photo by Reuters)\nOne person has reportedly been killed and three others were injured when a US Navy ship fired at an approaching fishing boat off the coast of Yemen’s southeastern province of al-Mahrah province in the northern tip of the Arabian Sea.\nYemeni media outlets, citing local sources, reported that a warship opened fire on the fishermen as they were roaming the Yemeni waters off the shores of the Hawf district in search of schools of fish to catch.\nThe sources added that three people were wounded in the attack, of whom one later succumbed to his critical injuries.\nThe development comes as foreign forces have turned most of fish markets in Mahra province into military barracks and weapons depots, adversely affecting the livelihood of fishermen there.\nBack in late July, a batch of US military forces entered Yemen’s Mahrah province, as Washington continues its aggressive attempts to establish control over oil reserves and plunder natural resources in the energy-rich region.\nTwo former German soldiers sentenced over bid to form mercenary force in Yemen\nGerman prosecutors have sentenced two former Bundeswehr soldiers to jail on charges of trying to form a mercenary force to intervene in the ongoing Yemen war.\nYemen Press Agency, citing local sources, reported that the American troops landed at al-Ghaydah Airport on July 28 onboard a flight from Riyan International Airport in Mukalla, which lies on the shores of the Arabian Sea and about 480 kilometers (300 miles) east of Aden.\nThe sources, who asked not to be named, stated that the arrival of the US forces was followed by a major disruption to internet connectivity in the Sayhut district, blaming the internet blackout on the installation of sophisticated surveillance devices by American troops.\nEarlier, a top-ranking Yemeni official said US and British military trainers had arrived at a port in Mahrah on vessels loaded with munitions as well as military and logistical equipment.\nThe provincial governor, al-Qatabi Ali Hussein al-Faraj, told Yemen’s official Saba news agency on June 26 that large arms shipments aboard military vessels disembarked at the port of Nishtun, and that British and American military trainers were stationed at al-Ghaydah International Airport.\nSenior Red Cross official says 19 Yemenis suffer from food insecurity as Saudi-led war against impoverished country continues\nAbout 19 million Yemenis are currently suffering from food insecurity, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC).\n“The Saudi-led coalition of aggression is involved in the smuggling and trade of narcotics in the area in order to perpetuate insecurity, advance its fiendish plots, and deter the local population from confronting the invaders,” Faraj said at the time.\nThe senior Yemeni official noted that occupiers and their allied Takfiri militants were trying to plunge Mahrah province into utter chaos and confusion as locals were fiercely opposed to the presence of foreign forces.\nSaudi Arabia launched the devastating war on Yemen in March 2015 in collaboration with its Arab allies and with arms and logistics support from the US and other Western states.\nThe objective was to reinstall the Riyadh-friendly regime of Abd Rabbuh Mansour Hadi and crush the Ansarullah resistance movement, which has been running state affairs in the absence of a functional government in Yemen.\nWhile the Saudi-led coalition has failed to meet any of its objectives, the war has killed hundreds of thousands of Yemenis and spawned the world’s worst humanitarian crisis.\nPress TV’s website can also be accessed at the following alternate addresses:\nwww.presstv.ir\nSHARE THIS ARTICLE\nUS\nYemen\nMiddle East\nUS RAPPLER\nTeam\nPolicies\nAwards and recognition\nSpecial Projects\nNews & updates\nGuest\nRegister\nSign in\nDonate\nSearch\nRAPPLER\nDonate\nLogin\nSubscribe Now\nVisayas\nAklan\nLightning strikes, kills young fisherman in Aklan\nMay 31, 2023 7:32 PM PHT\nJun Aguirre\nSUMMARY\nThis is AI generated summarization, which may have errors. For context, always refer to the full article.\nEMPTY. Street food vendors leave their mobile kiosks empty due to bad weather conditions in Kalibo, Aklan on Wesdnesday.\nJun Aguirre / Rappler\nINFO\nThe tragedy takes place moments before the Philippine Coast Guard issued an order suspending fishing, water sports activities, and select trips to and from Aklan due to strong winds\nAKLAN, Philippines – Tragedy struck in Aklan as a young man lost his life to a lightning strike while his group ventured out to sea.\nThe incident occurred just moments before the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) issued an order on Wednesday, May 30, suspending fishing, water sports activities, and select trips to and from Aklan due to strong winds.\nThe police identified the fatality as 17-year-old Aklan John Rey Almoquera of Barangay Libertad, Nabas, Aklan.\nAlmoquera was with a group who went fishing, unaware that the PCG warned fishermen against venturing out to sea because of the risks.\nThe lightning struck Almoquera’s chest, killing him instantaneously on the waters off Nabas town.\nPolice said the other fishermen were unhurt.\nThe Office of the Civil Defense (OCD) in the Western Visayas region also issued an advisory on Wednesday morning, cautioning about heavy rain and landslides expected in Aklan and Antique.\nIn neighboring Malay, the Municipal Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office initially suspended boat operations to and from Boracay on Wednesday afternoon, but later resumed them as weather conditions improved. Some areas in Malay experienced flooding due to the heavy rain.\nIn the eastern towns of Kalibo and Batan, local governments suspended work starting at 1 pm on Wednesday.\nIn nearby Antique province, numerous commuters were stranded in Lauaan after the local government blocked the passage of public vehicles to temporary access roads due to flooding on Wednesday morning.\nThe Paliwan Bridge, intended to provide a safe route for commuters, was damaged by flash floods in November.\nErrol Santillan, a former provincial board member, said the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) is currently reconstructing the bridge at a cost of nearly P285 million.\nThe reconstruction work commenced on April 5, and is expected to be completed after one year. – Rappler.com\nJun Aguirre is an Aries Rufo Journalism fellow.\nAdd a comment\nError.\nPlease abide by Rappler's commenting guidelines.\nPost Comment\nCancel\nSort by\nNewest comments\nOldest comments\nSubmit\nThere are no comments yet.     "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/us-news/us-coast-guard-suspends-search-for-missing-fisherman-after-three-die-articleshow.html": "US Coast Guard suspends search for missing fisherman after three die | Republic World\nRepublic World Republic Business R.Bharat R.Bangla R.Kannada          Home    World    Live TV    Defence      SportFit      India News    Latest News    Republic Business      Education    Entertainment     More    TRENDING/ Maha Kumbh Stampede  |\nYamuna 'Poisoning' Row   |\nRussia-Ukraine War  |\nSaif Ali Khan  |\nDeepSeek  |\nVirat Kohli  |\nNews /  World News /  US News /  US Coast Guard suspends search for missing fisherman after three die      Published 06:55 IST, April 23rd 2023  US Coast Guard suspends search for missing fisherman after three die The US Coast Guard suspended the search for a fisherman on Friday, a day the small boat he had been in was found capsized off the Massachusetts coast and the other three men who had been onboard were found unresponsive and later pronounced dead.  World News 2 min read Reported by: Associated Press Television News Follow:\nImage: AP/Representative | Image:\nself The U.S. Coast Guard suspended the search for a fisherman on Friday, a day the small boat he had been in was found capsized off the Massachusetts coast and the other three men who had been onboard were found unresponsive and later pronounced dead.   The Coast Guard searched nearly 1,600 square miles (4,144 square kilometers) of ocean for the boat and its four passengers, who were reported missing just before midnight Wednesday. It found the boat about 7 miles (11 kilometers) northeast of Cape Ann, Massachusetts.    On Friday, it suspended the search for the last of the missing men, Bin “Michael” Cai.  On Thursday search crews found 38-year-old Jia Fu Zheng and 43-year-old Daxiao Lin, both of Quincy, Massachusetts, and 42-year-old Jaime Liu, of Litchfield, New Hampshire. They were unresponsive when found and were pronounced dead after they were brought ashore in Gloucester, Massachusetts, officials said.    The Coast Guard did not provide an age or hometown for Cai.  The four left the harbor in Hampton, New Hampshire, on Wednesday morning intending to fish in an area called Jeffreys Ledge, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) offshore. They were due back by sunset.    A relative of one of the men called to report them missing at about 11:45 p.m. Wednesday.  Coast Guard Lt. Brandon Newman told Seacoastonline.com that there were 2-foot (0.6-meter) waves on Wednesday. The air temperature was 42 degrees (5.6 degrees Celsius) and the water temperature was 46 degrees (7.8 degrees Celsius).    The Coast Guard searched an area based on the last known position of one of the fishermen's cellphones and their intention to fish on Jeffreys Ledge.  The Coast Guard will conduct an investigation.    Capt. Amy Florentino, the commander of Coast Guard Sector Northern New England, said the decision to end a search was a difficult one.  \"\"The water temperature in New England at this time of the year dramatically reduces the survivability rate for anyone that enters the water, and we urge all boaters to keep the air and water temperatures in mind when planning their voyages this spring,” Florentino said in a statement.     Updated 06:55 IST, April 23rd 2023                  About Us Contact Us Privacy Policy Sitemap RSS Policies Disclaimers       Follow Republic on:         Download the all-new Republic app:   © 2025 Republic. All rights reserved.  Big Stories 19 New   Quick   Live TV   Video",
    "https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/463369/search-ends-for-missing-cook-islands-fishermen": "Search ends for missing Cook Islands fishermen | RNZ News\nNews\nRadio\nPodcasts\nSeries\nTopics\nTe Ao Māori\nPacific\nIndoNZ\n中文\nNavigation for News Categories\nNewsProgrammesSchedulesHow to ListenAbout RNZ Pacific\nPacific\nCook Islands\n15 Mar 2022\nSearch ends for missing Cook Islands fishermen\n7:55 pm on 15 March 2022\nShare this\nShare on Twitter\nShare on Facebook\nShare via email\nShare on Reddit\nShare on Linked In\nEleisha Foon, RNZ Pacific Senior Journalist\n@eleishafoon\nCook Island Police have discontinued their search for a pair of fisherman now missing for nine days.\nOn 6 March Toru Miri and Tekou Tepene went fishing in the dangerous Rutaki Passage, and never returned.\nIt is understood the pair were planning to net fish in the area, despite it being signposted to discourage people from entering it.\nA cable ship off the Rutaki passage.\nPhoto: Cook Islands government\nPolice spokesperson Trevor Pitt said, \"since last wednesday the police and volunteer groups have conducted quite extensive searches including the lagoon area where they were fishing.\"\nHe said,\"this is most likely a tragedy and will be another life lesson for people in the community.\"\nThe Rutaki Passage is a dangerous area, with a history of people being swept away or drowned.\nA fisherman of 40 years, Steven Kavana warned people to stay clear of the area.\n\"If you are not a fisherman do not go in that area. The current can change quickly, if you are caught in it you have to swim out with the current, not fight it. It will be very hard to find their bodies. It is a dangerous area.\"\nHe said it was a tragedy for the entire community. One of the men was considered an experienced fisherman, although the other was not.\nPolice were finalising an incident report to be referred to the Coroner.\nTags:\nCook Islands\nShare this\nShare on Twitter\nShare on Facebook\nShare via email\nShare on Reddit\nShare on Linked In\nCopyright © 2022, Radio New Zealand\nNext story in Pacific\nPNG man jailed for life for murder of 10 Chinese nationals\nPacific\nQuestions about deadly Samoan measles outbreak raised as Kennedy faces US Senate\n2025 Vanuatu official election results: Solitary woman elected to 52-member parliament\nRainbo Paita returns to Cabinet after failed attempts to topple James Marape\nGet the RNZ app\nfor ad-free news and current affairs\nTop New Zealand Stories\nFuture 'grim' for intervention services after Oranga Tamariki cuts\nTiwai Point scrub fire explodes to cover 250 hectares\nDonald Trump says Microsoft in talks to buy TikTok\nNZ First refuses to back down over 'xenophobic' comments\nThings 'about to get scary' for coffee industry\nSubscribe\nPacific RSS\nFollow RNZ News",

The bodies have been taken into the care of the government health forensics pathology services. Two survivors were transported to the hospital by an EMS ambulance and they are recovering. Share this Story : Lost fisherman: Hearts are heavy as lobster fishery sees tragedy in southwestern NS       Copy Link   Email   X   Reddit   Pinterest   LinkedIn   Tumblr Breadcrumb Trail LinksAtlantic CanadaCape BretonNewfoundland & LabradorNewsCanadaNova ScotiaHalifaxPrince Edward IslandLost fisherman: Hearts are heavy as lobster fishery sees tragedy in southwestern NSFisherman lost at sea after going overboard morning of Dec. 26 during fishing trip; official search called off Dec. 27 at noonAuthor of the article: Tina Comeau, PNI Atlantic Published Dec 27, 2022  •  Last updated Dec 31, 2022  •  4 minute readA search and rescue helicopter is photographed on Monday, Dec. 26, as the search for a missing lobster fisherman was being conducted from the air and on the sea. KATHY JOHNSON PHOTO Photo by Kathy Johnson /Kathy JohnsonArticle contentSOUTHWESTERN NS Hearts are heavy once again in fishing communities in southwestern Nova Scotia and throughout the province as people grieve another tragedy to befall the lobster and fishing industry.A Monday, Dec. 26, fishing trip resulted in the loss of a young fisherman who went overboard that morning off Cape Sable Island.An extensive search was conducted throughout the day on Monday and continued Tuesday morning, until being officially called off around noon time on Dec. 27 with the matter turned over to the RCMP as a missing person investigation.Advertisement 2Story continues belowThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.THIS CONTENT IS RESERVED FOR SUBSCRIBERS ONLY.Subscribe now to access this story and more:Unlimited access to the website and appExclusive access to premium content, newsletters and podcastsFull access to the e-Edition app, an electronic generation of journalistsSUBSCRIBE TO UNLOCK MORE ARTICLES.Subscribe or sign in to your account to continue your reading experience.Unlimited access to the website and appExclusive access to premium content, newsletters and podcastsFull access to the e-Edition app, an electronic replica of the print edition that you can share, download and comment onEnjoy insights and behind-the-scenes analysis from our award-winning journalistsSupport local journalists and the next generation of journalistsRegister to unlock more articles.Create an account or sign in to continue your reading experience.Access additional stories every monthShare your thoughts and join the conversation in our commenting communityGet email updates from your favourite authorsSign In or Create an AccountEmail AddressContinueor View more offersIf you are a Home delivery print subscriber, online access is included in your subscription.  Activate your Online Access NowArticle contentPrayers were being offered on social media for the missing man and his family throughout the search, with family members also asking for prayers that he be found.Many people in the region were changing their social media profile photos to a photograph of lit candles with the message: Light for Christian.Throughout the night people symbolically left their porch lights on as well to guide the missing fisherman home.Family members put up posts about their missing loved one as did community members, expressing their heartache and sadness.“Yesterday, Dec. 26th, 2022, the lobster industry lost one of their own. Christian Lee Atwood aged 27 years was lost,” read one post on Tuesday morning.Prayers are also being extended to the crew of the fishing vessel, as well. The captain of the vessel reportedly suffered a heart attack and is recovering from that.The Coast Guard vessel Cape Roger is seen from the distance from The Hawk on Cape Sable Island on Monday, Dec. 26 as it sailed to the scene where a search was being conducted for a missing lobster fisherman who had gone overboard that morning. – Kathy JohnsonThe fisherman was lost overboard on Dec. 26 from the fishing vessel MV Little Weasel II.The Joint Rescue Coordination Centre (JRCC) in Halifax said it received a mayday at 8:21 a.m. on Boxing Day from the 39-foot fishing vessel, which was six nautical miles southeast of Cape Sable Island.Advertisement 3Story continues belowThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article contentMany assets took part in the search for the missing fisherman.The CCGS Clarks Harbour and CCGS Cape Roger were tasked to the scene. In addition to those Coast Guard vessels, a Cormorant rescue helicopter and a Canadian Forces Hercules fixed-wing aircraft from 413 Squadron in Greenwood were also part of the search.As well, a large fleet of fishing vessels from Cape Sable Island were involved in the search.The fishing vessels included ones that were already out fishing and others that went out to the search area, JRCC said.Although the vessels werent tasked by JRCC their presence was felt.The numbers that were there, from what we could see, was somewhere between 12 and 15 vessels of opportunity that joined in, said Lt.-Commander Len Hickey, a spokesperson for JRCC.The CCGS Clarks Harbour and a large fleet of fishing vessels could be seen on Marine Tracker searching for a fisherman in an area off of Cape Sable Island on Monday, Dec. 26, 2022. – ScreenshotJRCC described the weather on Dec. 26 as being 25 knot winds with four-metre seas and overcast.Even after the believed time of survivability had passed, the search continued in earnest.They certainly saturated the search area and they continued the search well past what would be indicated by their survivability models, said Hickey.Advertisement 4Story continues belowThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article contentThe search also continued to be carried out throughout the night, with the CCGS Cape Roger and a PAL aircraft on the scene.Heading to the scene. A Cormorant helicopter flies above as the Coast Guard vessel Cape Roger is seen on the water below as a search was being conducted on Monday, Dec. 26 a lobster fisherman lost at sea. KATHY JOHNSON – Kathy JohnsonOn Tuesday morning it had been determined that the official search would continue until noon.If unsuccessful by that time, it would then be turned over to the RCMP as a missing person case, which has happened before in cases of fishers lost at sea.With regret, at 12:00 AST today, JRCC Hfx suspended the search for the missing fisherman who was lost overboard south of Cape Sable Island, Nova Scotia on December 26.HfxJRCC_CCCOS (@hfxjrcc)  December 27, 2022 The incident will continue with the RCMP as a missing person. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family and friends during this difficult time.HfxJRCC_CCCOS (@hfxjrcc)  December 27, 2022 Commercial fishing vessels continued to be part of the search Tuesday morning along with the other tasked search assets. Sea states were described on the morning of Dec. 27 as two-to-three metres, with winds 30-35 knots out of the southwest. It was said to be good visibility.While expressing the family’s sadness, a member of the fishermans family also expressed gratitude for the search efforts in a Facebook post shared by many others.Advertisement 5Story continues belowThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article contentChristians family wishes to thank everyone for their prayers at this time and ask for continued prayer to bring him home, the post read. Our thanks also go out to all who have been involved and continue to be part of the search effort to bring Christian home.The lobster industry is also expressing its sorrow.“A family is devastated. A community is broken,” writes Coldwater Lobster Association in a Facebook post. “The search for our fellow fisherman who tragically went over board off Cape Sable Island on Dec. 26th has been called off. Fishermen and coastal communities throughout the Maritimes are eerily still with emptiness and sorrow.”“May we all embrace Christians family, friends and his fellow crewmen who will undoubtedly need our guidance and love,” the post reads. “We send our deepest condolences as we try and conceive yet another tragedy to the sea. To everyone who assisted in the search, thank you. Truly heartbreaking.”The organization Fish Safe NS also spoke publicly about the tragedy.On behalf of the staff and board of directors of Fish Safe NS, we wish to send our heartfelt condolences to the family, friends and fellow crew members of Christian Atwood, who was tragically lost from the F/V Little Weasel II. The entire fishing industry have you all in our thoughts, it wrote in a Facebook post. We also wish to thank all those that aided in the search over the last 24-hours, your dedication and efforts are truly appreciated by all.Fish Safe NS said its team was preparing to make grief counselling services available in the Clarks Harbour and Barrington area. These services will be open to all those that wish to access them and will be available at no cost. More details were to come.Article contentShare this article in your social network         Share this Story : Lost fisherman: Hearts are heavy as lobster fishery sees tragedy in southwestern NS       Copy Link   Email   X   Reddit   Pinterest   LinkedIn   Tumblr Trending Nova Scotia to introduce its largest minimum wage increase     Nova Scotia   Halifax Infirmary ER employees injured by patient with weapon     Halifax   ‘This replaces an oil refinery’: Cape Breton biomanufacturing plant expected to begin production by spring     Cape Breton   Family of woman swept out to sea at Cape Spear searching for answers     Newfoundland & Labrador   Halifax driver faces four charges in death of pedestrian     Halifax  Latest from Shopping Essentials Review: The laptop stand that’s perfect for travel This adhesive laptop stand helps improve my workstation when I’m away from home   2 hours ago    Shopping Essentials    Advertisement 1Story continues belowThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Police said 10 crew members abandoned the sinking boat, seven of whom were rescued by mainland Chinese authorities at around 1.30pm. The boat ultimately went down in Hong Kong waters.The Hong Kong Government Flying Service sent helicopters to conduct a search and found one sailor who was unconscious when pulled from the water. The sailor was later certified dead after being sent to Ruttonjee Hospital in Wan Chai.A search for two missing sailors was still under way as of Sunday afternoon. Photo: Government Flying ServiceAs of Sunday afternoon, the two remaining sailors were still missing, with a Marine Department search and rescue operation still ongoing.At the time of the incident, the local wind speed was moderate, according to the Hong Kong Observatory, at around 20kph, with waves reaching about four metres in height and a water temperature of 20 degrees Celsius.In January 2020, a fishing boat suspected of being used to smuggle frozen meat into mainland China sank in waters near Hong Kong International Airport, leaving one of seven crew members dead. The captain was arrested for endangering the safety of others at sea.AdvertisementAdvertisement",

    "https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/people/article/3154620/indonesian-jumped-ship-somali-waters-escape-abuse-chinese-fishing": "Indonesian jumped ship in Somali waters to escape abuse on Chinese fishing vessel: survivor recalls death and violence at sea | South China Morning Post AdvertisementHuman rightsThis Week in AsiaPeopleIndonesian jumped ship in Somali waters to escape abuse on Chinese fishing vessel: survivor recalls death and violence at sea\nBrando Brayend Tewuh made a desperate escape attempt after suffering abuse and watching workers die on vessels belonging to the Liao Dong Yu fleet\nHe tells This Week in Asia he saw men being beaten until they bled and some knocked overboard in accidents, their bodies sometimes never recovered\nReading Time:4 minutesWhy you can trust SCMP7Amy ChewPublished: 8:00am, 3 Nov 2021Updated: 8:02pm, 3 Nov 2021An Indonesian worker who jumped from a Chinese fishing vessel into Somali waters to escape horrific working conditions in which crew members were beaten, starved and killed in accidents has said he hopes “no one else will experience” what he and his friends suffered.AdvertisementBrando Brayend Tewuh, 29, jumped from the fishing vessel with three other Indonesians in August in a desperate attempt to escape the abuse and reach the shore of Somalia. But their bid was in vain; after drifting for hours far from land three of them were picked back up by the same ship, while the fourth man is thought to have drowned.“I will never, ever work on a ship again,” Tewuh told This Week in Asia as he recounted his ordeal, which ended soon after his escape attempt following an intervention by industry watchdogs and the Indonesian and Somali governments.Tewuh recalled how he had worked for months without pay, “often for 24 hours at a time with no sleep and little food” after signing a one-year contract to work aboard ships belonging to the Chinese Liao Dong Yu fleet.Brando Brayend Tewuh, right, who jumped from a Chinese fishing vessel to escape abuse. On the left, circled, is one of the men who jumped with him and is thought to have drowned in the attempt. Photo: HandoutAdvertisementThe first fatal accident he saw came in July 2020, when he and his fellow crew members had just finished a 24 hour shift with no sleep. They were eating their lunch when a bell rang to call them back to the deck to haul up the trawler net.Advertisement",

More info×Group 28Thank you for subscribing!We have more newslettersShow MeNo thanks, closeSee our\nPrivacy NoticeA man has died in a horror fishing tragedy after a boat capsized in the North Sea. The vessel turned over off the coast of Macduff, Aberdeenshire, on Thursday morning. The 69-year-old was found in the water by rescue crews after the incident but he was tragically pronounced dead shortly after.  Coastguard and lifeboat crews were scrambled to the scene of the accident after the alarm was raised. A search and rescue helicopter was also deployed to the incident. A spokesperson for the Coastguard said: “HM Coastguard responded to a report of a capsized boat on the shore near Macduff on 21 September.  READ MORE: Family pay tribute to their 'loving daughter' who died in suspected drugs incident “The alarm was raised at about 11.15am. The RNLI’s all-weather lifeboat from Fraserburgh and an inshore lifeboat from Macduff were sent, as well as the HM Coastguard search and rescue helicopter from Inverness.  “Fraserburgh and MacDuff Coastguard Rescue Teams also attended, and Police Scotland was alerted.”  A Police Scotland spokesperson said: “Around 12pm on Thursday, 21 September, 2023, a 69-year-old man was found in the water after a fishing boat overturned in the North Sea near Macduff. He was pronounced dead a short time later.“\nRead More\nRelated Articles\nTown in mourning after girl, 9, killed in collision with a tractor while riding her bike\nRead More\nRelated Articles\nScot brutally killed by XL Bully dog would have been against ban on the breed, says friend\nThere are not believed to be any suspicious circumstances surrounding the death and a report will be submitted to the Procurator Fiscal.” Safety inspectors have travelled to Macduff to probe the tragedy. A spokesperson for the Marine Accident Investigation Branch (MAIB) said: “The MAIB has launched a safety investigation into a fatal accident involving the fishing vessel off Macduff which occurred yesterday. A team of inspectors have travelled to the area to gather evidence to understand the circumstances that led to this tragic accident.” For more news, follow us on Facebook and Twitter but never miss Rose – Eye of the Needle\nOn Target\nDr Jozelle Miller\nThe World Around Us\nRandom Thoughts\nAdvice\nKitchen Corner\nWhat’s on Fleek this week\nHealth Wise\nPhysician’s Weekly\nBusiness Buzz\nHey Rosie!\nPrime the pump\nePaper\nObituaries\nIn Memoriam / Acknowledgement\nTribute\nContact Us\nAdvertise With Us\nLetters To The Editor\nGeneral Contact Information\nContact our Webmaster\nAbout Us\nPrivacy Policy\nInteractive Media Ltd\nSt. Vincent & the Grenadines\nSubscribe\ntap\nNews\nFront Page\nNews\nBreaking News\nPress Release\nFeatures\nSpecial Features\nFrom the Courts\nSports\nRegional / World\nOpinions\nEditorial\nOur Readers’ Opinions\nBassy – Love Vine\nDr. Fraser- Point of View\nR. Rose – Eye of the Needle\nOn Target\nDr Jozelle Miller\nThe World Around Us\nRandom Thoughts\nAdvice\nKitchen Corner\nWhat’s on Fleek this week\nHealth Wise\nPhysician’s Weekly\nBusiness Buzz\nHey Rosie!\nPrime the pump\nePaper\nObituaries\nIn Memoriam / Acknowledgement\nTribute\nContact Us\nAdvertise With Us\nLetters To The Editor\nGeneral Contact Information\nContact our Webmaster\nAbout Us\nPrivacy Policy\nInteractive Media Ltd\nSt. Vincent & the Grenadines\nSubscribe\nNews\nFebruary 1, 2024\nFisherman dies in suspected drowning at Cumberland Bay\nThe Police in the Spring Village district are investigating the circumstances surrounding a suspected drowning that occurred on Wednesday  January 31, 2024 at Cumberland Bay.\nThe incident claimed the life of Devon Morgan, alias “Sleepy”, a 33-year-old Fisherman of Barrouallie.\nAccording to preliminary investigations, about 12:25 pm, police at the Spring Village Police Station received a telephone report that stated that someone had drowned at Cumberland Bay.\nUpon arrival at the scene, they met a male lying on the shore of Cumberland Bay in an unresponsive state and surrounded by bystanders. The deceased was later identified by a fisherwoman of Barrouallie.\nReports further suggest that Morgan was among a group of persons who were fishing in the waters off Cumberland Bay. He reportedly encountered difficulties and fell overboard from the vessel he was in. Other fishers rendered assistance, pulled Morgan out of the water, and performed CPR on him without success.\nMorgan was pronounced deceased at the scene by a medical practitioner.\nA post-mortem examination is expected to be conducted on the body to ascertain the cause of death.\nThe RSVGPF extends condolences to everyone who is negatively affected by this incident. Anyone with information that can assist with the investigation is encouraged to contact the Spring Village Police Station at 1-784-458-2322, any police station or police officer you are comfortable speaking with, or call 999/911. Information received will be treated confidentially.\nThe investigation is ongoing.\n{\"carousel\":\"Carousel\"}\nComments\nALSO IN THE NEWS\nPress Release\nChateaubelair men held on firearm, drug charges\nChristina\nJanuary 29, 2025\nTwo Chateaubelair residents were charged in connection with an unlicensed firearm, a large quantity of cannabis, and a significant sum of cash suspect...\nPress Release\nSanitation worker remanded for stealing strong rum\nChristina\nJanuary 29, 2025\nOn January 27, 2025, police arrested and charged Brian Rock, a 56-year-old sanitation worker of New Montrose, with the offence of theft.     "https://www.socialnews.xyz/2021/11/23/fisherman-from-pudukottai-missing-after-boat-overturns-in-sea/": "Fisherman from Pudukottai missing after boat overturns in sea - Social News XYZ\nHome\nAuthors\nPolitics\nNational\nInternational\nDiaspora\nDiplomacy\nMovies\nSouth Cinema\nSocial News XYZ Reviews\nBollywood\nReviews\nBox Office\nMovie Schedules\nHollywood\nInterviews\nTV\nGallery\nTollywood\nBollywood\nHollywood\nActresses\nPolitics\nSports\nOther\nVideos\nMovies News\nTrailers\nJukebox\nLive Events\nLive TV\nBusiness\nSports\nGreen Bag\nCricket\nAthletics\nBadminton\nFootball\nGolf\nHockey\nMotorsports\nTennis\nOther Sports\nScience/Tech\nBusiness Wire India\nHealth\nStudy\nEnvironment\nWildlife\nArchives\nTelugu\nGeneral\nCommentary\nCrime\nDisaster\nAccident\nDefence\nArmy\nHome » General » Crime » Fisherman from Pudukottai missing after boat overturns in sea\nFisherman from Pudukottai missing after boat overturns in sea\nPosted By: Gopi\nNovember 23, 2021\nChennai, Nov 23 (SocialNews.XYZ) A fisherman of Pudukottai district went missing after the boat in which he had gone for fishing on Monday night overturned in strong winds.\nTwo fishermen, K. Ganeshan (45) and L. Manimuthu(42) had gone for fishing in a fibre boat from Kottaipattinam village in Pudukottai district. The boat owned by Ganeshan was not registered with the fisheries department.\nAccording to sources in the Coastal Security Group, the two set sail by 7 p.m. and the boat overturned in strong winds by 8.30 pm. While those fishing in the nearby areas rescued Ganeshan from the heavy tides, Manimuthu went missing and could not be traced and located.\nLocal fishermen have gone into the sea in search of the missing Manimuth. Coastal Security Group is also monitoring the situation, sources said.\nSource: IANS\nFacebook Comments\nAbout GopiGopi Adusumilli is a Programmer. He is the editor of SocialNews.XYZ and President of AGK Fire Inc.\nHe enjoys designing websites, developing mobile applications and publishing news articles on current events from various authenticated news sources.\nWhen it comes to writing he likes to write about current world politics and Indian Movies. His future plans include developing SocialNews.XYZ into a News website that has no bias or judgment towards any.\nHe can be reached at gopi@socialnews.xyzMail | Web | Twitter\nLike this:Like     "https://www.southcoasttoday.com/story/news/2021/08/16/uscg-looking-off-nantucket-overboard-fisherman-new-bedford-blue-wave-fishing-vessel-cape-cod/8147890002/": "USCG looking off Nantucket for overboard fisherman from New BedfordNew Bedford Mayor Mitchell: Offshore wind is 'here to stay' despite federal changesNews Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWSUSCG looking for overboard fisherman from New Bedford aboard the Blue Wave vessel Linda RoyStandard-TimesNEW BEDFORD — The Coast Guard on Monday morning responded to a call off the Nantucket coast for a man overboard from the commercial fishing vessel Blue Wave out of New Bedford.As of 3 p.m. Monday, search and rescue was still underway, according to Petty Officer Ryan Noel with the USCG First District External Affairs office. According to the USCG, the man was not wearing a life jacket. The agency's Twitter post noted that crews from the USCG Air Station Cape Cod were actively searching for a man overboard off the southeast coast of Nantucket. The Coast Guard Cutter Tybee is also assisting in the search.The man was aboard the fishing vessel Blue Wave based in New Bedford, the post said.According to the Cape Cod Times, Air Station Cape Cod received a notification at 11:20 p.m. from the vessel Blue Wave, a boat out of New Bedford, which reported the man missing. The man was woken up because he had the next watch, but never showed up, Noel said. Air Station Cape Cod began searching at 12:47 a.m. Monday.Standard-Times digital producer Linda Roy can be reached at lroy@s-t.com. Image:  Paul Fleet/123rf.com          A fisherman is missing and another was  rescued after they fell off a commercial fishing vessel  at St Lucia, northern KwaZulu-Natal, on Sunday.             Jan Hoffman, station commander of the National Sea Rescue Institute at St Lucia, said the fishermen went overboard  at about 7am at Mapelane Bay.\"On arrival on the scene, it was determined that the two local fishermen had been ejected off the boat into the surf line.\"A local charter vessel had launched and they   rescued one of the fishermen in the surf line. He was safe on the beach, where NSRI medics treated him for shock and minor lacerations.\"Hoffman said the life jacket and raincoat of the missing fisherman had been recovered during the search,  but there was no sign of him.\"Despite an extensive sea and shoreline search, there remains no sign of the  fisherman.\"Police have opened an investigation and police search and rescue are continuing  the search.\"TimesLIVE                  British diver rescued off Malaysia says his son died at seaA Dutch teenager who disappeared after going diving off the coast of Malaysia is dead, according to his father who was found drifting at sea on ...News2 years ago      Dudula marchers issue threat: Once we're active in all provinces 'they will see'Operation Dudula commended its supporters for not responding with violence when they were “provoked” during their march in Durban on Sunday.News2 years ago                       Next Article    Would you like to comment on this article? Sign Up\nTerms of Service | Privacy Policy  Guyana NewsBody of fisherman found at Jib\nMahindra PersaudBy Stabroek News\nMarch 8, 2024\nA fisherman who was last seen alive on a boat moored at Jib, Essequibo Coast was found dead yesterday morning in the sea.\nThe police said in a report that the death of Mahindra Persaud, 23,  of Lot 259 Devonshire Castle Back Street, Essequibo Coast occurred sometime between Wednesday 6th March, 2024 at about 8 pm and Thursday 7th March, 2024 at about 6 am.The police say that according to Paishwarlall Chattergoon, 55, a boat captain,  on Tuesday 5th March, at about 11 am, he,  Persaud and Johnny Toro, a fisherman of Lot 80 Jib, left and went to sea to catch fish. However, the boat broke down and had to be  towed by another boat which is owned by the Paishwarlall.    Paishwarlall further said that on Wednesday 6th March at about 7.30 pm he,  Persaud and Toro moored both of the boats at the Jib seawall about 300 feet out in the sea and he left the now deceased and Toro and he went home.According to Toro, he was on the boat, which had  broken down while Persaud  was on the other boat. At about 8 pm he left the boat he was on and went home.\nYesterday, at about 6.30 am the body of Persaud was seen floating about 100 feet out at sea by a passerby.The police were summoned and the body was escorted to the Suddie Public Hospital.    According to his brother, Mervin Persaud, Mahindra left for sea four days ago. The brother would usually do that regularly as a way of providing for his family. Mervin said that he did not receive a call from his brother for four days but thought to himself everything was fine.“My brother means everything to us, he usually goes to catch his fish and return, my mother is ill and we all join to take care of her since our father died”, Mervin said.\nTrending\nKaneville girl crushed by truck may never walk again\nAli, Rubio agree to “jointly address”  illegal immigration -US State Dep’t\nTrump’s USAID order to affect programmes in Guyana\nMother charges negligence as causing baby’s death during childbirth at GPH\nBanks Chairman rejects claims Chinese-owned businesses being favoured\nWoman charged with  malicious damage to $1.6m  in items at Golden Grove\nGRA names Japanese company for inspection of cars to be exported here\nBeneficiaries can collect cash grant for those who died before cheque issued  – AG\nRamson, Flue-Bess face off over culture, youth and sport\nMore in Guyana NewsGRA names Japanese company for inspection of cars to be exported here\n6 h ago$14m jackpot win still to be claimed – lottery company\n6 h agoTrump’s USAID order to affect programmes in Guyana\n16 h agoGPHC successfully completes breast reconstructions\n16 h agoKaneville girl crushed by truck may never walk again\n16 h agoRamson, Flue-Bess face off over culture, youth and sport\n16 h agoCommentsRelated CoverageJib fisher found dead with suspected marks of violence\nSeptember 10, 2011Jib fisher died of fractured spine\nSeptember 15, 2011Murder suspected in death of young Jib fisher\nSeptember 11, 2011\nSign Up For The Morning BriefA FREE roundup of top news from Guyana you might otherwise miss. FM\nLIVE: Berur FM\nHome\nCounties\nFisherman dies while peeing from a moving boat\nBy James Omoro\n|\n1yr ago\nLoading Article...\nFor the best experience, please enable JavaScript in your browser settings.\n800   A boat used by fishermen in Lake Victoria during a past event (James Omoro, Standard).\nGrief has gripped fishermen in Homa Bay County after one of them drowned and died while peeing from a moving boat in Lake Victoria. The fisherman identified as Charles Opondo drowned in the Lake on Tuesday evening during a fishing expedition. Opondo, attached to Litare Beach in Mbita Sub-County, was involved in an accident when he was in the company of his fellow fishermen. According to the Assistant Chief of Kamasengre West Sub-location Meshack Wachianga, fishermen reported to his office that Odongo was standing in the moving boat to respond to a short nature call. But he lost balance and fell into the water before his body disappeared.\n\"Fishermen have reported that Odongo stood in the boat and began peeing in the lake without informing the coxswain to slow down. He eventually fell into the lake before his body sank and disappeared,\" Wachianga said. The administrator urged fishermen to put on life jackets to prevent deaths in case of such an accident. \"Suppose he wore a life jacket, his body would have floated for some time. This would have enabled his colleagues to rescue him,\" Wachianga said. He urged fishermen to embrace communication when they are travelling in a boat. \"Fishermen should communicate to one another so that one is able to tell a coxswain to slow down or stop the boat when they are pressed in any way,\" he added.\nLitare Beach Management Unit Chairman Isaiah Pero appealed to residents and well-wishers to intervene with humanitarian aid and help them look for Odongo's body. He said they had begun looking for the body.  Stay informed. Subscribe to our newsletter\nBy clicking on the SIGN UP button, you agree to our Terms & Conditions and the Privacy Policy\nSIGN UP\n\"I appeal to well-wishers to help us look for the body of our colleague,\" Pero said.Stay Informed, Stay Empowered: Download the Standard ePaper App!\nOdongo is a resident of South Kanyamkago Sub-location, Uriri Sub-county in Migori County. from Kaneohe Bay\nBy Star-Advertiser staff\nJune 29, 2023\nShare on Facebook\nShare on X\nShare by email\nHonolulu firefighters early this morning pulled an unresponsive woman out of Kaneohe Bay after resuming a search for a missing person that started Wednesday evening.\nThe body was transferred to an awaiting Honolulu Emergency Medical Services ambulance at about 7:20 a.m., according to the Honolulu Fire Department.\nEMS pronounced the 62-year-old woman dead.\nHFD initially responded to a 911 call at about 7 p.m. Wednesday for a missing fisherman near the sandbar in Kaneohe. It was reported that the woman went fishing early in the morning and did not return.\nFour units with 10 personnal responded to the call, with the first unit arriving at 7:11 p.m.\nFirefighters suspended search operations at about 9:30 p.m. due to darkness, with plans to resume the search at first light today.\nDon't miss out on what's happening!\nStay in touch with breaking news, as it happens, conveniently in your email inbox. It's FREE!\nEmail\nSign Up\nBy clicking to sign up, you agree to Star-Advertiser's and Google's Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. This form is protected by reCAPTCHA.\nHFD returned to the scene this morning, along with the Honolulu Police Department, the U.S. Coast Guard, and the Kaneohe Marine Corps Base Hawaii’s Waterfront Operations.\nHFD said the body matching the description of the missing person was found near Paradise Bay at Kahaluu.\nHonolulu police have classified the incident as an unattended death.\nPolice said Thursday morning, a fisherman observed a female body in the ocean, and that HFD transported it to a nearby pier.\n“Checks of the body did not reveal any suspicious injuries or foul play,” HPD said.\n0 Comments\nBy participating in online discussions you acknowledge that you have agreed to the Terms of Service. possible drowning off Kona\nBy Star-Advertiser staff\nJuly 25, 2023\nShare on Facebook\nShare on X\nShare by email\nHawaii island police say a teen found unresponsive in the ocean while spearfishing off the west side has died.\nThe victim has been identified as Yohan Choi, 17, of Kailua-Kona.\nPolice said at about 4:30 p.m. Monday, Kona patrol officers responded to a report of a missing spear fisherman near the Hokulia public beach access.\nIt was reported that four fishermen, including Choi, entered the ocean at 1:30 p.m. Three of them got out three hours later, but Choi was not with them, and could not be located.\nAfter a search was conducted, Choi was found unresponsive on the ocean floor. He was brought to shore, where CPR was initiated until Fire Department personnel arrived to take over. Attempts to resuscitate him were unsuccessful.\nHe was taken to Kona Community Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 5:29 p.m.\nDon't miss out on what's happening!\nStay in touch with breaking news, as it happens, conveniently in your email inbox. It's FREE!\nEmail\nSign Up\nBy clicking to sign up, you agree to Star-Advertiser's and Google's Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. This form is protected by reCAPTCHA.\nPolice are investigating the case as a possible drowning. They have initiated a coroner’s inquest investigation and ordered an autopsy to determine the exact cause of death.\nAnyone with information is encouraged to contact Kona Patrol Officer Kyle Murray at Kyle.Murray@hawaiicounty.gov or call the police department’s non-emergency line at 808-935-3311.\n0 Comments\nBy participating in online discussions you acknowledge that you have agreed to the Terms of Service. GilPublished on: Mar 04, 2024, 6:27 amCopiedTHE body of a fisherman who was declared missing was found floating in the waters off Bantayan town on Bantayan Island at around 7 a.m. on Monday, March 4, 2024. The 20-year-old victim, Anmer Dereal, of Madridejos town, was positively identified by his mother Analyn.The fisherman who found him dragged his body towards the shore using a pumpboat. Dereal was declared missing when he failed to return after he went fishing in the seawaters off Madridejos town last Friday evening, March 1, 2024.A certain Judy Jagdon posted in her social media page asking residents of the nearby municipalities to get in touch with the victim’s family or the police if they saw him. The Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) has launched search operations to locate the four missing crew of a fishing boat that sank near the island village of Tumalutab, Zamboanga City on Thursday, February 1. A photo handout shows a PCG personnel talking to a fisherman while conducting search operations. (SunStar Zamboanga)SunStar ZamboangaPublished on: Feb 02, 2024, 10:59 amCopiedTHE Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) launched search operations to locate the four missing crew of a fishing boat that sunk off Zamboanga City, the PCG said Friday, February 2024.Captain Larry Cendaña, Zamboanga Coast Guard Station commander, said the fishing boat, named RCT-999, sunk around 2 a.m. Thursday, February 1, near the island village of Tumalutab, Zamboanga City.Cendaña did not identify the four missing crewmen except they were part of the 38 crew members of the ill-fated RCT-999.Investigation showed the RCT-999 sunk after it was battered by big waves while on a fishing venture near Tumalutab Island.The Coast Guard District Southwestern Mindanao (CGDSWM) said personnel of the Coast Guard Sub-Station (CGSS)-Sangali immediately responded and rescued 34 of the 38 crew of RCT-999 utilizing the vessel of the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources.    “Currently, the search and rescue efforts are ongoing in the hopes of finding the missing individuals,” the CGDSWM said in a statement.Meanwhile, CGDSWM is closely monitoring the area to address any potential traces of oil spills.     "https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2023/06/22/2003801987": "Fisher suspected of murder arrested upon arrival at port - Taipei Times\nFront Page\nTaiwan News\nBusiness\nEditorial & Opinion\nSports\nWorld News\nFeatures\nBilingual Pages\nSearchSearch\nAll\nFront Page\nTaiwan News\nBusiness\nEditorial & Opinion\nSports\nWorld News\nFeatures\nBilingual Pages\nGO\nHome\nTaiwan News\nThu, Jun 22, 2023 page3\nFisher suspected of murder arrested upon arrival at port\nStaff writer, with CNA\nA Vietnamese fisherman who allegedly killed an Indonesian colleague on a Taiwan-flagged fishing vessel on the high seas in April was arrested upon the boat’s return to the Port of Kaohsiung last week, local authorities said on Tuesday.A team of Criminal Investigation Bureau agents boarded the Feng Kuo No. 616 as soon as the vessel berthed at the port and arrested the migrant worker, the bureau said.The Kaohsiung District Court approved prosecutors’ request to detain the man on suspicion of homicide, it said.\nA Vietnamese fisherman is escorted by Coast Guard Administration officials and Criminal Investigation Bureau agents upon his arrival at the Port of Kaohsiung on Tuesday.\nPhoto: Yao Yueh-hung, Taipei Times\nThe 43-year-old suspect had been locked in a storage room in the ship’s hold by the captain since April 28, when he allegedly killed a 34-year-old crew member, bureau International Criminal Affairs official Su Li-tsung (蘇立琮) told a news conference.The vessel was sailing about 674 nautical miles (1,248km) off the southeast of Cape Town when the alleged murder took place, Su said.\nAfter locking the suspect in the storage room, the captain sailed to Mauritius to seek help and was granted permission to berth at Port Louis, Su said.Mauritius did not launch a judicial investigation into the case, because Taiwan-flagged vessels are under the jurisdiction of Taiwan, he added.Taiwanese police officers normally stationed in South Africa traveled to Mauritius to collect evidence from the fishing boat, before the vessel left Port Louis on May 16, Su said.\nMost Popular\n1HSR to encircle Taiwan\n2MOFA welcomes Rubio’s Taiwan     "https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/5087508": "Indonesian fisherman dies after falling overboard off Taiwan's Penghu\n| Taiwan News | Jan. 30, 2024 14:40漢EN漢ENPoliticsAllForeign AffairsCross-straitBusinessAllInvestingTechSocietyHealthCultureEnvironmentLifestyleAllCuisineTravelEntertainmentSportsFeature PhotoOpinionWorldSponsoredMOREPoliticsAllForeign AffairsCross-straitBusinessAllInvestingTechSocietyHealthCultureEnvironmentLifestyleAllCuisineTravelEntertainmentSportsFeature PhotoOpinionWorldSponsoredLoading...About UsContact UsDirectory of TaiwanAbout UsContact UsDirectory of TaiwanTaiwan News © 2025 All Rights Reserved.Home/SocietyIndonesian fisherman dies after falling overboard off Taiwan's Penghu\nFisherman fell overboard 111 km southwest of Qimei, Penghu\nJan. 30, 2024 14:40(CGA photo)\n1321TAIPEI (Taiwan News) — An Indonesian fisherman died after falling overboard in waters around Penghu on Monday night (Jan. 29). The Coast Guard Administration's (CGA) Fleet Branch Penghu Offshore Flotilla received a report that a 22-year-old Indonesian man fell overboard on the Ta Chin Man No. 16 (大進滿16號) operating in waters 111 km (60 NM) southwest of Qimei, Penghu, per CNA. The CGA dispatched a patrol boat to conduct a search and rescue operation.The fisherman was found dead by CGA officers near the fishing vessel. His body was transported by the fishing boat, while escorted by the CGA patrol boat.Ta Chin Man No. 16 docked at Magong Harbor. (CGA photo)Early on Tuesday morning (Jan. 30), the fishing vessel returned to Magong Harbor and the incident was reported to law enforcement for investigation.The CGA said the Penghu-registered boat had one Taiwanese and six Indonesian crew members onboard, including the deceased Indonesian worker.# Indonesian migrant workers# CGA# fishing boat accident# lost at sea# fishery worker# fishery workers# drowningRelated Articles20-year-old male drowns in northern Taiwan creekSep. 2, 2024 17:293 divers trapped, one drowns in south Taiwan Aug. 14, 2024 19:09Indian American student drowns at south Taiwan beachJun. 26, 2024 11:46Taiwan president attends Coast Guard frigate handoverJun. 15, 2024 14:51Woman from Philippines drowns near south Taiwan waterfallJun. 13, 2024 14:34Chinese man arrested for arriving by motorboat in Taiwan identified as ex-navy officerJun. 12, 2024 12:27MOST READTaiwan receipt lottery reveals winning numbers for November-DecemberRemains of foreign tourist missing since Taiwan's 403 Hualien quake foundTrump proposes tariffs on Taiwan's semiconductorsLunar New Year red envelope traditions and etiquetteTaiwan receipt lottery winners at PX Mart and 7-ElevenEV car crash in Taoyuan kills 4, injures 4New Taipei topped Taiwan scratch card winnings in 2024Chinese AI DeepSeek censors on Taiwan, Tiananmen SquareTaiwan could see temperatures below 5 C this weekMagnitude 5.2 earthquake jolts TaitungKeoni EveringtonTaiwan News, Staff Writer1321",
    "https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/5115311": "Chinese fisherman goes missing off Taiwan outer island\n| Taiwan News | Mar. 15, 2024 12:21漢EN漢ENPoliticsAllForeign AffairsCross-straitBusinessAllInvestingTechSocietyHealthCultureEnvironmentLifestyleAllCuisineTravelEntertainmentSportsFeature PhotoOpinionWorldSponsoredMOREPoliticsAllForeign AffairsCross-straitBusinessAllInvestingTechSocietyHealthCultureEnvironmentLifestyleAllCuisineTravelEntertainmentSportsFeature PhotoOpinionWorldSponsoredLoading...About UsContact UsDirectory of TaiwanAbout UsContact UsDirectory of TaiwanTaiwan News © 2025 All Rights Reserved.Home/SocietyChinese fisherman goes missing off Taiwan outer island\nChinese fisherman falls overboard about 5 km east of Matsu's Beigan Island\nMar. 15, 2024 12:21Coast Guard Administration personnel search for missing Chinese fisherman. (CGA photo)\n1507TAIPEI (Taiwan News) — On Thursday (March 14), the same day a Chinese fishing boat sank off of Kinmen, a Chinese fisherman from another Chinese fishing vessel fell overboard off of Matsu, and the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) is assisting in searching for fishermen from both boats.The fisherman fell overboard about 5.55 km (3 NM) east of Matsu's Beigan Island, about four km outside of the island's restricted waters, reported CNA. The CGA received a notice from the Lienchiang County Government at 12:30 a.m. on Friday (March 15) and sent a ship to assist the Chinese coast guard in the search and rescue mission.A source said that a 26-year-old crew member from the Chinese fishing boat \"Minlianyu 60911\" fell overboard at noon on Thursday. Initially, the fishing vessel attempted to rescue the man, but they were unsuccessful, so they returned to China to report the incident and Chinese authorities then informed the Lienchiang County Government.The CGA dispatched two or three ships in the vicinity of the incident. They plan to conduct a coordinated search for 72 hours.The source told CNA that China also sent a coast guard ship and three to four fishing boats to help look for the fisherman.Earlier on Thursday, another Chinese fishing boat, the \"Minlongyu 61222,\" sank 27 km southwest of Kinmen with six crew members onboard. Chinese vessels had found four of the crew, but two of them had died. The other two crew members are still missing and a joint mission between Chinese and Taiwanese coast guard ships to find them is still underway.# ship accident# missing sailor# Chinese fishing vessels# Chinese fishing boat# Chinese fishermen# MatsuRelated ArticlesTaiwan lawmaker condemns Chinese fishing vessel incursionsAug. 19, 2024 15:59Taiwan releases Chinese fishers, fines them NT$300,000 for poachingJul. 10, 2024 11:57Taiwan outlying island legislators seek Chinese firms for construction projectsJul. 3, 2024 17:48Video shows Chinese fishing boat on island controlled by Taiwan militaryApr. 29, 2024 12:19Illegal crab and octopus pots removed from Taiwan's MatsuApr. 17, 2024 13:20Taiwan’s annual Dajia Matsu pilgrimage sets offApr. 6, 2024 13:08MOST READTaiwan receipt lottery reveals winning numbers for November-DecemberRemains of foreign tourist missing since Taiwan's 403 Hualien quake foundTrump proposes tariffs on Taiwan's semiconductorsLunar New Year red envelope traditions and etiquetteTaiwan receipt lottery winners at PX Mart and 7-ElevenEV car crash in Taoyuan kills 4, injures 4New Taipei topped Taiwan scratch card winnings in 2024Chinese AI DeepSeek censors on Taiwan, Tiananmen SquareTaiwan could see temperatures below 5 C this weekMagnitude 5.2 earthquake jolts TaitungKeoni EveringtonTaiwan News, Staff Writer1507",

[ Photo illustration by ASHLEY DYE and LUIS SANTANA | Times ]By Amy GehrtTimes staffPublished Oct. 14, 2021|Updated Oct. 14, 2021The Coast Guard has called off the search for a 69-year-old man who was reported missing Tuesday night.A crew member aboard the fishing vessel High Voltage called a dock manager in Madeira Beach to report that they believed Ricky Baker had fallen overboard about 46 miles from the shore of Venice around 8 p.m., the Coast Guard said in a news release Wednesday night.The dock manager notified watchstanders at Coast Guard Sector St. Petersburg at 9 p.m. and a search got underway, the agency said.Boats and a helicopter searched throughout the night, the Coast Guard said in a tweet.#Breaking USCG Station Cortez, Air Station Clearwater,  & cutters Diamondback & Shrike crews are searching for a 69 yr old man overboard from a fishing vessel 46 mil offshore Venice, FL. Crews have searched through the night. Mariners w/ info can contact CG on VHF radio ch 16. pic.twitter.com/kMBQkFGdlX— USCGSoutheast (@USCGSoutheast) October 13, 2021\nCrews searched for about 14 hours, covering around 100 square miles, before Baker’s body was located and recovered, the release said.“Our condolences go to Mr. Baker’s family and friends,” said Shawn Lansing, deputy commander for Sector St. Petersburg. “We are relieved to provide some closure to his loved ones.”This is a developing story.     "https://www.the-star.co.ke/counties/coast/2021-12-15-search-intensified-for-fisherman-who-drowned-in-indian-ocean/": "Search intensified for fisherman who drowned in Indian Oceannews counties business healthopinion sports siasasasa ADVERTISEMENTSearch intensified for fisherman who drowned in Indian OceanAthman  failed to swim back up hours after diving under the ocean bed for lobstersby cheti praxidesCounties15 December 2021 - 19:00ADVERTISEMENTIn Summary\nMohamed Athman,28, was among a group of eight lobster divers who had gone hunting for the edible sea food at the Manda-Bruno channel in Lamu island.\nHe was reported missing hours later by his colleagues after he failed to swim back up after he dived into the ocean for the lobster.\nDivers retrieve a body from the Indian Ocean in Lamu.\nDivers in Lamu have intensified their search for a lobster fisherman who went missing at sea on Monday.\nMohamed Athman, 28, was among a group of eight lobster divers who had gone hunting for the sea food at the Manda-Bruno channel in Lamu island.\nHe was reported missing hours later by his colleagues after he failed to swim back up hours after diving.\nNormally, a group of lobster fishermen will anchor their boat on the water then disperse to dive for the lobster in different locations and then meet in the boat after a few hours to head back home.\nAll the seven other fishermen turned up at the agreed location but Athman did not, prompting them to alert the Kenya Maritime Authority office in Lamu.\nA search was immediately mounted by divers from the KMA, Red Cross, county government and local divers.\nTwo days later, there has been no sign of the man and the divers now fear that he might have drowned and his body washed away downstream.\nLamu County government disaster management director Shee Kupi said the search and recovery efforts have been intensified and are being concentrated at the Manda-Bruno channel.\nHe however said the search will also be expanded to surrounding areas as the chances of the body having been washed further away from the rough waves at the channel are high.\n“Unfortunately, we are no longer searching for a living person but are trying to recover a body. Chances of him being alive are nil at this point considering the location he disappeared at. The channel is very rough and the water current here is very strong,” Kupi said.\nHe urged fishermen and sailors in Lamu to exercise extreme caution while at sea and keep off from dangerous channels like the Manda-Bruno.\nOther renowned dangerous and killer channels in the Lamu Archipelago include Mlango wa Tanu in Mkokoni, Mlango wa Ali in Kiwayu, Mlango wa Bomani in Kiunga, the Mkanda and Shella channels and Mlango wa Kipungani.\nThey are labeled ‘killer channels’ because of their location in the deepest parts of the ocean and are also characterised by rough tides and deadly waves.\nHundreds have lost their lives in those channels.\n“The sea is normally rough in December going onto January and so it’s better for all those plying here to be very careful,”Kupi  said.\nThere have been continued calls from residents and county leaders for the establishment of a well-defined emergency rescue centre to help save lives during marine accidents.\nIn February this year, the decomposing body of lobster fisherman Mbwana Badi from Kizingitini island in Lamu East was retrieved at Kwabuka beach in Faza island after he drowned at Rasini area.\n-Edited by SKanyaraADVERTISEMENTADVERTISEMENTLatest ArticlesKenya seeking new donors to support HIV response3h agoJOHN MUCHANGIHealthNews Brief: Ruto plannig to dismiss 15 PSs in major shuffle3h agoSTAR EDITORRealtimeRuto chairs virtual EAC Extraordinary summit4h agoAllan KisiaNewsADVERTISEMENTNewsWorldAfricaCorridors-of-powerInfographicsBig-readFact CheckerNews BriefStar-farmerTwitter SpaceRealtimeBreakfast-briefingCountiesRift-valleyNairobiNorth-easternCoastCentralNyanzaWesternEasternBusinessKenyaMarketsCommentaryHealthOpinionColumnistsLeaderStar-blogsCartoonSportsFootballAthleticsRugbyTennisGolfBoxingBasketballSiasaSasaLifestyleTechnologyEntertainmentSocietyFashionFoodTravelBooksEventsPartner SitesMpashoRadio JamboKiss 100Classic 105Privacy PolicyTerms and Conditions© The Star 2024.     "https://www.the-star.co.ke/counties/nyanza/2023-04-13-fisherman-who-went-missing-found-dead-on-ringiti-island/": "Fisherman who went missing found dead on Ringiti Islandnews counties business healthopinion sports siasasasa ADVERTISEMENTFisherman who went missing found dead on Ringiti IslandBernard Obonyo went missing on Tuesday before his body was found in Lake Victoria watersby ROBERT OMOLLOCounties13 April 2023 - 13:56ADVERTISEMENTIn SummaryHis colleagues said they suspect Obonyo was murdered by unknown people before his body was dumped in the lake waters.The fisherman’s body had visible injuries like deep cuts on the neck and his hands.\nSome residents near Lake Victoria in  Homa Bay county\nA 37-year-old fisherman who went missing two days ago has been found dead at Ringiti Island in Suba North constituency.\nBernard Obonyo went missing on Tuesday before his body was found in Lake Victoria waters on Thursday afternoon.\nHis colleagues said they suspect Obonyo was murdered by unknown people before his body was dumped in the lake waters.\nThe fisherman’s body had visible injuries like deep cuts on the neck and his hands.\nRingiti Island beach management unit treasurer Daniel Sure said they spotted the body when it was floating in the lake.\n\"It was spotted by some fishermen who went to bathe at the lake shore. They informed security officers about the incident,\" Sure said.\n“Some fishermen who went to bathe discovered Obonyo’s body after we had been searching for the body for two days. We suspect he was murdered because his body had some injuries.\"\nSpeaking on Thursday over the matter, the BMU officer said Obonyo was last seen when he left his house to go for a fishing expedition in the lake.\nHe said they have been looking for their colleague since then.\n“We were worried by his absence since he went fishing. It is unfortunate that he is dead,” he said.\nThe body was removed from the lake by a group of fishermen.\nHoma Bay county police commander Samson Kinne said they are undertaking investigations to enable them to know the people behind the death of the fisherman.\n“Investigations are ongoing into the cause of death. We are asking residents with information about those who killed Obonyo to report to him,” Kinne said.\nThe officer asked fishermen to remain vigilant and report cases of attacks when they are operating in the lake.\n“We also want them to report colleagues who operate illegal businesses in the lake,” he said.\nThe fisherman’s body was moved to Homa Bay County Referral Hospital mortuary for postmortem.ADVERTISEMENTADVERTISEMENTLatest ArticlesKenya seeking new donors to support HIV response3h agoJOHN MUCHANGIHealthNews Brief: Ruto plannig to dismiss 15 PSs in major shuffle3h agoSTAR EDITORRealtimeRuto chairs virtual EAC Extraordinary summit4h agoAllan KisiaNewsADVERTISEMENTNewsWorldAfricaCorridors-of-powerInfographicsBig-readFact CheckerNews BriefStar-farmerTwitter SpaceRealtimeBreakfast-briefingCountiesRift-valleyNairobiNorth-easternCoastCentralNyanzaWesternEasternBusinessKenyaMarketsCommentaryHealthOpinionColumnistsLeaderStar-blogsCartoonSportsFootballAthleticsRugbyTennisGolfBoxingBasketballSiasaSasaLifestyleTechnologyEntertainmentSocietyFashionFoodTravelBooksEventsPartner SitesMpashoRadio JamboKiss 100Classic 105Privacy PolicyTerms and Conditions© The Star 2024. Meanwhile the matter has been reported at Ngengu police station,” Oketch said.\nHis colleagues mourned him as a hardworking and disciplined fisherman.\nSteven Ouma, one of his colleagues said Oguta was a resourceful man in giving advice to members at the beach.\n“We have lost an integral person in our midst.
